DOC.HEAD: Phillies' Mulholland Hurls Season's 8th No-Hitter, a Record
DOC.TEXT: Terry Mulholland of Philadelphia Phillies pitched the eighth no-hitter of the baseball season Wednesday night, the most ever by major league pitchers in one year. His performance, sealed in the ninth inning when third baseman Charlie Hayes caught a line drive by pinch hitter Gary Carter, lifted the Phillies to a 6-0 defeat of the San Francisco Giants. The season's eighth no-hitter surpassed the modern record of seven set in 1917 and 1908. Mulholland (7-6) struck out eight and walked none in making baseball history against the team that traded him to Philadelphia last season. Only one batter reached base against Mulholland. Rick Parker reached first base on Hayes' throwing error to lead off the seventh inning, but was erased on a double play. It seemed only natural that the record would be surpassed in a season already becoming known as the year of the no-hitter. The no-hit parade started on April 11 when the California Angels' Mark Langston and Mike Witt combined to beat Seattle. Randy Johnson then pitched the first no-hitter in Seattle history, beating Detroit on June 2. Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers pitched his unprecedented sixth no-hitter to beat the Oakland A's on June 11. Oakland's Dave Stewart and the Los Angeles' Dodgers' Fernando Valenzuela made another bit of history on June 29 by pitching no-hitters on the same day different leagues. Less than 24 hours later, Andy Hawkins of the New York Yankees pitched a no-hitter against the Chicago White Sox _ but lost 4-0. On July 12, the Sox' Melido Perez pitched the record-tying seventh no-hitter of the season, a rain-shortened six-inning victory at Yankee Stadium.

DOC.HEAD: Guardians Appointed for Children in Forced Bone Marrow Donor Case
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Wednesday appointed guardians for a leukemia-stricken boy and his two young half-siblings, whom the sick boy's father wants tested as potential bone-marrow donors. But the Illinois Supreme Court later stayed any action by the guardians until it reconsiders its original order that they be appointed. The high court gave no indication when it would reconsider that ruling, Supreme Court spokesman John Madigan said. The father and the attorney for 12-year-old Jean-Pierre Bosze said they hope the boy's 3-year-old twin half-brother and half-sister would be tested if the guardians overlook the objections of the twins' mother. ``Mom is making the wrong decision in this case,'' said the children's father, Tamas Bosze of suburban Hoffman Estates. ``The children would decide differently if they were grown up. ``If my brother asked me for a blood test, I would say `sure','' Bosze said after the hearing. Jean-Pierre's doctor says a bone-marrow transplant is the boy's only chance for survival, and the twins offer the best chance of a match. Bosze, who fathered the twins by a former girlfriend, went to court to force the testing after the woman refused to allow it. In an order July 18, Circuit Judge Monica Reynolds refused to order the tests, saying it would be an invasion of the twins' privacy. The Illinois Supreme Court last week sent the case back to Reynolds with further hearing with an order that guardians be appointed for the three children. Beverly Pekala, an attorney for the twins and their mother, Nancy Curran, appealed the high court's order. ``The trial record is replete with evidence that all children involved with this case have had their interests zealously protected,'' Pekala said. But Attorney Edward Jordan, who represents Jean-Pierre, said the more objective view provided by guardians can help the court as it tries to balance the benefits to the boy versus the risk, pain or inconvenience to the twins. Jordan said in his appeal to the high court that he wants time to gather more evidence. He said this might include further medical information and testimony by people who have been donors in other cases. ``And if any parents whose children were donors want to come forward, we'd be happy to talk to them,'' Jordan said. The boy's father said that Jean-Pierre's leukemia must be in remission before he can receive a transplant. Bosze said his son recently underwent five days of chemotherapy and that doctors are close to bringing the disease under control to allow the operation. He said that many non-relatives have volunteered as donors, but none has proven to be compatible. The guardians named by Reynolds are both Chicago attorneys _ Sheldon Engel for Jean-Pierre and Charles Fleck for the twins.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Cases of Stroke Reportedly Caused by Lyme Disease
DOC.TEXT: The American Heart Association is urging doctors across the country to consider testing for Lyme disease in patients with unexplained strokes. The suggestion comes after neurologists at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, D.C., reviewed 12 cases of stroke caused by the disease contracted in Europe. The serious and possibly permanent brain damage that may result from strokes ``make it imperative'' that infection with Lyme disease ``be suspected in any atypical stroke ...,'' neurologists Eugene May and Bahman Jabbari wrote in the August issue of Stroke, a heart association journal. Jabbari is director of the epilepsy and neurophysiology section at Walter Reed. ``I suspect strokes caused by Lyme disease have occurred in the United States, but none has been reported so far,'' said May, senior neurology resident at Walter Reed. ``Hopefully, ... neurologists in the United States will start looking more closely for Lyme disease infections in stroke patients.'' The doctors were alerted to the Lyme-stroke connection when a 20-year-old U.S. Army soldier was transferred to Walter Reed in January 1989, where it was determined he had suffered a stroke triggered by an infecting agent that causes Lyme disease. The spirochete, Borrelia burgdorferi, is transmitted to humans mainly by certain species of ticks, each about the size of a pinhead. May and Jabbari found 11 similar cases in scientific literature, and determined that all 12 had experienced meningitis and all had been infected in Europe. But they noted that only a few of the European strains of the Lyme spirochete are closely related to the strains that cause Lyme disease in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Probe Finds Some Truth in Allegations of Nimitz Cheating
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has confirmed that several sailors aboard the USS Nimitz cheated on tests of their technical knowledge of the aircraft carrier's nuclear reactor operations and procedures. But the Navy said it found no evidence that such cheating would harm the crew's ability to operate the ship. It denied public allegations by four sailors of unsafe procedures aboard the ship, including shortcuts in various systems tests and the possibility of sabotage. It found that ``the ship's reactors are safe and that crew members are qualified to operate them,'' the Navy said in a statement Tuesday. The problem of ``several sailors'' cheating on exams was being resolved by the Nimitz crew, the Navy said. Rep. Norm Dicks, D-Wash., met Tuesday with Nuclear Reactors Office head Adm. Bruce DeMars. Dicks said testing procedures involving the Navy's nuclear reactors were being reviewed because of the cheating. ``There were nine people out of 345 who were involved in cribbing for exams, and that's simply unacceptable,'' Dicks said. ``But it didn't relate back to any safety problem on the ship.'' Lt. Col. Bob Pritchard, a Navy spokesman in San Diego, said the exams require crew members in charge of reactor operations to answer a short list of questions. The questions deal with their technical knowledge of operations and procedures concerning the power plant. Four sailors who said they work with the ship's nuclear propulsion system had alleged on KIRO-TV on Aug. 3 that the crew was overworked, cheating on examinations was widespread, and shortcuts were being taken in the ship's system safety programs. They claimed many nuclear crew members did not have sufficient knowledge to handle a nuclear accident and that some had considered minor acts of sabotage against the reactor to ease their workload. The Navy said it found no evidence of sabotage or a conspiracy to commit sabotage.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Warned of Investment Scams Tied to Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: A state regulators' group is warning consumers about con artists who may try to exploit the crisis in the Persian Gulf by peddling bogus oil, gas and precious metals investments. The North American Securities Administrators Association has issued an investor bulletin to warn small investors about the latest scams tied to recent developments in the Mideast. The group is an association of state government regulators that periodically alerts the public to the latest twists in consumer-related securities fraud. ``People shouldn't expect to make money overnight,'' Susan E. Bryant, president of NASAA, said in a telephone interview Tuesday. ``If a legitimate oil company is going to profit from the Mideast oil crisis, it's going to take a while.'' She said the organization had no direct reports of Persian Gulf oil-related scams, but there are ``rumors that they're on the streets.'' ``We usually don't get the complete story until someone figured out they lost money, which could be several years down the road,'' she said. A con man's ``best friend is a headline or television news flash out of the Mideast that threatens a disruption of oil supplies to the United States,'' said Bryant, who is also administrator of the Oklahoma Securities Department. Con artists previously have seized on the scam potential of Mideast turmoil, including the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo, the 1979 Iranian revolution and the tanker war during the Iran-Iraq war in the 1980s, Bryant said. ``Investors should realize there are hundreds of high pressure telephone sales operations in the United States that will be burning up the phone lines with these kind of pitches for non-existent or blatantly abusive investments,'' she said. Investors should not to give money to strangers who contact them by phone, NASAA said. It also advised checking out whether an investment is registered with state authorities and if the promoter is licensed. The NASAA bulletin warned that crooks, through high pressure telephone sales from temporary ``boiler room'' operations, encourage investors to buy into oil partnerships for $5,000, $10,000 or more. To sweeten the deal they say the gulf conflict will drive up oil or commodity prices and the investor will be getting in early enough to ride the price rise. But, NASAA advised, the wells in question often don't exist, belong to someone else or are dry. Even a legitimate oil field can take as long as two years to reach full production, the bulletin stated. War and the rumor of war also can drive up the price of precious metals such as gold, silver and platinum _ historically used as investment hedges during times of uncertainty _ and attract scam artists hawking bullion and coins, NASAA said. Investors should be particularly careful about promotions for bank-financed or collateral loan programs involving gold or silver. The salesperson usually has made extravagant or misleading claims about the profit potential and very often high commissions, interest charges, storage fees and other expenses ``make it extremely unlikely that an investor will see a penny of profit,'' the bulletin said.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed in Riots Over Price Increases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to raise death toll. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A two-day, nationwide strike over sharply higher prices led to clashes between police and protesters that left at least 11 people dead and 50 wounded, authorities said today. The general strike virtually paralyzed the Caribbean nation of 7 million people on Monday and Tuesday. Nearly all stores, factories and offices were closed and public transportation was scarce. Normal activity resumed today, however. The anti-government strike, which was organized by nine major unions, led to violent confrontations between protesters and security forces in the capital, Santo Domingo, and several other cities. Police said the 11 people who died were all killed as a result of bullets fired by police and soldiers to disperse unruly crowds. It was earlier reported that an 10-year-old girl had died after being struck by a stone during looting, but police said today that she was accidentally hit by a bullet. At least 50 protesters were wounded and 2,000 arrested over the 48-hour strike period. The unions organized the protest in response to an austerity program introduced last week by the government of President Joaquin Balaguer to shore up the country's faltering economy. Juan Jose Arteaga, presidential economic adviser, said today the strike would have no effect on the government's economic policies. The program includes sharp increases in the costs of basic consumer goods. The price of gasoline, for example, rose 83.6 percent from 55 cents to $1.07 a gallon. The conservative Balaguer, 83 and blind, is to be inaugurated Thursday to a second consecutive four-year term. He narrowly defeated his longtime challenger, leftist Juan Bosch, in a disputed election May 16.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Restoration of Soviet Citizenship May Include Solzhenitsyn
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to ADD quotes from Foreign Ministry spokesman, more background on two writers. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today ordered the restoration of citizenship to a large number of exiles, and an official suggested that Nobel laureates Alexander Solzhenitsyn and Joseph Brodsky may be among them. The Soviet president ``canceled the decrees on citizenship concerning a number of persons who are now living abroad,'' the official Soviet news agency Tass reported, citing an official announcement. The decree came two days after Gorbachev issued a sweeping decree restoring the rights of all victims of Stalin's repressions, saying thousands of innocent people still bore ``a stain of injustice.'' The brief report on today's order said it dealt with ``injustices that occurred between 1966 and 1988,'' but did not say if it affected everyone whose citizenship was revoked during that period. Nor did it name anyone in particular. However, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said the order ``concerns a rather large number of people. Some names were mentioned _ Brodsky, Solzhenitsyn.'' ``I just heard that ostensibly Mr. Solzhenitsyn got back his Soviet citizenship, but I don't know for sure,'' Gremitskikh said. The government of former Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev revoked the citizenship of prominent authors and performing artists who spoke out against repression in their homeland. But Gorbachev's government has restored the citizenship of a number of them, notably cellist and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich and his wife, singer Galina Vishnevskaya. Gremitskikh was unable to say whether the presidential order also applies to Jews who emigrated to Israel and were deprived of their citizenship. Both Solzhenitsyn and Brodsky spent time in Soviet prison camps for their political views. Solzhenitsyn is the author of ``The Gulag Archipelago,'' which depicted the horrors of dictator Josef Stalin's prison camps. The author was charged with high treason in 1974, stripped of his citizenship and expelled from the country. He now lives in Vermont. Other well-known works by Solzhenitsyn, who won the Nobel Prize in literature in 1970, include ``One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich'' and ``Cancer Ward.'' The Soviet Union banned his books for decades but in the past year has published several of them, including ``The Gulag Archipelago.'' Solzhenitsyn came under particular criticism in his homeland because he has condemned not only Stalin but also Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin, calling him ``evil.'' Lenin is still generally revered in the Soviet Union. Solzhenitsyn has said he would not return to the Soviet Union unless all of his books were published and widely available. A number of his books have been printed, but almost none can readily be found in the shortage-plagued Soviet Union. Brodsky is a poet and essayist who now lives in New York. Only a few of his works were published in the Soviet Union until the literary monthly Novy Mir printed a selection after he won the 1987 Nobel Prize for Literature. He was sentenced to five years in an Arctic labor camp in 1964 after being convicted of ``parasitism,'' but released after 18 months. Parasitism was the crime of not holding a job. Many dissidents were fired, barred from working and then found guilty of parasitism. Brodsky left the Soviet Union in 1972 after being told by secret police to emigrate or ``face the consequences.'' He understood the threat to mean that he might face another prison term if he stayed. He left behind an eloquent appeal to Brezhnev that he be permitted to return home one day. ``Although I am losing my Soviet citizenship, I do not cease to be a Russian poet. I belong to Russian culture, I feel part of it,'' he said. ``I feel bitter as I leave Russia, I was born, raised and have lived here and I owe everything I have in the world to Russia. Everything bad I have suffered has been more than compensated by the good, and I have never felt that I have been hurt by my homeland.'' In an interview in Paris with the reporters from the Soviet newspaper Izvestia in 1988, Brodsky said he might be interested in returning to Leningrad for a private visit. Moscow News said today that a book of Brodsky's poetry is being published for the first time in the Soviet Union. The Northwest publishing house in Leningrad plans 100,000 copies of the book, ``The Autumn Cry of the Hawk.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Visit Chemical Weapons Disposal Facility at Johnston Atoll
LaserPhoto HU2
DOC.TEXT: A television monitor shows the destruction of one of the world's most loathed weapons _ a rocket armed with deadly nerve agent being cut by a machine and dumped into an incinerator. It was the 63rd M-55 rocket destroyed Tuesday at this remote outpost 800 miles southwest of Honolulu and the 1,104th incinerated since the Johnston Atoll Chemical Agent Disposal System or JACADS plant began tests June 30. ``I came here with a few doubts, but I leave here reinforced in my support for this facility,'' Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, said after seeing the process. He and several other visitors wore gas masks and nerve gas antidote syringes strapped to their sides. The $240 million facility was built to destroy 300,000 aging chemical weapons moved here from Okinawa in 1971. Pending government approval and the outcome of a lawsuit filed by the environmental group Greenpeace USA, the facility also will incinerate 100,000 rounds being shipped from West Germany. Some Pacific leaders and environmental groups fear the facility is unsafe and could turn Johnston Atoll into the nation's _ and perhaps the world's _ chemical munitions disposal site. To address those fears, Inouye traveled to the small, flat atoll on Tuesday with congressional delegates Ben Blaz, R-Guam, and Eni Faleomavaega, D-American Samoa, Pacific forces commander Adm. Huntington Hardisty and several reporters. An Army spokesman said it was the first time reporters had been given access to the atoll's chemical weapons facilities. Inouye, chairman of the Senate defense appropriations subcommittee, said he arranged the tour because a lack of information about activities at Johnston Atoll was causing unfounded concern. Inouye said he came away convinced the facility was safe, would not harm the environment and would not be used for weapons stored on the U.S. mainland. ``My reaction is very good,'' Blaz said. ``I am absolutely convinced this facility is as good as it can be to do the job for which it is intended.'' Col. David Moss, in charge of JACADS, told the visitors the facility is safe. ``We take all the precautions we possibly can. We do extensive monitoring. We've destroyed over 1,100 rockets already without incident,'' Moss said. Similar plants are planned for the mainland, where nearly all of the U.S. chemical weapons stockpile is kept. The Johnston Atoll and European weapons amount to 6.6 percent of the U.S. chemical munitions arsenal. The disposal facility, which resembles a factory or power plant, covers several acres on the coral atoll that is barely large enough to accommodate its airport. The facility is being tested in a 16-month trial run, burning obsolete rockets containing the nerve agent GB, which kills by paralyzing the respiratory system. Greenpeace sued to block the shipment of weapons from West Germany to Johnston Atoll. A federal judge in Honolulu will consider the group's request for a preliminary injunction to halt the shipment at an Aug. 20 hearing. Greenpeace claims the Army's environmental impact statements for the incinerator are not comprehensive and fail to address alternatives to incineration. Two ships that will carry the weapons to the Pacific are not scheduled to leave West Germany until next month.

DOC.HEAD: Top Party Chief Ousted After Magazine Reports Secret Police Links
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with party saying Kirchner relieved of duties pending investigation of accusations. Pickup 4th, `Stern...'
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's top political party relieved its general secretary of his duties today after a news magazine said he had worked for the former Communist secret police for 15 years. Martin Kirchner, chief of the Christian Democratic Union of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, was told to step aside pending an investigation of the accusations, said party deputy chairman Horst Korbella. Kirchner was pushed aside shortly after the West German magazine Stern reported in its latest edition that he worked for the notorious secret police as a paid informant for 15 years. Stern, which cited as sources three former secret police members, said Kirchner was working for the intelligence network when he met last year with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and other West German officials. Kirchner was on vacation and could not be reached for comment. He has denied previous reports in the press that he had ties to the secret police, known as the Stasi. The Stern report is the latest of several accusations that prominent people in East Germany's new democratic system were informers for the once-feared domestic intelligence network. In recent months, there also have been widespread reports that the Stasi harbored notorious leftist terrorists and may have plotted and carried out the assassinations of dissidents and refugees. Considered one of the most skilled intelligence services in the world, the omnipresent Stasi created an atmosphere of fear and intimidation that helped keep in power the government of former hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker. Honecker was ousted in the fall by a popular pro-democracy uprising. The Stern report said Kirchner reported to the Stasi details of a meeting with Kohl and other West German officials during the waning days of the former government. Kohl's West German Christian Democrats helped turn the East German Christian Democratic Union from a Communist-linked puppet party into a sister party that will soon merge with its West German counterpart. The Stern report said Kirchner supplied information from the meeting with Kohl to the Stasi so it could prepare for the days following Honecker's fall. The Christian Democrats won the most votes in East Germany's first free elections on March 18 by promising to seek quick unity with West Germany. De Maiziere has denied accusations that he also supplied information to the secret police. Stern said Kirchner was paid monthly by the Stasi and worked as an informant for the agency until a few days before the opening of the Berlin Wall on Nov. 9. Stern said two of the three former Stasi members it quoted were Kirchner's bosses during his relationship with the secret police between 1978 and 1989. The Stasi had more than 80,000 members but was believed to have had even more people working with it on a regular basis. This group included educators, scientists and numerous other people. East Germans are torn between seeking retribution and prosecuting former Stasi agents and informants or granting a general amnesty.

DOC.HEAD: Ted Koppel Scores Coup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 2nd and SUBS final 2 grafs to UPDATE with CBS anchor Dan Rather also now in Baghdad, other network efforts.
DOC.TEXT: ABC anchor Ted Koppel, planning a second day of reports from Iraq today, says Jordan's King Hussein may have helped get him there in hope of airing the Iraqi point of view. The ``Nightline'' anchor scored a journalistic coup Tuesday when he became the first American reporter let into Iraq since that country's takeover of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Today, CBS anchorman Dan Rather and a CBS team that included correspondent Allen Pizzey also were allowed in, a CBS spokeswoman said. NBC and Cable News Network still were trying to arrange similar trips. Koppel, in a phone report from the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad to his ``Nightline'' program Tuesday night, said he'd spent 2{ hours with King Hussein several days ago. He said the king, an ally of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, ``is extremely eager to have the Iraqi point of view communicated through the American media....'' The king, he added, ``was very helpful, I think, in making our trip possible.'' He speculated that Iraqi officials let him in because they feel things are going so poorly for them that ``they have nothing to lose by letting us come over here and report from here. ``Because the reporting has been all so anti-Iraq that I guess they feel it can't get much worse. And who knows? Some of their point of view might get across.'' Koppel, whose Emmy-winning series is known for offering interviews with heads of state who engage in what some call television diplomacy, flew to Iraq from Jordan late Tuesday. The ABC crew with him included morning news anchor Forrest Sawyer, who reported from Bagdhad today on ``Good Morning America.'' But Koppel was unable then to interview the country's leader, and his ABC crew him was unable to arrange a satellite video hookup from the state-run television facilities in Baghdad. So, as Sawyer did today, Koppel phoned in his reports to ABC's ``World News Tonight'' and then ``Nightline,'' the latter anchored in New York by Chris Wallace. Koppel also included on his late-night broadcast an interview with Bob Vinton, whom he identified as a U.S. businessman who has lived in Iraq since last fall. Vinton works for Johnson Controls Inc., a Milwaukee-based company that makes automotive batteries and building instrumentation. Vinton said Iraqis continued to treat Americans in Baghdad courteously and that ``we have complete freedom of movement.'' But he said there had been ``no indications'' that Americans in Iraq ``can go home at any time'' during the current crisis, and he expressed surprise Koppel was allowed in the country. Koppel said on the air that Iraqi leaders had been trying to get news of U.S. moves and glean U.S. intentions from the global broadcasts of Cable News Network received in Baghdad. NBC, seeking entry into Iraq for ``Sunday Today'' co-anchor Garrick Utley and correspondent Rick Davis, has had difficulty getting visas due to communications problems between Iraqi officials in Jordon and Baghdad, said NBC News foreign editor David Miller. ``But we're hopeful,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Choice Protesters Attack Meeting with Catholic Officials and PR Firm
DOC.TEXT: Pro-choice activists burned mock baptismal certificates and declared themselves ``voluntarily excommunicated'' to protest an anti-abortion campaign developed for the Roman Catholic Church. ``I'd certainly like to be excommunicated if that's what they are doing to people who support abortions,'' said Alison Gude, 28, who was baptized in the Catholic church. Gude was one of 20 protesters who gathered Tuesday outside the Cathedral Hill Hotel where 200 Catholic officials and laymen got their first glimpse of the campaign put together by the public relations firm Hill and Knowlton. ``We're here to let them know the majority of people in this country are pro-choice and no slick advertising campaign is going to deter women from seeking abortions,'' said Marianne Jensen, a spokeswoman for the Bay Area Coalition Against Operation Rescue, which organized the protests. Some church officials have termed the campaign as informational rather than advertising. The protesters chanted slogans such as ``Keep Your Rosaries Out Of Our Ovaries'' as they gathered around a skeleton draped in red robes which they said represented Cardinal John O'Connor. O'Connor, the archbishop of New York and chairman of the Bishop's Committee for Pro-Life Activities, addressed the diocesan pro-life coordinators Monday during the first day of the two-day conference. Protesters said the church intended to spend $5 million on the Hill and Knowlton campaign. Church officials have not released the project's cost, but said $3 million in private donations has been earmarked for the project. ``We think their money would be better spent on Social Services programs,'' Jensen said. ``The point is to get professional assistance on how to better communicate our message so it will be heard,'' said the Rev. John Goudrick, executive director for the Secretariat for Pro-Life Activities. ``I don't think it's being heard because I rarely see reference to the unborn.'' Goudrick said the abortion debate instead centers on the conflict between women and government. ``We're focusing on the fact that right now respect for human life in this country is eroding,'' Goudrick said. Goudrick said the campaign would not target just a Catholic audience. ``Human life is a human issue. It's not just a Catholic issue,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of the Iran-Iraq War
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of the eight-year war between Iran and Iraq, which remains formally unresolved pending a final peace treaty.

April 1 _ Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who returned to Tehran in February after the Shah was toppled, proclaims the Islamic Republic of Iran. July 16 _ Saddam Hussein, vice chairman of Iraq's ruling Revolutionary Command Council, replaces Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr as president. Nov.4 _ U.S. Embassy in Tehran is stormed by militants. Fifty-two Americans are held hostage for 444 days.
DOC.HEAD: and economic
DOC.TEXT: installations on the Iraqi side of Shatt-Al-Arab. Sept. 20-23 _ Iraqi warplanes strike Tehran Airport; army begins advance and later reaches Karun River several hundred miles into Iran. Sept. 28 _ U.N. Security Council adopts Resolution 479 calling for a cease-fire. Iran rejects the call.
Jan. 20 _ American hostages freed by Iran. May-Oct. _ Iran counterattacks, eventually pushing Iraqis back across the Karun River.
March 29 _ Saddam proposes withdrawal to international borders. Iran ignores the offer and continues to advance.
Fighting continues with Iran advancing.

Feb. 29 _ First reports that Iraq has used chemical weapons. United Nations later confirms the reports. March 27 _ Iraq shifts the war from land to sea in an attempt to force Iran to negotiating table. It attacks tankers bound for Iranian ports. June 11 _ Iran and Iraq agree to a U.N.-sponsored moratorium on the shelling of civilian targets but continue to hit targets in the gulf.
March _ Iran and Iraq fire missiles into each other's population centers, beginning the ``war of cities.''
Aug. 12 _ For the first time, Iraq bombs Iran's oil-loading facilities on Sirri island, 400 miles from Iraq. Iran fires a missile into Baghdad.

Jan. 6 _ Saddam calls for cease-fire. Iran rejects it again. Jan. 9-14 _ Iran seizes western bank of Shatt-Al-Arab; overruns key Iraqi defenses east of Basra; launches new offensive in Mehran area. May 17 _ Iraqi missile hits USS Stark in Gulf, 37 sailors killed. Iraq says it was an accident. May 19 _ U.S. agrees to reflag 11 Kuwaiti tankers as protective measure. July 20 _ U.N. Security Council unanimously votes for Resolution 598 calling for a cease-fire. July 22: First tankers flying U.S. flag escorted into gulf by U.S. naval forces in region, beefed up by 15 ships for escorting operations. Oct. 8 _ U.S. helicopters sink three Iranian speedboats in the gulf. Oct. 16 _ Iranian missile hits U.S.-flagged Sea Isle City near Kuwait; 18 injured. Oct. 19 _ U.S. attacks two Iranian platforms.

July 3 _ USS Vincennes downs Iran Air jetliner, killing 290. July 18 _ Iran accepts year-old Security Council Resolution 598. Iraq had accepted it previously. Aug. 20 _ Cease-fire takes hold, U.N. troops deploy along border. Aug. 25 _ Indirect Iran-Iraq negotiations begin in Geneva.

Aug. 2: Iraqi troops overrun Kuwait. Aug. 12 _ Saddam links withdrawal from Kuwait to, among other things, resolution of Iran-Iraq disputes stemming from war. Aug. 15 _ Saddam, facing U.S. and Arab troops that were dispatched to Saudi Arabia to protect it, promises to withdraw from Iranian territory and release soldiers captured during the Iran-Iraq war.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Closely Following Gulf Crisis, Survey Shows
DOC.TEXT: Two out of three Americans say they are following the action in the Persian Gulf very closely and 85 percent of those polled say it is the most important news of the month, a media organization reported today. The Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press said the level of interest was significantly higher than for news of previous actions involving U.S. armed forces. For example, 60 percent said they paid very close attention to the December invasion of Panama and 58 percent to the U.S. air strikes against Libya in 1986, compared with the 66 percent for the Gulf developments. Times Mirror said it was unprecedented to have 85 percent responding that the Gulf action was the most important story. The previous high was 56 percent for the invasion of Panama. The center is an arm of Times Mirror, which publishes a number of newspapers and has other news media interests. The center makes monthly surveys of public interest in the news. It said the public was reasonably well informed about the Gulf crisis, with 66 percent knowing that the Soviet Union is supporting U.S. efforts to get Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Almost as many, 64 percent, knew that other countries were sending forces to Saudi Arabia to defend against an Iraqi invasion. The organization surveyed 1,213 adults by telephone from Aug. 9-12. The error attributable to sampling and other random effects is plus or minus 3 percentage points, the center said. The center also said that 30 percent of the public, an unusually large proportion, said they had followed news about the condition of the economy closely during the previous four weeks. In May, only 18 percent said they were paying close attention to news about increasing interest rates and higher inflation. Still, however, just as was the case in June, only 18 percent claimed to be closely following stories about the efforts of the administration and Congress to cut the budget deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Aircraft Carrier, Seven Other Ships Leave East Coast Ports
DOC.TEXT: The aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and seven other ships left East Coast ports this morning on their way to join the growing U.S. military presence in the Middle East. Leaving from Norfolk were the Kennedy; the guided missile cruisers USS Mississippi, USS San Jacinto, and USS Thomas S. Gates; and the combat stores ship USS Sylvania. The destroyer USS Moosbrugger from Charleston, S.C., the guided missile frigate USS Roberts from Newport, R.I., and the fast combat support ship USS Seattle from Earle, N.J., will join the carrier group at sea, said Lt. Cmdr. Carrie Hartshorne, an Atlantic Fleet spokeswoman. ``The Kennedy battle group will be available for potential relief of the Eisenhower battle group or additional tasking to be determined by rapidly changing events,'' said Ms. Hartshorne. The Eisenhower battle group has been in the Mediterranean for several months. About 150 family members and friends gathered at the Norfolk Naval Station as the Kennedy departed with its crew lining the rails. ``I really don't want him to go,'' said 15-year-old Trevor, whose father is a petty officer aboard the aircraft carrier. The Navy requested that the last names of family members not be used. ``He told me what was happening and explained why he had to go,'' the boy said. Tuesday, the Navy hospital ship USS Comfort and two amphibious vessels set out from Norfolk. The 1,000-bed Comfort left on a direct route to the Middle East, but the amphibious vessels, the USS Portland and the USS Trenton, headed for Morehead City, N.C., to pick up troops en route to their deployment. The carrier battle group will carry about 9,000 sailors and Marines, the spokeswoman said. Activated Monday for duty in the Middle East was the Cape Mohican, a freighter from the James River Reserve Fleet. It is the sixth ship called to duty from the approximately 100 at anchor in the James River off Fort Eustis, said Anthony A. Schiavone, the James River Fleet superintendent. He said the ship should be ready to go by the end of the week. The ship can carry 36 barges that are 95 feet long and 35 feet wide, said William S. Chambers, Maritime Administration director for the South Atlantic region. The Maritime Administration operates the fleet. The Cape Mohican also can carry Army landing craft and small cargo boats, Schiavone said. The Roberts weathered a previous Middle East crisis. On April 14, 1988, it hit an Iranian mine while escorting a Kuwaiti-flagged oil tanker during the Iran-Iraq war. The blast tore a 22- to 25-foot hole in its bottom, flooded its engine room and set off a fire that took five hours to control. Ten crewmen were injured, and have since recovered.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Escort Embassy Staff from Battle Front
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 18th pvs, `More than...' to ADD location of Congo Town relative to Monrovia. Pickup 19th, `About 2,000...'
DOC.TEXT: Rebel fighters escorted staff and refugees living in the West German, Moroccan and Egyptian embassies from the battle front of Monrovia today but refused to let Guineans evacuate their mission. The rebels of Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front have accused Guinea of supporting Liberian President Samuel Doe with troops. Taylor's rebels escorted 11 Germans, two Moroccan diplomats, the Egyptian ambassador, 4 Lebanese and 24 Liberians in an 18-vehicle convoy headed for neighboring Ivory Coast, West German Ambassador Juergen Gehl told reporters as he departed. It would take at least 12 hours to reach the northeastern border, traveling through rebel-held territory. About 60 Guineans, including the ambassador, were not allowed to join the convoy, Gehl said. Rebels attacked the embassies of Guinea and Nigeria last week, forcing more than 8,000 people sheltered there into the streets, where the rebels were battling Doe's troops with rockets, anti-aircraft guns and assault rifles. People at Guinea's mission made their way back to the building rather than risk passing through numerous rebel check points blocking the route to the border. Many of those chased from the embassy were Mandingos, a tribe rebels accuse of supporting Doe's government. People suspected of aiding Doe risk summary execution. Taylor's forces have captured at least four Guinean soldiers accused of fighting with Doe's troops. But one of the prisoners told reporters he was guarding the embassy when he was taken. An estimated 1,400 people are still sheltered at the Nigerian Embassy, next to the West German compound. In the past, Taylor has said he would allow the Nigerian and Guinean embassies to evacuate their personnel. But that was before both countries announced they were sending troops to a six-nation West African task force mobilizing in neighboring Sierra Leone. The force has orders to sail to Monrovia and force a halt to the nearly 8-month-old civil war. The West African nations sending troops are Ghana, Gambia, Guinea, Nigeria, Sierra Leone and Togo. Rebels invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. In February, rebel commander Prince Johnson split with Taylor and formed a rival faction that is fighting Doe's soldiers in central Monrovia and fending off attacks from Taylor's forces. On Tuesday, Taylor said his rebels had killed Johnson in an ambush, but reporters later interviewed Taylor's rival, who laughed at the claim. Doe and Johnson have welcomed the West African intervention. The intra-rebel fighting has prolonged the rebellion in which 5,000 people have been killed, mostly civilians. More than 100 people, including 52 West Germans, 28 Spaniards, five Swiss, four Filipinos and two American citizens were evacuated Sunday by U.S. Marines in helicopters from the Atlantic Ocean port of Buchanan, 90 miles east of Monrovia. They had traveled by convoy from Congo Town, about a mile outside Monrovia, through rebel-held territory. About 2,000 U.S. Marines in ships off the Liberian coast are on standby to protect U.S. citizens and installations or are in Monrovia guarding the U.S. Embassy.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Blocks Release of Counselor's Tapes
DOC.TEXT: Taped conversations between a psychotherapist and two brothers accused in the shotgun slayings of their wealthy parents can't be released, a state appeals court said in a temporary ruling. The court blocked release of tapes confiscated in connection with the arrests of Erik and Lyle Menendez. The brothers are accused in the Aug. 20, 1989, murders of their father, Jose Menendez, and his wife, Kitty, inside their Beverly Hills mansion. Prosecutors allege the sons were motivated by the prospect of a $14 million inheritance. The 2nd District Court of Appeal issued the emergency stay Tuesday and set Aug. 24 for the prosecutors' rebuttal, said clerk John Lepo. The recordings are of counseling sessions between the brothers and their psychotherapist, L. Jerome Oziel. Prosecutors, who already have listened to the tapes, consider them key evidence. Defense attorneys claim the tapes fall under doctor-patient privilege and thus cannot be introduced as evidence. ``We're delighted by the ruling,'' said defense attorney Gerald Chaleff. Santa Monica Superior Court Judge James Albracht ruled Aug. 6 that the privilege protection did not apply because Oziel was threatened. Communication between a therapist and patient is considered confidential unless it involves threats or has been disclosed to a third party. Albracht said Oziel believed the brothers made threats during the sessions and it was necessary to disclose the conversations to protect himself and others. In another development, Erik, 19, has refused to give authorities a handwriting sample. Beverly Hills Municipal Judge Charles Rubin warned him Monday that his refusal can be used as evidence. Prosecutors want to compare the brothers' handwriting to that found on records used to buy two shotguns in San Diego. A preliminary hearing in the case is scheduled for Oct. 22.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Conservationists Claim They Rammed Japanese Driftnet Boats
DOC.TEXT: A conservationist vessel deliberately rammed two Japanese fishing boats in the North Pacific, disabling equipment used to recover driftnets, a crew member reported. The action was part of a campaign to document and halt the incidental deaths of millions of seabirds, marine mammals and sea turtles from driftnetting, said Chris Keyser in a marine satellite telephone call Tuesday to The Associated Press. The Sea Shepherd II, operated by the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, came upon the six-boat Japanese squid fleet Monday about 1,500 miles north of Honolulu, said Keyser, a free-lance writer aboard the British-registered, 196-foot North Sea trawler. ``It was necessary to disable their fishing gear in order to put them out of operation,'' said Paul Watson, the skipper of the Sea Shepherd II and founder of the radical conservation group. ``It was also necessary to create an international incident to focus international attention on the issue,'' he said. The Japanese driftnetters are in violation of the North Pacific treaty on the protection of migratory seabirds, which was signed by the Japanese government, Watson said. But he contended that U.S. and Japanese authorities for the past decade have done nothing to enforce the treaty, which protects 22 species of sea birds, 13 of which are threatened or endangered. ``We're fed up with people just talking about it. It's about time someone did something to get these pirates out of here,'' said Watson, who charged that the North Pacific area has become ``a biological wasteland'' because of the driftnetters. ``Any consequences are worth the action we took. The Sea Shepherd Society has always taken responsibility for its actions and (we) have never committed a criminal act nor caused any injuries,'' he said. There were no injuries, although two of the Japanese fishermen threw knives at the Sea Shepherd II after the ramming, Keyser said. The Coast Guard had not received any reports of the ramming, but will be looking into the matter to see if any U.S. citizens were involved, said Lt. Michael Mohn at the Joint Rescue Coordination Center. Keyser identified the Japanese vessels as the Shunyo Maru and Ryoun Maru. After sideswiping the two boats, the Sea Shepherd II went after two more boats, but they were faster and were able to escape, Keyser said. There has been a growing movement throughout the Pacific to ban the nearly invisible driftnets, known by critics as ``walls of death,'' which can stretch for 30 miles trapping a wide variety of marine life and birds as well as large schools of squid for which they were developed. Watson was one of the original founders of the conservation group Greenpeace before breaking ties to found the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, now said to have 15,000 members worldwide. The 23 crew members of the Sea Shepherd II include citizens of the United States, Great Britain, Canada, Spain and the Philippines, Watson said.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 99 Killed As Factional Fighting Engulfs Black Townships
LaserPhoto JOH3
DOC.TEXT: The death toll in four days of black factional fighting soared to at least 99 today after armed bands attacked shantytowns east of Johannesburg, hacking people to death with axes and spears. The Star newspaper put the death toll at 105, but police officials said they could confirm only 99 killings since fighting began Sunday. At least 90 of the deaths came Tuesday night and today, police said. ``We just keep on finding bodies,'' a spokesman said. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Police said they expected the death toll to climb. Long columns of police armored vehicles and trucks filled with police armed with assault rifles and shotguns roamed through the townships today in a huge show of force. Many areas in Tokoza and Katlehong townships were quiet, but police and residents feared violence would begin again tonight. Police were seen today loading more than 40 bodies onto trucks in various places. The fighting pits Xhosa people of the African National Congress against the conservative Zulu Inkatha movement. The ANC and Inkatha oppose apartheid, but they are divided by leadership disputes, tribal divisions and their visions of a future South Africa. The fighting is the biggest single outbreak of township violence in recent years, the independent South African Press Association reported. Armed bands of Zulus attacked several shantytowns Tuesday night and again today. They set fire to houses and attacked fleeing residents with spears, pangas _ a machette-like weapon _ knives and other weapons. An armed Xhosa-speaking man with blood covering his shirt told a local journalist his group had just killed ``eight Inkatha'' and had suffered two losses. State-run South African Broadcasting Corp. radio said about 90 people had been treated for injuries at the Natalspruit Hospital. A police spokesman, Capt. Eugue Opperman, said a policeman sustained shrapnel wounds today after a hand grenade was hurled at police by an unidentified man. He said police had been fired at on several occasions. Police used tear gas today to drive back several hundred armed Inkatha supporters as they moved toward a shantytown at Katlehong that had been attacked during the night, witnesses said. Police also fired several gun shots. Police seized hundreds of knives, spears and other weapons and reported finding a chest containing Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles and grenades. A large police truck piled high with confiscated weapons was seen leaving Katlehong. More than 5,000 blacks have died since 1986 in fighting between Inkatha and ANC supporters in Natal, but only in recent weeks has the factional fighting begun to spill over into the Johannesburg area.

DOC.HEAD: Ban in Judicial, Local Elections Struck
DOC.TEXT: California's ban on political party endorsements in elections of judges and local government officials is unconstitutional because if violates freedom of speech, a federal appeals court has ruled. The 8-3 ruling of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals is the second blow in two years to state laws restricting party endorsements. Last year the U.S. Supreme Court struck down a California law that prohibited parties from endorsing candidates in their own partisan primaries. ``This decision constitutes a charter of freedom for political parties,'' state Democratic Chairman Edmund Brown Jr., the former governor, said in a statement after Tuesday's ruling. ``Lobbyists and special interest groups have enjoyed a free hand, while official political parties have been left out of local government.'' Deputy City Attorney Burk Delventhal of San Francisco, whose office defended the state law, said the ruling could be damaging to local government and judicial independence if it led to widespread party endorsements in nonpartisan elections. ``It would deprive local governments of the opportunity to have people with independent points of view who do not necessarily have to toe the party line to gain access to the public,'' Delventhal said. He said no decision has been made on an appeal to the Supreme Court. The ban on endorsements in nonpartisan local government, school board and judicial elections was added to the state Constitution by the voters in 1986 after the state Supreme Court had ruled that the endorsements were not prohibited by law. Sponsors of the 1986 measure claimed roots in the reforms of the 1910s that sought to break the grip of big-money interests by weakening political parties. One of the reforms was to make all local government offices nonpartisan. The measure was immediately challenged by a diverse group of San Francisco political activists, backed later by the state Democratic Party. U.S. District Judge Alfonso Zirpoli ruled in their favor; a three-judge appellate panel overturned his decision, saying the law was needed to protect nonpartisan elections, but the larger panel on Tuesday reinstated Zirpoli's ruling. Chief Judge Alfred Goodwin, in the majority opinion, said parties and their members have rights of free speech and association that cannot be completely suppressed without a compelling reason. He said nonpartisan elections had been adequately protected by keeping the parties out of the nomination process and restricting the candidates' partisan activities. In a separate concurring opinion, Judge Stephen Reinhardt, joined by Judge Alex Kozinski, said the integrity of the political process is threatened not by parties, but by ``the corrupting influence of money in politics.'' Keeping parties weak does not prevent corruption and may even encourage it, Reinhardt wrote; office-holders and candidates ``must go directly to the big monied interests and beg for the funds necessary to finance their campaigns.'' He also said that as long as California elects its judges, it must leave the voters ``free, rightly or wrongly, to consider the political philosophy of the candidates.'' Banning party endorsements merely leaves the field free to special interests, Reinhardt said. Dissenting Judge Arthur Alarcon said a party endorsement in a judicial race might be tempting to ``a frightened incumbent who has been subjected to media criticism for an unpopular decision,'' Alarcon said. Judge Pamela Rymer, in a separate dissent joined by Alarcon and Judge Ferdinand Fernandez, said allowing party endorsements ``would effectively destroy the nonpartisan system.''

DOC.HEAD: No Longer A Joke: Hundreds Expected to Return to Love Canal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with tours and news conference, picking up 5th graf pvs, `More than...'
DOC.TEXT: A state agency today put nine homes up for sale near the Love Canal chemical dump and said the neighborhood bought up by the government in the 1970s is safe, but with no guarantees. The homes have been rigorously tested and are as safe as any in Niagara Falls, said William L. Broderick, executive director of the Love Canal Area Revitalization Agency. But he said it was impossible to guarantee that the toxic chemical leaks that once drove 2,500 people from the neighborhood would not recur. ``There's no written guarantees going to be given,'' Broderick said at a news conference at his agency's offices about 500 feet from the site of the toxic dump. ``All we have is the written assurance of the state Health Department and the state environmental department as to the maintenance of the canal. ``If there is a problem in the future, I'm sure the state will come back and do as they did last time.'' The agency originally planned to offer 10 homes today, but Broderick said a resident of the neighborhood already had offered to buy one. Eight years ago, the idea that anyone would want to move back to Love Canal was so preposterous that it became a joke in the movie ``Tootsie.'' James E. Carr, the agency's planning director, said tours of the homes will be given for the next 20 days to interested buyers. The agency plans to start accepting offers Sept. 5. Broderick said a flurry of last-minute court action on Tuesday would not prevent the agency from going ahead with plans to sell some Love Canal homes. More than 200 people, including several former residents, have expressed interest in the small, single-family homes. Asking prices of $40,000 to $60,000 _ about 20 percent less than comparable homes elsewhere _ have stimulated interest. Many prospective buyers say they believe the danger from the 22,000 tons of chemicals still buried there has been overstated. ``The canal went right through my back yard. As kids, we used to go back in those fields, mow them down, play baseball,'' said Gail McClinsey. ``I'm fine, and I have two children. They're fine. I keep in touch with some of the friends I grew up with. They're fine.'' But doubts remain about allowing people to move into homes just a few blocks from the canal bed where Hooker Chemical Co. dumped dioxin, PCBs and other toxic chemicals in the 1940s and 1950s. Leaks discovered in the late 1970s led 2,500 residents to abandon their homes, making Love Canal a national symbol of the threat posed by toxic waste. In ``Tootsie,'' Dustin Hoffman's character considers taking a part in a play called ``Return to Love Canal.'' Carr said the area containing the 10 homes is safe even though most of the chemicals dumped in the canal have not been removed. ``They do testing all the time. There's continual monitoring going on,'' he said. ``Sure, I'd live there.'' Richard J. Lippes, a lawyer for environmental and community groups seeking to block resettlement, disagreed. ``I would never buy a home in Love Canal. I would never put my family in such jeopardy,'' he said. ``And if I wouldn't do it, there is no way I could recommend to anyone else to do it.'' The groups asked state Supreme Court Justice Joseph Mintz to enforce his 1985 injunction barring resettlement pending environmental and livability studies. But the agency urged him to lift the order, saying the studies have been done. The attorney general's office, which originally sought the injunction, said it would not object. ``We feel that the terms of the injunction have been met,'' said Leslie Gersing, spokeswoman for Attorney General Robert Abrams. No rulings are expected until Mintz returns from vacation next month. A study completed in 1988 found that the resettlement area north and northwest of Love Canal, which contains about 250 single-family homes, was no more contaminated than comparable parts of Niagara Falls. An area east of the canal containing about 270 homes was deemed uninhabitable because of contamination. Resettlement opponents claim the livability study, and an environmental review completed this year, are flawed. Among other things, they say that other areas of Niagara Falls may be polluted from several chemical plants and other toxic dumps. ``They haven't determined that those control areas are safe, and if those control areas aren't safe, neither is Love Canal,'' Lippes said.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Kuwaiti Official Says Iraq Invasion Came Despite Concessions
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's takeover of Kuwait came despite the emirate's concessions on two key Iraqi demands, the foreign minister of Kuwait's ousted government said in an interview published today. In talks that broke down less than 24 hours before the Aug. 2 invasion, Kuwait had agreed to write off Iraq's war debts and let Baghdad use a Kuwaiti island for its oil operations, said the minister, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Jaber. In remarks published in this week's edition of the state-owned Al-Mussawar magazine, Sheik Sabah said Iraq had demanded the writeoff of an estimated $14 billion to $15 billion in loans Kuwait provided Baghdad during its eight-year war with Iran. ``Iraq asked us to drop the debts, and we did not object,'' Sabah said. He said the questions surrounding Iraq's need of an outlet for its oil exports had not been completely resolved, but that Kuwait had done what it could to meet Baghdad's demands. He said Iraq had asked for ownership of two strategic Persian Gulf islands _Bubiyan and Warba _ and that Kuwait had areed to lease Iraq one of them instead. ``Iraq asked for Bubiyan Island,'' he told the magazine. ``We agreed to give them Warba island instead because Bubiyan is about a quarter the area of Kuwait and because Warba is enough for Iraq's purposes.'' He said Iraq would have been able to use Warba as an outlet to the gulf for oil from its wells in Rumaila, a rich field in on the disputed Iraq-Kuwait frontier. The former minister said the demand for ownership was refused because the Kuwaiti Parliament had issued a decree banning the ceding of any land. Iraq stormed out of the meeting in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, and the invasion followed. Afterward, Baghdad contended it invaded at the request of a new government that had overthrown the old ruling family. Most diplomats discounted that claim. Iraq later announced formation of a new Kuwaiti government, then declared it had annexed Kuwait. The ousted foreign minister said the island question had been an irritant between Iraq and Kuwait throughout the Iran-Iraq war. Baghdad repeatedly asked for the use of the two islands; Kuwait consistently refused. In the fortnight before the invasion, Iraq accused Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion in oil from the wells near the frontier. It also charged Kuwait was trying to ruin Baghdad's economy by producing more than its OPEC quota of oil, pushing down world market prices. At the time of the Jiddah talks, diplomatic sources said the war-debt problem could be resolved but that Kuwait's refusal to cede sovereignty over the two islands was a main sticking point.
Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad.

Aug. 9 East Oregonian, Pendleton, Ore., on rising oil and gasoline prices: It's fascinating to observe that whenever the price of oil and gasoline skyrockets, some oil company hotshot tells the rest of us we don't know how markets operate. Maybe fascinating isn't the word. How about disgusting? Recent statements by Charles J. DiBona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, typify the arrogance and obfuscation of those who think they know better as they gouge us during times of crisis. DiBona told the Senate Commerce consumer subcommitee ... that critics of the recent price increases were taking ``a naive, one-sided view of how markets work.'' Oil industry representatives issued similar statements after the Exxon Valdez oil spill. Mr. DiBona, we may be naive in the sense that we expect the oil industry to show a little more restraint (a little more patriotism?) when our nation faces a tough situation. But we know how markets work. The big oil companies use any excuse possible to jack up prices and the American consumers must fork over the dough if they want to get to work every day and keep American industry functioning. Considering the crisis in the Mideast, it's to be expected that oil prices would rise. ... But there is a difference between a legitimate price increase and a gouge. ... Taxpayers are spending millions to finance a strong, effective response to this crisis. At the same time, we are hostage to the profiteers at home. More critical is the possibility that the oil companies' policy of greed before country is driving America into a recession. Economic growth has been slow the past few months _ almost stagnant _ while unemployment and interest rates are rising. Steep energy prices could plunge us into an economic downturn. ... (S)upply isn't the problem. This week an Energy Department official said U.S. commercial supplies of 392 million barrels are at the highest level in nine years.

Aug. 10 The Journal, Lorain, Ohio, on rising oil and gasoline prices: Political cases are funny in that the final verdict may not always equal the sum of all the evidence. Such, we suspect, will be the case in the investigation into the rapid rise in gas prices allegedly resulting from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. At a House Subcommittee Energy and Power hearing looking into the rapid rise in gas prices, chairman Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., suggested the cut-off of oil from the Persian Gulf warranted dipping into the U.S. strategic petroleum reserve. That would reduce consumer prices for gasoline. But John Easton of the Energy Department claims those reserves could only be used to make up for supply shortages, not to bring down the price of gas. But wait a minute. If there isn't a shortage of oil then why is the price of gas rising so rapidly at the pump? Spokesmen for the big oil companies, who claim no price gouging is taking place, say it's because the price of crude oil rose about $7 a barrel (last) week on the world market. ... These contradictions in supply and demand deserve investigation. But the body doing the investigating is Congress, which has been stuffing its pockets annually with PAC money from the big oil companies. We'll just bet this probe turns out to be a case where Congress couldn't hit water if it fell out of a boat.

August 9 The Burlington County Times, Willingboro, N.J., on the Persian Gulf crisis: With the array of opposing forces deployed around him, why does Saddam Hussein persist in his annexation of Kuwait and his threats to Saudi Arabia? Is his pride so important that he would commit national suicide rather than back off? The situation would be laughable but for the modern-day arms supplied him by the Soviets and our friends the French. And how can we laugh when a nation the size of Iraq raises a million-man army and uses poison gas on its own people? Perhaps the ghost of Hitler and the Munich Pact serve us now, for President Bush said, ``We must resist aggression, ... appeasement will not work. ... Iraq cannot be allowed to benefit from its invasion of Kuwait.'' If all the pressure fails to dissuade Saddam, we will at least be nipping in the bud a force that is a clear and definite threat to world peace and the world economy. What we are doing is the best we can do in a dangerous situation we cannot control, only oppose.

Aug. 13 Los Angeles Times on Japan and the Persian Gulf crisis: (Japan) is wholly dependent on foreign oil for all that it does, and so much of that oil comes from the (Persian) Gulf. .. Japan is prevented by its constitution _ imposed on it in the settlement of World War II _ from developing or deploying anything other than a force for self-defense. ... For the Japanese, the best course of action is often the one that permits it to go quietly about its business. ... But unable to send troops and in the position of not wishing to alienate its Arab oil vendors, Japan needs to figure out its best profile in this crisis. Tokyo was right in agreeing to join the embargo early, even before the key (United Nations) Security Council sanctions vote ..., and now it would be well-advised to assume the role of one of the anti-Hussein coalition's key underwriters. Japan would be a key beneficiary of a more stable gulf region and would be an even bigger loser than the United States or Britain if the place goes to pieces. It could offer to help bankroll, for instance, the cost of any U.N. Security Council peacekeeping effort if one is established.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Lew DeWitt, Statler Brothers Tenor, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Lew DeWitt, the Statler Brothers tenor and guitarist for more than 18 years, died today at home, his business manager said. He was 53. DeWitt died this morning in his sleep, said Chet Fitzgerald. DeWitt had suffered from an intestinal disorder for nine years. ``He was coherent up until the end. He's been in ill health for several months,'' Fitzgerald said. DeWitt wrote one of the Statlers' biggest hits, ``Flowers on the Wall,'' in 1965. It sold more than 1 million copies and has been recorded by about 30 other artists. In those years the group traveled with country singer Johnny Cash's road show. Shortly after leaving the Statlers in 1982, DeWitt resumed his career on a smaller scale with the Star City Band. He retired again in November 1989. DeWitt, who suffered from regional enteritis, or Crohn's disease, said life on the road ``was miserable at times.'' At one point, his weight dropped from 213 pounds to 119 pounds. The Statlers were ``kicking around, singing gospel'' when they met Cash in nearby Roanoke in 1964, DeWitt once recalled. ``He saw something different in us _ something we could do to make more money.'' The Statlers converted to country music, and Cash put the group in his show. ``We had two flop records before we made it big,'' DeWitt said. ``We weren't really big in Columbia Records' eyes until `Flowers on the Wall.''' Over the next two decades, the Statlers became one of the most widely recognized groups in country music. They won three Grammy awards and were named top vocal groups nine times by the Country Music Association. DeWitt is survived by his wife, Judy, and four children, and his mother, Rose.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Rules Alleged PLO Terrorist Can Be Extradited to Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf with 2 grafs to UPDATE with defense attorney comment.
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court has cleared the way for the extradition to Israel of a Palestinian-American accused of taking part in a machine-gun attack on a bus traveling through the occupied West Bank. Mahmoud El-Abed Ahmad has been in jail since his arrest three years ago while lawyers argued over whether he could get a fair trial in Israel. In a unanimous ruling, the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals rejected Ahmad's argument that the crime was a political act not covered by an extradition treaty with Israel. Ahmad's lawyer, former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark, said today he would seek a stay of extradition while he petitioned the U.S. Supreme Court to review Ahmad's case. If the high court refuses to hear the case, Ahmad could be extradited, Clark said. Ahmad, 37, who Israeli authorities sometimes refer to as Mahmoud Abed Atta, is charged with taking part in a 1986 attack in which three Palestine Liberation Organization terrorists hurled Molotov cocktails and opened fire on a bus carrying Jewish settlers. The driver was killed and a passenger injured. Ahmad left Israel after the attack and was arrested by FBI agents in 1987 on a flight from Venezuela. In hearings last year before U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein, Ahmad argued he would not get a fair trial in Israel and would be tortured. Weinstein ruled in September that Ahmad should be extradited, saying his offense was not a political crime and that he would receive just treatment in Israel. The appeals court affirmed Weinstein's ruling but criticized him for holding such long hearings. ``The interests of international comity are ill-served by requiring a foreign nation such as Israel to satisfy a United States district judge concerning the fairness of its laws and the manner in which they are enforced,'' Judge Ellsworth H. Van Graafeiland wrote. The U.S. secretary of state has the final decision on whether extradition should be denied on humanitarian grounds, the court said. Ahmad was born in the West Bank town of Ramalah and became a U.S. citizen eight years ago.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: is established.
DOC.TEXT: Aug. 12 The Commericial Dispatch, Columbus, Miss., on David Souter: So far, we like what we don't hear about Judge David Souter, the president's nominee to the Supreme Court. He's a man who minds his own business and is too immersed in the law to seek the self-aggrandizing spotlight. He sounds like a man who has no use for the trend setters _ preferring to spend his time with the writings of the influential minds of the ages than with Andy Warhol and his 15-minutes-of-fame gang. His is an American character and mind we can be proud of. There seems little doubt that Souter is a strict constructionist, not prone to divining implications from the Constitution. We believe Souter will defer to Congress' prerogative of making the law ... and then test those laws against the immutable principles of the Constitution. The trouble comes when judges circumvent elected representatives, and thus the people, to decide social policy. Judge Souter will be a law tester within the context of learning and constructionism, not a lawmaker. He should be confirmed by the Senate when hearings start next month.

Aug. 11 Charleston (W.Va.) Daily Mail on the Red Cross: The American Red Cross is the nation's largest charity and it enjoys a high degree of public trust. But ... it (has) found itself defending its reputation on two fronts. The Pittsburgh Press reported on a nine-month investigation of the Red Cross response to more than 200 disasters. The paper found that the charity sometimes overstated its response to an emergency, especially right after a disaster. Sometimes, donated funds didn't go where contributors thought they were going. _Three days after a flood in Alabama, the Red Cross said it had opened a feeding site in Elba and was distributing hundreds of cleanup kits. Only one Red Cross worker was in Elba that day, the Press reported, and she didn't have cleanup kits. The Red Cross wasn't running a food operation, either; church groups were. _A local Red Cross unit raised $1.13 million after a tornado ripped up an Alabama subdivision. The recovery effort has cost the Red Cross $400,000 so far. The rest of the money went into the national disaster fund. _Contributors earmarked $40 million to help earthquake victims in northern California, and found out later that the Red Cross did not intend to spend that much there. Complaints were so vociferous that the Red Cross established a new policy; henceforth, funds contributed to a disaster will be used there. _The Red Cross gives the impression that disaster relief is its main line of work. But only about $100 million _ 9 percent of the $1.2 billion the Red Cross raised and spent last year _ went for disaster aid. About $664 million went for blood processing expenses. Red Cross blood operations have also come under fire _ serious when you consider that it supplies half the hospitals in the country. A Food and Drug Administration investigation showed weaknesses in Red Cross reporting of accidents and errors in handling blood. As a result, the charity is reorganizing its system and has replaced its director of blood services. ... The Red Cross will have to work overtime to explain some of these criticisms to the public on which it depends.

Aug. 13 The Dallas Morning News on foreign investment: After decades of deriding the rest of the world for refusing the benefits of U.S. investment, Americans are growing more fearful of losing their own economic and political independence to foreign interests investing in the United States. ... Why are Americans so afraid of foreign investment? If investment is good, what difference does it make where it comes from, as long as it is not from organized crime? Since Americans have been busy buying consumer goods and transferring incomes among themselves, rather than putting money into productive investments, it is nice someone has considered the United States to be worthy of investment. ... While foreign assets in the United States have increased to $2 trillion, the best guesses are that they amount to only about 1 percent of the nation's total wealth; foreign-owned firms employ less than 4 percent of the non-bank work force. One reason foreigners are transferring their huge dollar holdings into U.S. assets is that they can get good prices. Restrict this repatriation of capital ... and the U.S. economy will lose one of the few energetic factors left in it. The United States is not going to provide for its economic future by halting investment that gives foreigners a stake in keeping the U.S. economy healthy. The United States will provide for its future by getting its own house in order.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Patients Kept Alive By Hand During Blackout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to add Con Ed spokeswoman's comments today and hospital status, picking up 7th graf pvs, `County Natwest...'
DOC.TEXT: Nurses kept hospital patients alive by operating respirators by hand and a Wall Street firm set up in a hotel ballroom because of a fire-caused blackout in its third day today in lower Manhattan. The fire Monday at a Consolidated Edison substation trapped thousands of Wall Street workers in steamy buildings. By Tuesday, most of the Wall Street area and the American Stock Exchange and New York commodities markets had reopened. But Con Ed said the South Street Seaport, the Fulton Fish Market and a 1,550-unit high-rise apartment complex could be without power until Sunday. The utility estimated 1,600 customers were affected. About 2,000 utility workers were pulling and splicing cables today in the 38-block zone surrounding the South Street Seaport tourist attraction-shopping area, said Con Ed spokeswoman Pat Richardi. ``Things are pretty much the same as they were yesterday,'' she said. Residents and businesses in the area, for the most part, were showing great forbearance and keeping their spirits up, Ms. Richardi said. ``I think by and large people have shown a lot of patience and even good humor.'' The 300-bed Beekman-Downtown Hospital was without power Tuesday for about 1{ hours when its emergency generators failed. No patients were hurt, but nurses had to operate the respirators of 14 patients by hand until portable generators provided by Con Edison and the Fire Department were set up in their rooms, said nursing director Sandra Sperry. The hospital canceled all non-emergency operations. The hospital was providing all essential services to its patients this morning, said spokeswoman Joan Macri. ``Things are very good now. ... Everybody's spirits are up. Everyone is pitching in.'' County Natwest USA shifted 75 people in its equity sales and trading operations to the Grand Renaissance ballroom at the Helmsley Palace hotel in midtown Manhattan after it was driven from its offices on Wall Street. Employees of Quick & Reilly Inc. hauled trading and account records down 14 flights of stairs. The discount brokerage managed to hook up telephones in its stock clearing firm shortly after the market opened at 9:30 a.m. ``We all came down carrying boxes and bags,'' said Thomas Quick, the brokerage's president. ``Then it was navigating the crowds on the streets.'' At the Fulton Fish Market, Joe Minio, owner of Smitty's Filet House, said he had bought about $1,000 worth of dry ice to try and keep his salmon, tuna and swordfish cold. John Flanigan, owner of Emerald Sea Food, said he could lose 75 percent of his Monday shipment of fish. Con Edison spokesman Bill Murphy said damage was so extensive to the substation that it was impossible to determine the cause of the fire.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: in order.
DOC.TEXT: Aug. 14 Messimvrini, Athens, Greece, on the Persian Gulf crisis: One would assume that after 50 years of human progress and the attempts that have been made to heal the wounds of World War II there should no longer be any ``madmen'' anywhere who would play with fire. ... And yet, as if there were no Hitler, as if there were no Mussolini, ... as if there were no merciless war in which rivers of blood were spilled and the world were divided into two camps, up comes ... Saddam Hussein _ wanting to follow in the footsteps of those notable dictators. In 1940, though, the free people of the West either did not notice the danger in time or shrank back when they should have said the big ``no'' in the way that smaller but brave nations such as ours did. ... And so those two paranoid ``conquerors of the world'' began the slaughter. ... Today, fortunately, things are different. Or appear to be different. ... (F)ellow Arabs have joined in the Western multinational force against the Iraqi ``visionary conqueror'' and herald of the ``holy war'' of hatred. ... In this way it is possible that his blackmail will not succeed. In fact, Saddam Hussein may pass into history as one of the failed ``conquerors'' of humanity, whom no one will remember in a few years, in far less than 50 years.

Aug. 13 Stampa Sera, Turin, Italy, on the Persian Gulf crisis: Saddam Hussein is sufficiently intelligent to know that the United States cannot impose, even if it wanted to, anything on Israel. And if ever it wanted to ``convince'' the present rightwing government of Israel to clear out of the occupied territories, the U.S. could not do it particularly now when paradoxically, thanks to Saddam, Israel will recover that role of ``bulwark of the West'' that was weakened as a result of the American-Soviet thawing. But to tie a possible withdrawal from Kuwait, obviously in exchange for some guarantees (that is, money and strategic islands) to the problematic withdrawl of Israeli forces from the territories would serve Saddam primarily to save his face, and secondarily to repropose himself as the ``knight of the Arabs.''

Aug. 9 El Mercurio, Santiago, Chile, on the Persian Gulf crisis: Some think that the other oil exporting countries will not be able to increase their production to fill the vacuum left by the (United Nations) embargo (on Iraq). That is a reasonable point of view, although it is also disputable. Those holding that point of view seem to ignore that strategic reserves of oil exist that will ensure supplies for a fairly long period of time. On the other hand, both Iraq and Kuwait have very large food deficits. Will the threat of famine make (Sadam) Hussein change his mind? Or, on the contrary, will it be able to strengthen the unity of the Arab peoples in an Islamic crusade seeking to do away with the pro-Western Arab monarchies, Israel and Christians still living in Lebanon?
