Should that happen, the answer from the West would be immediate, violent, paralyzing.

Aug. 14 Tass, the official Soviet news agency, Moscow, on the Persian Gulf crisis: The developments of the recent days _ Iraq's annexation of Kuwait and worldwide reactions to the act _ have brought into focus the long-pressing question _ to give a boost to the work of the Military Staff Committee of the United Nations Security Council. ... During the war in Korea, the functions of the direction of armed forces placed at the disposal of the United Nations by some member states were transferred, as a result of U.S. political maneuvers, directly to the General Assembly. The Military Staff Committee thereby turned into a stillborn agency. In the 1970s ... committee sessions were held regularly but they were a pure formality. ... Now that the Cold War has ended, the situation has radically changed. ... The Soviet Union has reconsidered its attitude toward many U.N. agencies, including the Military Staff Committee. Undoubtedly, conditions are quite ripe to add substance to its functioning. A solution to problems that have arisen in the Persian Gulf area could be the first practical step in this respect. Collective efforts and full use of U.N. mechanisms are the surest and the most reasonable way to act in such conflict situations. ... In the current complex situation in the Middle East, it would be apparently quite useful to use the potential of the United Nations, the Security Council and its Military Staff Committee, and not just the efforts of the United States alone with the involvement of other countries.

Aug. 10 Straits Times, Singapore, on Pakistan: The dismissal of ... Benazir Bhutto as prime minister of Pakistan answers to a familiar pattern in Pakistani politics. Ever since its inception in 1947, Pakistan has had problems coming to terms with democracy. ... However, the proper way to deal with weaknesses of the government would have been to subject it to questioning and possible defeat on the floor of Parliament, not dismiss it from above. The presidential action is a problematic one, therefore. Ms. Bhutto has alleged that the military, with which she had growing differences, had a hand in her dismissal. If this is true, the whole affair would be a reminder of the way the army has intervened in politics whenever, in its judgment, the politicians have made a mess of things. ... Pakistan has fought, and lost, four wars with India. There are some who think that army rule contributed to Pakistan's decision to fight, and that a dilution of military professionalism because of involvement in politics contributed to its defeat. Given that the next war might not remain non-nuclear, regional stability would dictate that Pakistan make every effort to resolve its political problems effectively and quickly.

Aug. 13 The Daily Telegraph, London, on Marion Barry: (Washington Mayor Marion) Barry's case is a striking indictment of the state of race relations in America. A public officer found guilty of an offense which the administration sees as one of the greatest threats to society should have resigned immediately. Instead, the mayor basks in the adulation of his supporters and speaks sentimentally of forgiveness. A government which believed in justice would hasten to strengthen its case. Instead, it appears to be wavering for fear of a black backlash. Such muddled thinking diminishes public respect for the rule of law and, by encouraging them to see themselves as eternal victims, does a profound disservice to blacks. It is time to recall Martin Luther King's words that a man should be judged not by the color of his skin but by the content of his character.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Nazi Dictator Stripped of Honorary Citizenship
DOC.TEXT: The city of Potsdam stripped Adolf Hitler of his honorary citizenship on Wednesday, more than 45 years after the Nazi dictator's death. City councilors in this town outside Berlin were correcting an embarrassing oversight that was hushed up by the former Communist regime. Potsdam officials also revoked the honorary citizenship for Hermann Goering, the top Nazi official who directed Hitler's air war against the Allies. Both votes in the 76-member city council were unanimous. Potsdam officials made Hitler an honorary citizen in March 1933, an action that dozens of other German cities also undertook. City officials discovered in 1988 that they had not revoked the honor for Hitler and Goering. They hushed up the oversight to avoid the wrath of the hard-line Communists. Earlier this summer, Potsdam officials admitted their mistake and promised to take care of the matter.

DOC.HEAD: Bus, Tram Drivers Strike in Siberian City
DOC.TEXT: Bus and tram drivers in the city of Krasnoyarsk in eastern Siberia staged a one-day strike Wednesday for higher pay, affecting thousands of commuters, the Tass news agency reported. The transit workers, whose monthly salary averages about $735, are seeking a 25 percent pay increase, the official news agency said. The City Council agreed to form a commission to deal with the drivers' demands, and the strike ended at 6 p.m., Tass said. The workers went on strike for higher pay, among other issues, one year ago, Tass said. While many of the other demands have been satisfied, the wage issue remains outstanding, the news agency said without elaboration. Soviet workers increasingly have been resorting to strikes to protest their working conditions. Last summer, thousands of coal miners staged strikes in the Soviet Union to press economic and political demands. Krasnoyarsk, a city of 885,000 people, is 1,920 miles east of Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Dirty Flows The Don: Seven Stricken by Cholera Along River
DOC.TEXT: Seven people fell ill with cholera in southern Russia along the Don River, apparently from raw sewage that is flowing into the waterway, a Soviet newspaper reported Wednesday. The seven were stricken in the community of Koluzaevo, near the city of Rostov, about 600 miles south of Moscow, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported. About 2.8 million cubic feet of raw sewage are pumped daily into the Temernik River, a tributary of the Don, causing bacterial levels to increase up to 100 times more than is permissible, the newspaper reported. One of the victims apparently drank water from the Don, Pravda said. It did not say how the others were infected. Health officials are making house-to-house inquiries to check people who may have come in contact with those who fell ill, the newspaper said. Fishing and the operation of private boats on the river are forbidden, Pravda added.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Term for Hotel Owner Upheld by High Court
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo High Court on Wednesday upheld a three-year prison term for the owner of a Tokyo hotel that burned in 1982, killing 32 people. Presiding Judge Taro Okubo said the court agreed with the lower court's 1987 ruling that Hideki Yokoi, owner of the now-closed Hotel New Japan, was responsible for the failure to improve the hotel's fire safety measures. A pre-dawn blaze destroyed the top two floors of the 10-story hotel Feb. 8, 1982, killing 32 people. Prosecutors argued that the hotel's fire-prevention systems were inadequate, despite orders from the Tokyo Metropolitan Fire Board for improvements, and said the hotel had failed to install sprinklers and train employees on how to evacuate guests. Yokoi, 77, is being held on $1.7 million bail. Lawyers for Yokoi said he has not decided whether to appeal to the Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Says Patrol Ship Hit Chinese Fishing Boat By Accident
DOC.TEXT: Taiwan's navy acknowledged Wednesday that one of its patrol boats accidentally slammed into a Chinese boat filled with people being forced back to China. Twenty-one people on the Chinese boat drowned. Defense Minister Chen Li-an said a court will investigate the collision and that those responsible will be ``dealt with severely.'' The vessel Min Ping Yu No. 5202, carrying 50 illegal Chinese aliens, was being forced to return to China when the accident occurred Monday night. The navy initially claimed the fishing boat rammed into the patrol ship. The navy rescued 29 Chinese from the high seas. Searchers found three bodies Wednesday, and 18 other people were missing and presumed drowned. All of those on board the fishing vessel, except the crew, were locked in a cabin to prevent them from jumping ship and swimming back to Taiwan. The crew were also Chinese illegal aliens. Taiwan has repatriated more than 10,000 mainland Chinese since 1987. Last week, China's official Xinhua News Agency claimed Taiwanese authorities sealed 26 Chinese in the cabin of a fishing boat and sent them back to China, causing 25 of them to suffocate to death. Taiwan denied the report and said mainland Chinese were repatriated in humane ways.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Paul Klee Dies 3 Days Before Opening Exposition
DOC.TEXT: Swiss art historian Felix Klee, the son of artist Paul Klee, is dead at age 82. He died Monday, three days before he was to open a commemorative exhibition of his father's works at the Bern Kunstmuseum, the museum announced. The exhibition is to mark the 50th anniversary of his father's death. Paul Klee, a German expatriate born in Bern, rose to prominence in Germany in the 1920s. He returned to Switzerland in 1933 when the Nazis seized power and declared his work degenerate art. Felix Klee, his only son, studied music in Germany and was drafted into the Wehrmacht in 1944 to serve on the Russian front. After his release from a Soviet prison camp, Felix Klee moved to Switzerland where he was naturalized in 1960. In 1957 he published the diaries of his father and since 1963, he headed the Paul Klee-Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors End Strike After 19 Days
DOC.TEXT: Doctors called off a nationwide strike after 19 days on Wednesday when the government promised to review a ban on private practice. Hundreds of patients were reported to have died from lack of care during the strike by the country's 8,000 doctors. Abdul Majid, president of the Bangladesh Medical Association, said the doctors would give the government three weeks to formulate a new health policy. Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest countries, spends less than $1 per person annually on health care for its 110 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Army Prepared to Distribute Gas Masks, Awaiting Order
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The army has completed preparations for handing out gas masks to all Israelis, but Israeli leaders said Wednesday they were hesitant to give the order because it might create panic and send a wrong message to Iraq. Many Israelis were not waiting for government action. Alarmed by Iraqi threats to attack Israel with chemical weapons, residents were buying protective gear from private stores. ``By the time the army distributes the gas masks it will be too late,'' one shopper told the Yediot Ahronot daily Wednesday. The man bought a gas mask, plastic poncho, rubber boots and gloves at Amos Gazit Co., a safety equipment store in Tel Aviv. In Jerusalem, a store called Safety and Protection tried to lure shoppers by hanging a white protective suit and gas mask outside the front door. Boxes of gas masks were piled on the small shop's floor. Employees refused to discuss business. Israeli newspapers have been running full-page articles explaining what type of gloves, clothing, boots and gas masks are needed for protection against chemical weapons. Israel has long prepared itself for chemical warfare. Students go through gas attack drills and even the telephone book contains instructions of what to do in the event of a gas attack. Anxiety about an Iraqi attack increased Sunday after Iraqi President Saddam warned he would attack Israel if the Americans launched a military strike in the Persian Gulf. Saddam has nerve gases in his arsenal. Israel army radio reported Wednesday that Israel's Civil Defense had completed preparations for distributing gas masks to all Israelis, and that it was now up to the government to issue such an order. Defense Minister Moshe Arens reportedly is trying to assess whether mass distribution of gas masks would be perceived by Iraq as an Israeli preparation for a strike against it. Foreign Minister David Levy said that in the current tense atmosphere, Saddam might use the distribution of gas masks as an excuse to attack Israel. ``It could be interpreted as preparation of an Israeli step, and this could be used as an alibi by that dictator (Saddam) to do something,'' Levy told army radio. An army source said gas masks could be distributed to all 4.5 million Israelis within four or five days if the government gave the go-ahead. In Tel Aviv, meanwhile, the municipality's Emergency Committee met with army officials to discuss emergency preparations and said hundreds of bomb shelters have been checked in recent days.

DOC.HEAD: Bert Parks Makes It Official: He'll Sing at Pageant
DOC.TEXT: Bert Parks said today that despite ``residual resentment over the years,'' he reluctantly agreed to appear in the Miss America Pageant's 70th anniversary show this year. Parks was fired in January 1980 after being host of the Miss America Pageant for 25 years. Then-pageant director Albert Marks Jr., who died last year, said Parks was too old at age 65 to continue. Parks, now 75, will sing ``There She Is,'' the theme song he made famous, to a parade of former Miss Americas. But the new Miss America still will be serenaded by Gary Collins, who will remain the pageant co-host with Phyllis George. Asked whether he was happy with the arrangement, Parks replied, ``I'm not crazy about that _ no.'' The decision to have Collins sing was made for ``contractual reasons. But we'll see about that,'' he said impishly. Parks appeared at a news conference with Dorothy Benham, Miss America 1977, and Leonard Horn, chief executive officer at the Miss America Organization. They symbolically buried a hatchet in a cake that read, ``Welcome back Bert. Miss America Pageant 1990.'' Horn said Parks would have other, as yet undisclosed, roles in the show. He said Parks and show officials had not discussed whether he would be back for more than one year.

DOC.HEAD: New US Ambassador to Kuwait Ready to Go `When Iraqis Leave'
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For more than 20 years Edward W. Gnehm Jr. toiled the diplomatic ranks on his way to being confirmed as new ambassador to Kuwait. Then, within hours, Iraq's invading army made him an envoy without a post. Gnehm, a 45-year-old career Foreign Service Officer, was endorsed by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for his first ambassadorship only seven hours before Saddam Hussein's forces swept into the tiny Persian Gulf sheikdom. The Senate formally approved him a day after the invasion. ``It was fair irony,'' he said in an interview. Gnehm had left his post as deputy assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, and was ``in the throes of packing'' when Iraq's takeover of Kuwait disrupted his travel schedule. Gnehm, a Georgia native known as ``Skip,'' said he and his family had planned to take a beach vacation last week and then return to Washington to pack and depart for Kuwait. Instead, he has been thrust into the job of director of Task Force One, a State Department crisis center handling family liaison and other political, military and consular matters concerning the Middle East situation. Gnehm is also at the Washington end of critical telecommunication lines with U.S. embassies in Kuwait and Baghdad. He said he is putting in 16- to 18-hour days and ``it's a big job. .... We receive thousands of calls a day'' from people with family or other personal interests in Iraq or Kuwait. The outgoing ambassador to Kuwait, Nat Howell, is to remain indefinitely in Kuwait City. It is not yet clear how the Bush administration will respond to Iraqi orders for all foreign diplomats to leave the city by Aug. 24. Meanwhile, Gnehm's ambassadorial responsibilities have been confined to such duties as escorting the foreign minister of Kuwait's government-in-exile around Washington. Gnehm had anticipated that his new posting might be a troubled one. In July 25 Senate confirmation hearings, he said the State Department was ``deeply concerned'' about Iraqi troop movements toward Kuwait. ``They are near the Kuwaiti border. They are threatening. There is no question about Saddam's intentions.'' Sen. Daniel Moynihan, at the same hearing, advised Gnehm, ``Do not hesitate to tell them in Kuwait that they are a very small, weak country that is very rich. And there are a lot of countries, other countries, that would like to gobble them up.'' Gnehm, who speaks Arabic and French, received a master of arts degree from George Washington University in 1968 and a year later joined the foreign service as a commercial officer in Saigon, Vietnam. He went on to serve as vice consul in Nepal, economic officer in Syria, head of the embassy liaison office in Saudi Arabia and deputy chief of mission in North Yemen. He worked as deputy chief of mission in Jordan from 1984 to 1987 before being appointed deputy assistant secretary of defense for the Near East and South Asia and then moving to his most recent State Department post last year. Gnehm said he was still excited about his first chance to head a diplomatic mission and hoped he could assume his post soon. ``I'm looking forward to a successful term in Kuwait,'' he said, ``once the Iraqis leave.''

DOC.HEAD: Uganda Anglicans Accept Women Priests
DOC.TEXT: Bishops of the Anglican Church in Uganda have voted to accept the ordination of women priests, it was reported Wednesday. New Vision newspaper said the decision was announced by Archbishop Yona Okoth of Kampala at the opening of a four-day church assembly. The Anglican Church was established in Uganda by British missionaries 110 years ago and has a current estimated membership of about 5 million. The question of ordaining women has been hotly debated in Uganda for a number of years.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb on Railroad Defused
DOC.TEXT: The army defused a 40-pound bomb on the Belfast-Dublin railroad Wednesday after receiving a warning from the Irish Republican Army, police said. The IRA telephoned a local radio station and said a bomb was on the line in southern County Armagh, near the Irish border, police said. They said the bomb contained homemade explosives and a timing device. The railroad, a frequent target of bombs, was closed while police searched the area. In Londonderry, in the northwest of the British-ruled province, police said they fired a plastic bullet while dispersing youths who threw 30 gasoline bombs at army patrols. There were no injuries, they said. Army bomb disposal experts were called to defuse bombs planted on two hijacked vehicles, they added. Police said the incidents were believed linked to the 21st anniversary of the arrival of the British troops on the streets of Londonderry. The IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the province with the Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Former Chairman of Animal Protection Group Cited for Cruelty to Dogs
DOC.TEXT: The former chairwoman of an animal protection group has been charged with cruelty to animals in connection with the killing of hundreds of dogs by lethal injections, newspapers said Wednesday. Clara Josefina Leloir Unzue, 75, was arrested Tuesday at her home following complaints from neighbors. Eleven animals were found dead at the house, and 37 were rescued and taken to an animal shelter. Most of them were healthy. The independent news agency Noticias Argentinas quoted Mrs. Unzue as saying she had been putting sick animals out of their misery. She is a former chairwoman of the Sarmiento Society for the Protection of Animals. Under Argentine federal law, cruelty to animals is punishable by prison terms of 15 days to one year.

DOC.HEAD: Yosemite's Hot, but Park Avoids Controversy of Yellowstone Blazes
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Forest fires this week in California's Yosemite National Park have cooked up memories of 1988, when flames swept across another cherished piece of the West: Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming. The fires have a lot in common. Both were aggravated by extreme drought and a decades-long buildup of dry, downed wood. And fires in both parks are considered natural _ even essential _ ecological forces. But Yosemite officials are glad of one big difference: They have so far escaped the harsh criticism that Yellowstone's fires focused on the National Park Service's policy of letting some forest fires burn. During the virtually rainless summer of 1988, fires swept through nearly half of Yellowstone's 2.2 million acres. The unusual drought surprised Yellowstone managers, who clung for weeks to their standing policy of letting most natural fires burn if no human lives or property are threatened. By mid-July, when officials declared war on all fires within the park, it was too late. Only the cooler, wetter weather of autumn stopped the flames. The controversy raged even longer, as the Park Service took heat for what critics called a ``let-it-burn'' policy. This past week in Yosemite, fire has charred more than 18,000 acres and caused more than $10 million in property damage. While small compared to the Yellowstone fires, the fires have been especially destructive in the popular park, where almost every feature of the landscape is treasured by visitors. Fire destroyed 66 homes in Foresta, a vacation village near the park. Four other communities were evacuated, and the 759,000-acre park has been closed to visitors since Friday. But criticism of the Park Service has been light. Like Yellowstone, Yosemite has a policy of letting lightning-struck fires burn in some areas. But the fires this summer are burning in ``suppression areas,'' where fires are fought automatically because of their proximity to roads or buildings, said Sue Fritzke, a Yosemite fire official. ``There was no question of policy at all,'' she said. It also helps that Californians are more accustomed to drought and wildfire, she said. While Yellowstone's fires were a hundred-year event, the Yosemite fires are the result of a four-year statewide drought, and are by no means California's worst blazes this summer. ``California was made to burn,'' Fritzke said. ``People here understand that fire is a part of the ecosystem.'' In both parks, officials blamed the intensity of the fires on 100 years of unenlightened management. ``You always thought fires were bad and you put them out. That was in the days before we understood the role fire plays in forest ecology,'' said Joan Anzelmo, a Yellowstone spokeswoman. By not allowing periodic, small fires to sweep the forest clear of fallen dead wood and underbrush, managers set the stage for huge, destructive fires. That practice changed in the early 1970s, but there's still a buildup of downed wood and underbrush left over from earlier days. Huge sequoias in Yosemite, for example, have survived 2,000 years of periodic fire and drought. But they are susceptible to intense crown fires that roar through the canopy of the overgrown forest, so crews this week sprayed the majestic sequoias with flame retardant chemicals. Normal fire policy is on hold in both parks. In Yosemite, managers are waiting for more manpower and cooler weather before resuming theri controlled burns. In Yellowstone, all blazes have been fought since 1988, pending adoption of a new, stricter fire management plan due out next year. Officials in both parks said fire demonstrates nature's amazing recuperative ability. After the 1988 fires, Yellowstone researchers watched in wonder as plants poked up through ash and wildlife wandered back to begin a new cycle of life. In Yosemite this week, the persistence of human nature was also apparent. Doug Martin, a Foresta resident whose home burned down, is calling neighbors this week to tell them of damage to their homes. Most of them don't care so much about how the town looks or if it's safe to return. Martin said their first question is: ``Are we going to be allowed to rebuild?''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Helms Group Files FEC Complaint Against Gay Boycott
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of Sen. Jesse Helms have filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission over a boycott of Philip Morris products by gay rights groups. The complaint filed by an independent group called Re-Elect Jesse Helms says homosexual groups are acting as a political action committee in boycotting Marlboro cigarettes and Miller beer, both made by Philip Morris Inc. The boycott was called because Philip Morris' political action committee has contributed to Helms' re-election campaign. ``While economic boycotts may be considered lawful as a means of political protest, (newspaper articles submitted with the complaint) leave no doubt that the true purpose and intent of defendants' activities extend beyond acts of protest to the defeat of Senator Jesse Helms for re-election,'' says the complaint filed last week. Because none of the groups are registered as political committees, efforts promoting the boycott amount to an improper spending of funds to influence an election, the complaint alleges. The complaint names ACT UP-District of Columbia and ACT UP-San Francisco, which are AIDS activist groups with gay rights components; as well as the Dallas Gay Tavern Guild, the Dallas Gay Alliance and the Tarrant County (Texas) Gay Alliance. Kate Raphael, a member of ACT UP-San Francisco who helped organize the boycotts, said the group was assured by its attorneys that the boycotts comply with federal elections laws. ``We've been assured that what we're doing is most certainly permissible with the FEC,'' Ms. Raphael said. ``What it does make clear is that this action is having the desired effect'' by hurting Helms' campaign. Helms angered gay activists this year by criticizing National Endowment of the Arts grants for a Robert Mapplethorpe photography exhibit that included photos of homoerotic acts and naked children. The exhibit by the late Mapplethorpe led Helms to propose restrictions on federal support of art deemed obscene or offensive. Helms also has been a vocal critic of any federal spending on AIDS education that might condone or promote homosexuality. The FEC complaint is at least the second filed by Helms' supporters in the past week. State GOP chairman Jack Hawke last week filed a complaint with the commission asking that it investigate any relationship between the National Abortion Rights Action League and the campaign of Harvey Gantt, Helms' Democratic opponent in November. Hawke questioned an ad by the league that criticized Helms' opposition to abortion. Hawke asked the FEC to investigate whether the ad is an independent expenditure or whether it is connected to the Gantt campaign. Gantt campaign manager Mel Watt denied any connection between the campaign and the ad.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Indicts Grape-Growing Brothers
DOC.TEXT: Two grape growers have been charged with passing off inexpensive wine grapes as premium varieties. Brothers Nick and Frank Bavaro, who own vineyards and a grape brokerage in Escalon in the San Joaquin Valley, are at the center of a statewide grape scandal. An indictment charged them with conspiracy, mail and wire fraud and false statements to the United States Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms in connection to the sale of wine grapes to seven northern California wineries. The indictments from a federal grand jury were issued late last week. If convicted of all charges, each faces a maximum of 130 years in prison and fines up to $6.5 million. Lawyers for both brothers declined comment. According to the indictment, inexpensive grapes such as Valdepena and French columbard were sold as expensive Zinfandel, Chardonnay and other varieties. The Bavaros made $400 to $1,200 per ton for grapes that usually sell for $100 to $200 per ton. The brothers allegedly lied about at least 6,500 tons of wine grapes valued on the wholesale market at about $4 million. Among the wineries that purchased the grapes in question were the Delicato Vineyards in Manteca, the Lost Hills Winery in Acampo and the Robert Mondavi Winery in Oakville.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Seeks End To War With Iran; Bush To Urge Jordan To Close Port
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 28th graf pvs, Crown Prince... to CORRECT spelling of Hassan; pick up 29th graf pvs, `A CBS...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX6,7,XSAV1,NY5,10,TOK1,XAAFB1,AMM1, LaserColor XAAFB1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's Saddam Hussein, facing U.S. and Arab troops at the Saudi border, today sought peace on another front by promising to withdraw from Iranian territory and release soldiers captured during the Iran-Iraq war. Also today, King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Washington seeking to mediate the Persian Gulf crisis. President Bush on Tuesday said the United States may extend its naval quarantine to Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba to shut off Iraq's last unhindered trade route. In another mediation effort, the Soviet Union said today it had sent an envoy to the Middle East on a series of stops to include Baghdad. Soviet officials also said Soviet women, children and invalids would be allowed to leave Iraq. President Bush today denounced Saddam's ``ruinous policies of war,'' and said the United States is ``striking a blow for the principle that might does not make right.'' In a speech delivered at the Pentagon, Bush seemed to suggest that American forces could be in the gulf region for some time. ``No one should doubt our staying power or determination,'' he said. The U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia continued at fever pace, with Syrian troops now part of a multinational force camped out in the desert to guard the Saudi kingdom from any new thrust by Iraq. In a letter to President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, read by a broadcaster over Baghdad radio, Saddam said he will begin withdrawing troops from Iranian territory on Friday and release Iranian prisoners of war. Iran said an Iraqi diplomatic delegation was en route to Tehran to deliver Saddam's message, which it said it would review ``with optimism.'' Saddam appeared to accept a border demarcation treaty he had rejected in peace talks following the August 1988 cease-fire of the eight-year war with Iran. The move seemed aimed at heading off more trouble with Iran, which had condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 but also criticized the multinational force dispatched to Saudi Arabia. Saddam said he sought to ``turn the gulf into a lake of peace free of foreign fleets and forces that harbor ill intentions against us.'' In other developments: _The Pentagon said that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is considering urging Bush to order a national callup of armed forces reserves for active duty because of the drain on units sending soldiers abroad. Bush can call up to 200,000 reservists for up to 180 days without seeking congressional approval. _Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said special ambassador Mikhail Sytenko left Tuesday for consultations with the governments of Syria, Jordan, Egypt and other Arab countries. Sytenko, a former deputy secretary-general of the United Nations, is also expected to visit Baghdad, Gremitskikh said at a regular news briefing today. _The outlook darkened for about 3,000 Americans caught in Iraq and Kuwait when Saddam sent his forces into the small, oil-rich sultanate. The Iraqi ambassador to Greece said in Athens the Americans and other stranded foreigners could leave ``as soon as the threats from the United States and its allies are eliminated.'' ABC quoted an Iraqi Foreign Ministry official in Baghdad as saying Americans in Iraq are ``restrictees'' who will stay there until the crisis ends. _The Soviet Foreign Ministry said Soviet women, children and invalids would be permitted to leave Iraq. Spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said the first group of 230 evacuees was assembling in Baghdad today, but evacuation plans were hampered by desert heat and lack of transportation. Nearly 9,000 Soviets were among the hundreds of thousands of foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq has agreed to allow all 880 Soviets in Kuwait to leave, but only by a 1,200-mile road route through Iraq and to the Iraq-Jordan border. _The British Foreign Office said today conditions in Kuwait appear to be deteriorating. There have been reports of wholesale looting but food and gasoline were still available, said a spokesman, who by custom was not identified. Banks remained closed. _The Iraqi ambassador to Venezuela said on Tuesday that Iraq would retaliate against Venezuela and other OPEC oil cartel members if they boost oil production to fill the gap created by blocked supplies from Iraq and Kuwait. With Kuwait now ``annexed,'' Iraq has control of 20 percent of the world's oil reserves. A steep rise in world oil prices followed the Kuwait invasion. The U.N. Security Council on Aug. 6 ordered a global embargo on trade with Iraq as punishment for seizing Kuwait. Bush then sent U.S. troops and planes to Saudi Arabia, saying Iraqi troops massed nearby in Kuwait threatened Saudi Arabia and its vast oil reserves. Twelve Arab League nations voted for an Arab force to protect Saudi Arabia, with the vanguard of Syria's contingent arriving Tuesday, according to diplomatic sources in Riyadh, the Saudi capital. Egyptian and Moroccan troops are already there. The predominantly Moslem nation of Bangladesh said today its troops would join multinational forces in Saudi Arabia. The size of the contingent was not disclosed. Turkey and Saudi Arabia in effect shut down Iraq's major oil outlets through those countries, but according to Jordanian officials, a smaller line into Jordan remained operating. Truckloads of goods rolled into Iraq from Jordan on Tuesday and Iraqi-bound cargo was unloaded from ships at the Red Sea port ofAqaba despite the U.N.-ordered sanctions. King Hussein was reportedly carrying a message to Bush from Iraq's Saddam, with whom the king met Monday. The monarch will meet Bush on Thursday in Kennebunkport, Maine. Crown Prince Hassan, King Hussein's brother and political adviser, was asked today about the message the king was said to be carrying. In an interview from Jordan on ABC, he declined to discuss details, but said: ``I don't think that his majesty would be traveling at this crucial moment if the Iraqi leadership did not have a rational approach to the future.'' A CBS News report citing unidentified Jordanian sources said that Saddam's message called for an international conference to be convened to discuss an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. In exchange, the buildup of U.S. forces in the region would halt. Bush, however, says he sees no short-term hope for a diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis _ at least until economic sanctions force Saddam to withdraw his army. Bush held out the prospect of more aid to Jordan if it cooperates with the trade embargo. On Tuesday, the United States and Soviet Union conferred in Washington on putting an anti-Iraq naval blockade under a United Nations umbrella. The United States has provided most of the naval vessels so far to block Iraqi trade, with Britain, West Germany and Australia among the other nations lending support at sea. The embargo is meant to cripple Iraq by cutting off its exports of oil and imports of food and military supplies. Iraq imports about three-quarters of its foodstuffs. U.S. allies and other U.N. members have objected that the Security Council embargo resolution did not specifically authorize such a naval operation. Bush told a news conference on Tuesday that the naval barricade now in force might be extended to Jordan's Aqaba ``if it is a hole through which commerce flows'' in and out of Iraq. In Saudi Arabia, today is the eighth day of ``Desert Shield,'' the operation designed to confront an estimated 200,000 Iraqi soldiers now in Kuwait. Iraq boasts an army of 1 million members. At least 50,000 U.S. troops are expected to be committed to Desert Shield within weeks, including Marines, Army air assault forces, paratroopers and infantry. Iraq said it invaded Kuwait because of disputes over oil and money. It accused Kuwait of deliberately slashing Iraqi oil revenues by overproducing oil and driving down prices, among other charges. Iraq has 17 million residents, and Kuwait about 1.9 million.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Most Americans Closely Watching Persian Gulf
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two-thirds of Americans surveyed say they're closely following developments in the Persian Gulf while 85 percent say the crisis is the most important news of the month, a media group reported Wednesday. The Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press said the 66 percent of Americans who say they're closely watching the Persian Gulf story is the fourth highest level recorded since the surveys began in 1986. The highest percentage was set by the 1986 explosion of the space shuttle Challenger _ 80 percent. That was followed by last year's San Francisco earthquake at 73 percent, and the 1987 saga of Jessica McClure, a toddler who was rescued after falling into a well near her Texas home at 69 percent. The center, an arm of the Times Mirror Co., makes regular surveys of public interest in news developments. The Persian Gulf story was considered the most important story of August by 85 percent of those surveyed, the center said. The previous high was set by December's U.S. invasion of Panama, regarded as the most important story of that month by 56 percent of those surveyed. The surveys also found that 60 percent paid very close attention to the invasion of Panama and 58 percent to U.S. air strikes against Libya in 1986. The Marine landing in embattled Liberia last week to evacuate American citizens attracted very close interest among only 27 percent of the public, the center said. Among blacks, the figure rose to 33 percent. Liberia was founded by freed slaves from America. Nelson Mandela's announcement that the African National Congress would end its armed struggle with white-ruled South Africa was followed very closely by 47 percent of black Americans and only 8 percent of white Americans. Thirty percent of African-Americans very closely followed the verdict in the drug trial of Marion Barry, the black mayor of Washington, D.C., compared with 14 percent of whites. The center said 66 percent of the public knew that the Soviet Union is supporting U.S. efforts to get Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and 64 percent knew that other countries will send forces to defend Saudi Arabia against an Iraqi invasion. In other news, the center said that 30 percent of the public, an unusually large proportion, said they closely followed news about the economy during the previous four weeks. In May, only 18 percent said they were paying close attention. Comedian Roseanne Barr's controversial rendition of the national anthem attracted more attention than George Steinbrenner being forced to give up control of the New York Yankees, the center said. Twelve percent followed the Steinbrenner story closely, while 21 percent kept track of the controversy involving Ms. Barr. Only 4 percent of Americans said they followed very closely the ouster of Benazir Bhutto, Pakistan's first female prime minister. The organization surveyed 1,213 adults by telephone from Aug. 9-12. The margin of error is plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Order Allows Bank to Operate Programs in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: President Bush issued an order Wednesday allowing the Export-Import Bank to operate its loan guarantee and credit programs in East Germany. Bush's decision will be beneficial to U.S. companies that want to do business in East Germany, said White House spokesman Bill Harlow. The Export-Import Bank, a U.S. agency, is designed to enhance exports from the United States by providing loans to foreign interests. The order waived the Jackson-Vanick law, generally used to set criteria for granting the most favorable U.S. trading relations with other nations. The law requires that a nation must grant free immigration and other rights to gain most-favored trading status with the United States. East Germany has met those conditions, but its pending unification with West Germany made a trade agreement moot, Harlow said.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Protest in East Berlin, Economics Ministers Fired
With PM-East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with the dismissal of four ministers who dealt with the economy. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of East German farmers protested today on the square where communism was toppled to demand protection from free-market forces crushing their industry. Late in the day, East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere fired four ministers who dealt most closely with the nation's crumbling economy. Dismissed were Finance Minister Walter Romberg, Agriculture Minister Peter Pollack, Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl and Justice Minister Kurt Wuensche. Pollack presides over the economic sector of the nation that has been hardest hit by East Germany's shift to a free market. The estimated 30,000 farmers who converged on East Berlin's Alexanderplatz were part of a nationwide series of strikes. At the protest, farmers waved banners demanding protection from Western competition and black flags of mourning to protest what they said was the imminent death of their industry. ``Ending Agriculture with a Clearance Sale,'' read a large green-and-white banner spread high above the crowd, a reference to the slashed prices at which farmers must now sell their goods. Just a few hours before de Maiziere announced his removal, Pollack was pelted with eggs and tomatoes when he tried to speak to the protesting farmers. The protest was the biggest yet among East German farmers, the most militant and hardest-hit section of the country's troubled economy. The economic merger of the two German states on July 1 opened the floodgates to Western competition, and East German grocery stores have been filling their shelves with Western products. The large, Soviet-style collective farms that once had a captive market now are forced to price their products at market levels, and many are unable to meet their formerly subsidized payrolls. Experts say up to half of the collectives, which employ more than 800,000 people, are essentially bankrupt and doomed to fail soon. Up to 70 percent of the market has been lost, economists say. Rainer Prizkow, who works on a pig farm in the city of Neuruppin, said his operation has sold no pork in the last month. ``We won't survive the winter,'' he said. Arno Mittendorf held up a red-and-gold banner awarded to his collective by the former Communist regime two years ago because the farm had the highest production in its district of Neubrandenburg. Mittendorf, an agricultural economist, said production is the same, but little is sold. ``We can only pay our workers through September,'' he said. Experts say up to 4 million of East Germany's 8.8 million workers could lose their jobs as the nation makes the transition to the free market. Almost 1 million workers are either jobless or working shorter hours at lower pay under a West German-financed program to keep workers targeted for layoff on the job. Romberg, a member of the left-leaning Social Democrats who are uneasy coalition partners in de Maiziere's broad-based government, often clashed with the Christian Democrats who dominate the Cabinet. Pohl is a Christian Democrat, and the other two are not aligned with a party. Romberg has been accused of overstating East Germany's economic situation and once predicted that the country would experience a ``hot autumn,'' a reference to unrest prompted by high unemployment expected in the fall.

DOC.HEAD: Two Ex-Prosecutors Plead Guilty in Cocaine Case
DOC.TEXT: Two former state prosecutors pleaded guilty today to cocaine charges in federal court. Richard Guida, who headed the attorney general's criminal division until 1986, pleaded guilty to one count of cocaine distribution. The offense is a felony, punishable by up to 20 years in jail and a $1 million fine. Michael Trant, who was an associate deputy attorney general, pleaded guilty to one count of cocaine possession. He could be sentenced to up to one year in jail and fined $5,000. The pleas were entered before U.S. District Judge Edwin Kosik. Guida and Trant, who served under former state Attorney General LeRoy Zimmerman, waived indictments and pleaded guilty to the charges. Federal prosecutor Gordon Zubrod said in court that Guida provided cocaine to friends on a number of occasions between August 1985 and October 1987. During part of that period, he worked as a state prosecutor. Zubrod said the government found no evidence to show that Guida sold cocaine. Guida's plea is conditional on the outcome of a related appeal. Guida earlier pleaded guilty to the lesser charge of cocaine possession. But that agreement was dissolved at the request of federal prosecutors who accused Guida of withholding information. He appealed. If Guida loses the appeal, today's plea would stand. If he wins, the earlier plea would be reinstated. Both men are to be sentenced later.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Envoy Sent to Middle East; Evacuations From Iraq to Begin
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Wednesday prepared to evacuate its citizens from Iraq and Kuwait and announced it has sent an envoy to the Middle East to help settle the Persian Gulf crisis. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said special ambassador Mikhail Sytenko left Tuesday for consultations with the governments of Syria, Jordan, Egypt and other Arab countries. Sytenko, a former deputy secretary-general of the United Nations, is also expected to visit Baghdad, Gremitskikh said at a regular news briefing. ``This visit goes along with the efforts by the Soviet Union to stop the escalation of tensions in the region and to resolve the crisis caused by Iraq's aggression against Kuwait,'' he said. Gremitskikh said 32 Soviets have managed to leave Iraq by airplane since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. He did not elaborate. Nearly 9,000 Soviets were among the hundreds of thousands of foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, including 193 military advisers to the Iraqi government. Iraq has agreed to allow all 880 Soviets in Kuwait to leave, but only via a 1,200-mile route through Iraq to the Iraq-Jordan border. All Soviet women, children and invalids will be permitted to leave Iraq, but not Soviet men. Officials have not said how many of the Soviets trapped in Iraq are men. Gremitskikh said the first group of 230 evacuees were assembling in the Iraqi capital of Baghdad on Wednesday. Evacuation plans were hampered by intense desert heat and lack of transportation, he said. Iraq will not allow cars with Iraqi license plates to leave the country, he said, so buses have to be rented in Jordan to transport the evacuees. Gremitskikh reiterated that the Soviet military advisers did not advise Iraq's President Saddam Hussain to invade Kuwait. ``Military advisers who participate in planning military operations, we do not have such kind of advisers there. They did not and could not participate in the planning of Iraqi operations,'' he said. He said an unspecified number of Iraqi students were studying at a Moscow military academy. ``Most of them are about to graduate and we will have to see what will become of them.'' Moscow has maintained it prefers a political solution to the crisis over a military solution and has called for an expanded U.N. mediation role. It has refused to consider participating in a multinational force or naval barricade of Iraq unless sanctioned by the United Nations. However, it has sent two warships to the region to protect commercial shipping and has supported an economic embargo by cutting arms supplies to Iraq. ``We do not support any unilateral actions aimed at establishing a sea blockade that some countries are considering now,'' Politburo member Gennady Yanaev told a news conference. ``Any solution by force might provoke unpredictable consequences. We do not want those consequences to occur.'' Yanaev is the Politburo member responsible for international affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Precede SANTA MONICA
Marlon Brando's Son Released on $2 Million Bail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 graf to UPDATE with Christian Brando released from jail. Picks up 4th graf, `Outside the...'
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's son was released today on $2 million bail after 90 days in jail on charges he killed his half-sister's boyfriend. ``It's good to be out,'' said Christian Brando. ``I'm just going to go home and try to straighten this out.'' He was greeted outside the Los Angeles County Jail by his father and brother Miko, as well as girlfriend Lorene Landon Coughlin. ``It's a very special moment, a moment I have long looked forward to,'' said Marlon Brando. ``I'm proud to have my son out of jail.'' The actor had to put up his $5 million estate in the hills above Los Angeles as collateral. Santa Monica Superior Court Judge David Perez approved the arrangement Tuesday. Christian Brando had been jailed since the May 16 slaying at the estate. Outside the courthouse Tuesday, Marlon Brando was asked what he believed was the best he could hope for in a trial. ``The best I could hope for is accidental manslaughter,'' he said. Christian Brando, 32, is accused of shooting to death Dag Drolett, 26, in an argument at the Brando family manor. Cheyenne Brando, the actor's 20-year-old daughter, was pregnant at the time with Drollett's son. She has since returned to Tahiti and given birth. The judge decided Marlon Brando's home may be used to back his son's $2 million bail, which was reduced from $10 million last week. The 66-year-old actor would lose his property if his son jumped bail. Prosecutors vehemently opposed bail for fear Christian Brando would flee the country.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Manufacturing Put Brakes on Overall Industrial Growth in June
DOC.TEXT: Automotive output dropped sharply and stalled overall industrial production in July, the government said Wednesday, although it noted the economy continued its slow growth in most other manufacturing areas. The Federal Reserve said that while overall output was unchanged from June, ``excluding motor vehicles, industrial output rose 0.2 percent last month, about the same rate of growth that has been evident so far this year.'' In another report Wednesday pointing to continued growth, the Commerce Department said business sales were up 1.0 percent in June, while inventories fell 0.4 percent. If inventories were to rise excessively in relation to sales, it could cause production cutbacks and job layoffs as businesses attempted to sell off the backlog. ``It's modest growth,'' Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington forecasting firm, said of both reports. ``Not very exciting, but not recession numbers.'' Nevertheless, Evans and other analysts pointed out the July report preceded the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August and they questioned the impact of the subsequent rise in oil prices on economic growth later this year. While weakness in auto sales has been a major factor contributing to the overall sluggishness of the economy this year, economist Michael P. Niemira of the Mitsubishi Bank in New York said he expects a strong increase in vehicle production this month. ``We're going through an intentional car buildup in the third quarter,'' Niemira said, pointing to a backlog of just 55 days' supply compared to the normal 60-65 day supply. Evans said he thought the auto industry was positioning itself for a possible strike when the Big Three labor contracts expire this fall. The Fed report also cited a falloff in production of stone, clay and glass products as further signs of weakness in the construction industry as well. Overall industrial production has fallen just twice so far this year _ 1.0 percent in January and a slight 0.1 percent in April. But the rates of growth in the other months have been less than 1 percent, including a 0.4 percent gain in June. Production in manufacturing plants making both durable and non-durable goods inched down 0.1 percent in July after a 0.3 percent gain a month earlier. That was even weaker than the 0.5 percent advance first reported. Output of durable goods, motor vehicles and other big-ticket items expected to last at least three years fell 0.4 percent and offset a 0.4 percent advance in June. Manufacturing of non-durable goods such as food and clothing was up 0.3 percent after a 0.2 increase a month earlier. Output at mines jumped 1.0 percent after a flat June, while utility production was off 0.4 percent after a 1.9 percent gain a month earlier. The Fed said its industrial production index in July stood at 109.9 percent of its 1987 base, the same level as the previous month. The Fed also said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities _ which usually move in tandem with industrial production _ slipped 0.2 percentage point to 83.4 percent. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels. The operating rate at factories producing durable goods fell 0.5 percentage point to 81.6 percent, while the rate at plants making non-durable goods was unchanged at 83.9 percent. The operating rate at mines was up 1.1 percentage point to 90.2 percent, while it slipped from 86.2 to 85.7 percent at utilities.

DOC.HEAD: EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is based on a pool dispatch.
Saudi Officers Ready to Fight Fellow Arabs `To The Death'
DOC.TEXT: Saudi military officers said Wednesday they have no qualms about fighting fellow Arabs if Iraqi forces invade their desert kingdom. One pilot declared that if Saddam Hussein ``wants to fight, we will fight to the death.'' Several Saudi pilots, interviewed by U.S. reporters, said they were prepared to defend their nation if the Iraqi president launches an attack. Their squadron commander said his U.S.-trained pilots were so eager to take on the Iraqis that ``we have to put a leash on them. ... We have to put a leash on me,'' Asked about the possibility of fighting fellow Arabs, one pilot said: ``It's not that, it's a matter of pride. We are a nation that is not willing to start a fight but we will fight to protect the sovereignty of our country and we will win.'' Another pilot commented, ``I'm a soldier; when I go to fight, an enemy is an enemy.'' Added a third. ``Nobody likes war, but if he wants to fight, we will fight to the death.'' The pilots were interviewed at a Saudi air base under ground rules that prevent the journalists, flown to Saudi Arabia by the Pentagon, from disclosing the size or location of U.S. and Saudi troop deployments. Only command-level officers may be quoted by name. The base's commander, Brig Gen. Turki Bin Nasser, a member of the Saudi royal family, told the reporters: ``We would not like to see Arabs fighting Arabs, but if we have to we will do it. If anybody wants to come to the kingdom and attack, we will fight to defend ourselves.'' No Arab nation had taken up arms against other Arabs in modern times, until Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The Saudi pilots all spoke English and were all trained in the United States. Before the meeting with Turki, the journalists were allowed into Saudi jet hangars and maintenance facilities that officials said are off-limits to many Saudis. The journalists saw further evidence of the growing U.S. presence, including the first-ever field deployment of the Patriot surface-to-air missile system. Transport planes land day and night, bringing in heavy artillery and other equipment to reinforce American units deployed after Saddam's army overran Kuwait. Turki said that Saudi, American, and British pilots were conducting joint missions but that many command responsibilities have yet to be worked out. ``We hope the higher authorities will solve the problems of command control,'' he said. A squadron commander said the three nations' pilots have been flying as a single force under a single command. ``From the first day they arrived here, that plan had to be implemented before we leave the ground,'' the commander said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney plans to visit Saudi Arabia later this week, presumably to discuss command questions. President Bush committed U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia to protect the kingdom's oil fields, the world's richest, and to back up his call for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. American troops are equipped with masks and special suits to protect themselves against Iraq's formidable supply of chemical and gas weapons. But Turki questioned Saddam's ability to effectively use such weapons. ``As far as we know, he doesn't have means of delivery with ballistic missiles but he has the means if they are carried by aircraft,'' the general said. ``Air to air, I have no problem,'' he added, meaning he believes U.S., Saudi and British air defenses can intercept any Iraqi plans carrying chemical bombs. The Saudi air force is equipped with American F-15s and F-5 fighters, AWACS radar planes and C-130 transports, plus British-made Hawks, Lightnings and Tornadoes. Turki said Saudi Arabia needed help from the United States and other nations simply because of Iraq's huge army. ``If you face a million-man army, you have to have a large enough force to deter it and to fight it if you need to,'' he said. He said the threat of an attack by Iraq remains significant, citing Iraqi defensive positions set up near the Saudi-Kuwaiti border. One Saudi pilot, trained in San Antonio, Texas, called the Iraqi air force quite strong but no match for a joint Saudi-U.S.-British defense. A squadron commander, who said he received his first training in Selma, Ala., said Iraqi plans have been spotted near the border with Kuwait but none has crossed into Saudi airspace. ``I don't think it wise for them to cross the border,'' he said. ``We will react to that. ... I'm confident that we could inflict heavy damage.''

DOC.HEAD: Four Government Ministers Fired; Farmers Protest
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere on Wednesday fired four Cabinet ministers who had dealt closely with the nation's crumbling economy. They included the agriculure chief, who earlier was pelted with eggs by angry farmers. The fired officials were Finance Minister Walter Romberg, Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl, Justice Minister Kurt Wuensche and Agriculture Minister Peter Pollack. Hours before de Maiziere announced the dismissals, Pollack tried to speak to thousands of protesting farmers on East Berlin's main square. He was shouted down with cries of ``Bandit!'' and ``Dog!'' Protesters hurled eggs and tomatoes. During the melee Pollack was hit on the head by a farmer who grabbed a reporter's microphone. He was unhurt, but the rear window of his car was smashed. The fired finance minister is a member of the left-leaning Social Democrats, who are uneasy coalition partners in de Maiziere's broad-based government. He frequently clashed with the Christian Democrats, who dominate the Cabinet. Pohl is a Christian Democrat. The other two fired ministers are not aligned with a party. Romberg has been accused of overstating East Germany's economic woes and once predicted that the country would experience a ``hot autumn,'' a reference to unrest that could be prompted by high unemployment expected in the fall. Farmers have been especially hard-hit by East Germany's shift to a free market after four decades of socialism. On Wednesday, about 50,000 farmers converged on the Alexanderplatz, the sprawling East Berlin square where protests last year helped topple Communist rule. They were among hundreds of thousands of farmers who took part in a series of two-hour strikes, rallies and other protests across the country. The farmers waved black flags to mourn their dying industry and listened to farm leaders demand an economic bailout from both German states, which are expected to unify by year's end. The economic merger of the two German states July 1 opened the floodgates to Western competition, and East German grocery stores have been filling their shelves with Western products. The bloated, Soviet-style collective farms that once had a captive market now are forced to price their products at market levels, and many are unable to meet their formerly subsidized payrolls. Farmers are sitting on thousands of tons of unsold pork, beef, produce and grain. Experts say up to half of the collectives, which employ more than 800,000 people, are essentially bankrupt and doomed to fail soon. Up to 70 percent of the market has been lost, economists say. Rainer Prizkow, who works on a pig farm in the city of Neuruppin, said his operation has sold no pork in the last month. ``We won't survive the winter,'' he said. Arno Mittendorf held up a red-and-gold banner awarded to his collective by the former Communist regime two years ago because the farm had the highest production in its district of Neubrandenburg. Mittendorf, an agricultural economist, said production is the same, but little is sold. ``We can only pay our workers through September,'' he said. Edgar Mueller, president of an association of farm collectives, demanded $2.2 billion to $2.5 billion in aid for this year. Officials in both German states say the inefficient, overstaffed farms must change to model the leaner, privately run operations in the West. Protests also were reported in the cities of Rostock, Dresden, Halle, Gera, Erfurt and Suhl. Several highways were blocked by tractors and other farm equipment. Nationwide, up to 700,000 farmers took part in the two-hour strikes, the East German news agency ADN said. Officials say other sections of the economy will quickly follow the plunging fortunes of the agriculture industry. Experts say up to 4 million of East Germany's 8.8 million workers could lose their jobs as the nation continues its move to a market economy at an unprecedented pace. Almost 1 million workers now are either jobless or working shorter hours at lower pay under a West German-financed program to keep workers targeted for layoff on the job.

DOC.HEAD: Inventories at Best Level Since 1984
DOC.TEXT: A combination of rising business sales and falling stocks on shelves and back lots in June put inventories at their most favorable level in at least six years, the government said Wednesday. ``It's a rather impressive decline'' in inventories, said Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington forecasting firm. ``One of the reasons we start a recession is that inventories get out of line, and there's no evidence of that happening.'' ``It means there's room for more growth if sales hold,'' added Michael P. Niemira, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank in New York, who said the inventory correction that began at the beginning of the year apparently continues. In fact, Niemira said, the decline in inventories combined with strong sales probably means a much better balanced economy in the second quarter than the government first estimated last month. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that sales jumped 1.0 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted $544.4 billion, the same rate of increase as in May. The advances were the strongest since February, when sales rose 1.4 percent, and regained a 1.0 percent decline in April. Inventories, meanwhile, dropped 0.4 percent to a seasonally adjusted $797.3 billion, down $3.1 billion from May when inventories posted a 0.5 percent advance. It was the largest drop since a similar 0.4 percent decline in February. The combination produced a 1.46 ratio of inventories to sales, the lowest ratio since this series began in 1982, a Commerce spokesman said. The ratio means it would take 1.46 months to exhaust the backlog of goods at the June pace. The ratio stood at 1.49 in both April and May. If inventories were to pile up excessively while sales slowed, it could prompt businesses to cut back purchases, resulting in a drop in production and job layoffs. In its initial estimate of second-quarter growth, the Commerce Department reported last month the 1.2 percent gain in the gross national product was due almost entirely to a big buildup in business inventories. Other major components of the economy declined. The initial report on the GNP _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ will be revised twice including the first reexamination on Aug. 24 when the June sales-inventory report is taken into account. Wholesalers showed the biggest sales gain in June, 1.7 percent, while retailers posted a 1.1 percent advance and manufacturers a 0.5 percent increase. Wholesalers had a 0.8 percent decline in inventories, followed by a 0.5 percent drop by manufacturers. Retail inventories, on the other hand, edged up 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll in Black Factional Fighting in South Africa Hits 140
LaserPhoto JOH3
DOC.TEXT: Rival black factions battled Wednesday with axes, spears and other crude weapons, hacking people and burning homes as four days of fighting brought the death toll to at least 140. ``We just keep on finding bodies,'' a police spokesman said. The violence was in three black townships east of Johannesburg. It pits mostly Xhosa supporters of the African National Congress against the conservative Zulu Inkatha movement. The independent South African Press Association said the township fighting was the worst in years. Both groups oppose apartheid, but they are divided by leadership rivalry, tribal loyalty and differing visions of a future South Africa. Police said 140 bodies had been recovered late Tuesday and Wednesday in Thokoza, Katlehong and Vosloorus. Police and hospital officials said hundreds of people were injured. Columns of armored vehicles and trucks filled with police bearing assault rifles and shotguns roamed the stricken areas Wednesday in a show of force. Armed bands of Zulus attacked several shantytowns Tuesday night and early Wednesday. The bands set fire to houses and attacked fleeing residents with spears, knives and pangas _ a crude machete-like weapon. One resident, who did not want to be named, said he saw ``more than 2,000'' Zulus with guns, spears, butcher's knives and axes attack a squatter camp in Katlehong. ``I saw mothers with babies on their backs running past my house. ... I didn't know what was happening and then I saw the Zulus,'' he said. Witnesses said the Zulus searched houses, hunting out and attacking Xhosa residents. Some residents tried to flee to a nearby swamp but were chased down and hacked to death. Others died when their houses were set afire. Police used tear-gas barrages and shotguns later Wednesday to drive back several hundred armed Inkatha supporters who tried to attack the squatter camp a second time, witnesses said. Hundreds of residents gathered for safety in large groups with the remains of their possessions after their attack. The South African Red Cross said it was trying to set up refugee camps to house them. Police spokesman Capt. Eugue Opperman said a policeman sustained shrapnel wounds Wednesday after a hand grenade was hurled by an unidentified man. He said police had been fired on several occasions. Police seized hundreds of knives, spears and other weapons and reported finding a chest containing AK-47 assault rifles and grenades. A large police truck piled with confiscated weapons was seen leaving Katlehong. The South African Press Association reported Wednesday the army had been called in to assist police, but no troops were seen. South African Defense Force spokesman Riaan Louw confirmed police had requested army help, but gave no details. The fighting started Sunday after a minor clash, but as of Tuesday police said only nine people had been killed. Violence increased after peace talks failed Tuesday. The battles between the ANC and Inkatha began spilling into the townships around Johannesburg in recent weeks. Previously it had occurred mainly in Natal province. The government cited the violence when it left in effect a state of emergency in Natal province. The emergency measures were lifted elsewhere in the country in June, including Johannesburg.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's son was freed on $2 million bail Wednesday after 90 days in jail on charges he killed his sister's boyfriend. ``It's good to be out,'' said Christian Brando, 32. ``I'm just going to go home and try to straighten this out.'' He was greeted outside the Los Angeles County Jail by his father and brother Miko, as well as girlfriend Lorene Landon Coughlin. ``It's a very special moment, a moment I have long looked forward to,'' said Marlon Brando. ``I'm proud to have my son out of jail.'' The actor put up his $5 million estate in the hills above Los Angeles as collateral for the bail, which was reduced from $10 million. Christian Brando pleaded innocent to murdering Dag Drolett, 26, at the Brando estate May 16. He had been jailed since the shooting. After the shooting, Brando's daughter, Cheyenne, 20, gave birth to Drolett's son in Tahiti, where she reportedly remains. Outside the courthouse Wednesday, Marlon Brando said ``the best I could hope for is accidental manslaughter'' at his son's trial. Christian Brando is the son of the actor and his first wife, Anna Kashfi. The couple divorced in 1960.

Actress Glenn Close missed a press conference because she was losing her voice, but was back on the set Wednesday of the television movie ``Sarah, Plain and Tall.'' Close, who is also executive producer of the Hallmark Hall of Fame show, bowed out of a press briefing Tuesday night because she'd been up since 6 a.m. and was losing her voice, said Russ Patrick, a Hallmark spokesman. Miss Close was back on the set at the Stuhr Museum on Wednesday, said Lew Cole, the museum's public relations director. The museum's Railroad Town became Hays, Kan., circa 1910, this week when Miss Close and actor Christopher Walken arrived to film portions of the movie, which will air on CBS this winter. Miss Close has been nominated for an Academy Award five times. Her films include ``Fatal Attraction,'' ``Dangerous Liaisons,'' and ``The Big Chill.'' Walken starred in ``The Deer Hunter.''

Princess Anne, daughter of Queen Elizabeth II, quietly celebrated her 40th birthday Wednesday with her children. Anne, who is separated from her husband, Mark Phillips, spent the day with son Peter, 12, and daughter Zara, 9, at Gatcombe Park, their estate in western England, said a Buckingham Palace spokesman. The princess was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize last week for her work for poor children around the world.

Bert Parks has buried the hatchet with the Miss America Pageant and will sing at the contest's 70th anniversary show this year. Parks, 75, will sing ``There She Is,'' the theme song he made famous, to a parade of former Miss Americas. Parks was fired in January 1980 after hosting the Miss America Pageant for 25 years. Then-pageant director Albert Marks Jr., who died last year, said Parks was too old at age 65 to continue. During the anniversary show, the new Miss America will be serenaded by Gary Collins, who will remain the pageant co-host with Phyllis George. Parks said he was ``not crazy about that'' and that the decision to have Collins sing was made for ``contractual reasons.'' Parks appeared at a news conference with Dorothy Benham, Miss America 1977, and Leonard Horn, chief executive officer at the Miss America Organization. They symbolically buried a hatchet in a cake that read, ``Welcome back Bert. Miss America Pageant 1990.'' It hasn't been decided whether Parks will appear at later pageants, Horn said.

Princess Diana's official visit to Pakistan next month has been postponed, Buckingham Palace said Wednesday. Former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto had invited Diana, but last week Pakistan's President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed Bhutto and declared a state of emergency. The Sept. 17-20 trip would have been Diana's first solo journey to a British Commonwealth country. It was canceled by mutual agreement, said a palace spokesman, who added that the princess was ``naturally disappointed.'' Diana, 29, is married to Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says New Guidelines for Americans Being Prepared
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi authorities have told U.S. envoys that ``new guidelines'' are being prepared governing travel rights of the estimated 3,000 Americans stranded in Kuwait and Iraq, the State Department said Wednesday. Privately, U.S. officials said they doubted that the rule changes would permit the Americans to leave. Besides the Americans, more than 2 million other foreigners have been detained within the borders of the two countries since the Iraqi invasion two weeks ago. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said an Iraqi Foreign Ministry official informed a U.S. diplomat in Baghdad on Tuesday that the new guidelines would be issued. ``We are waiting right now,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. She continued to refuse to describe the Americans as hostages and she dismissed as ``pure semantics'' an Iraqi official's description of the Americans as ``restrictees.'' ``Whatever terms the Iraqis use, it doesn't change the facts. We have been telling you for days these people are restricted from leaving,'' she said. ``There is no secret about this. The world knows it. Finally, they are admitting behavior that is contrary to all international norms.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater attached no significance to the Iraqi official's use of the word ``restrictees.'' ``That's not an official description and not what the government has told us,'' said Fitzwater, who spoke to reporters while flying with President Bush back to Kennebunkport, Maine. The Iraqi official told ABC News on Tuesday the Americans would not be allowed to leave Kuwait and Iraq until the current crisis ends. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Sadiq Mashat, has said the Americans will be allowed to leave ``in due time.'' Ms. Tutwiler said Iraqi officials have been giving contradictory information about the status of the Americans. She said the administration has been avoiding the term ``hostage'' because the Iraqis have made no demands for their release and they are not ``bound and gagged.'' Iraqi authorities have closed airports and borders to most foreigners since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Ten Americans connected to the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad were allowed to leave last Saturday and another group was expected to be allowed out soon. About 500 Americans are estimated to have slipped out of Kuwait, circumventing the Iraqi travel ban. The State Department has been discouraging Americans from trying to leave since a British citizen was shot to death during an escape attempt last weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Khamenei Denounces U.S. Forces in the Region
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran's spiritual leader Wednesday called the stationing of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia an ``insult to the Moslem people of that country,'' Tehran radio reported. Speaking at a religious gathering in Tehran, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the United States was using Iraq's invasion of Kuwait as a pretext to strengthen its military presence in the region. Lashing out at Saudi Arabia for inviting the U.S. forces, Khamenei said ``those governments which invited the U.S. forces to their countries are devoid of grassroots support, and do not command the backing of their peoples. ``This is the reason they are unable to defend themselves,'' he added. He said the U.S. military presence in Saudi Arabia was an ``insult to the Moslem people of that country.'' ``They will have to pay a dear price for the bullying, U.S. military forces,'' he said. Khamenei also condemned the West and Arab countries that backed Iraq in its eight-year war against Iran, and said: ``Global arrogance and reactionary regimes of the region maintained an inhumane silence during the eight-year incursion against Iran.'' Iran often refers to the United States and the West as ``global arrogance.'' Khamenei made his comments before Iraq offered to seek a formal peace treaty to end the Iran-Iraq war, according to the Islamic Republic News Agency. Some analysts fear that anti-American radicals in Iran will pressure the government to back Iraq in the current gulf crisis to help force the U.S. military out of the region. Iranian officials have criticized Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, but have also denounced the dispatch of foreign forces to the region. Kuwait and Saudi Arabia were Baghdad's largest financial backers during the Iran-Iraq war, extending an estimated $30 billion to Iraq in loans for its war efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Considering First Call-Up of `Weekend Warriors' in 20 Years
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is considering the first call-up in more than 20 years of the nation's ``weekend warriors,'' the reservists the Pentagon has come to rely on to back up its fulltime military men and women. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney discussed the reserves question with Bush in a private meeting at the Pentagon Wednesday, but the defense secretary has not decided on a recommendation, said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary. The issue is politically sensitive because of the public perception that a reserve mobilization is tantamount to a declaration that the nation is on a war footing. More than 20,000 active-duty U.S. ground forces already are in Saudi Arabia as part of Operation Desert Shield to help deter an Iraqi attack on the desert kingdom. The Pentagon has contingency plans to deploy as many as 250,000 troops. Some reservists called to active duty would be deployed to U.S. military installations and ports to help with the transportation of troops and equipment to Saudi Arabia, while others would make the 7,000-mile trip as part of the U.S. combat force. The president has the authority to activate as many as 200,000 reservists for 90 days. He can extend the period an additional 90 days without declaring a national emergency. Reservists perform a wide range of combat roles on the ground, at sea and in the air. Military officials said the U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia will be seriously hobbled if at least some of the nation's 1.2 million Army, Navy and Air Force reservists are not mobilized. The last time that reserves were ordered to active duty was in 1968, when President Johnson called up 35,280 reserves after the start of the Tet offensive in Vietnam and the seizure by North Korea of the surveillance ship Pueblo. Those reserves served on active duty from January 1968 to December 1969. Most reservists train for one weekend a month, in addition to a two-week training session each year. Some work fulltime with active-duty units as civilians but also perform their reserve training. Others are not obligated to train at all. Some military officials said they foresaw at least a partial mobilization of reservists, although a Pentagon spokesman, Maj. Doug Hart, said no decision had been made. The services have come to depend on reserve forces for a wide variety of military missions. The Army, for example, relies on reservists to fill 80 percent of its combat service support units, including medical specialists and engineers. Its armored divisions typically include two brigades of active-duty soldiers and one brigade of reservists. ``The U.S. Army cannot sustain a major deployment, except with great difficulty, without them,'' said one Army strategist who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
