Reservists served voluntarily during the U.S. invasion of Panama last December, and others volunteered for minesweeping operations when the United States began escorting Kuwaiti oil tankers in the Persian Gulf starting in 1987. About 1,000 members of National Guard units already have participated in the Saudi Arabian deployment as volunteers. No guard or reserve units have been ordered to active duty, Hart said. The largest contingent of reserve forces is the Army National Guard, with 457,000 members, according to Pentagon figures. There are 319,000 members in the Army Reserve, 151,000 in the Navy Reserve, 116,000 in the Air National Guard, 83,000 in the Air Force Reserve and 43,000 in the Marine Corps Reserve. In addition to those nearly 1.2 million reservists, the services have 460,000 people in the Individual Ready Reserve and the Inactive National Guard. These are former active-duty personnel who could be called on in a national emergency but are not trained as extensively. Reservists are most often called on to assist in natural disasters. For example, Air Force Reserve C-130 Hercules transport planes from the 913th Tactical Airlift Group in Pennsylvania flew relief missions after the San Francisco earthquake last October.

DOC.HEAD: Higher Production May Bring Some Price Relief
DOC.TEXT: Consumers will see some relief from record meat prices as production increases next year, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Retail pork prices are expected to decline 1 percent to 3 percent in 1991 from this year's record level, the department's Economic Research Service said. Poultry prices may be down 4 percent to 6 percent. The 1991 forecast was based on indications that farmers will boost livestock production in response to favorable returns this year. However, beef production is not expanding enough to keep up with population growth, so further price increases can be expected next year. But the report said 1991 retail beef prices may rise only 1 percent to 2 percent. In 1990, the report said, retail pork prices are expected to climb an average of 12 percent from last year. Overall, 1990 poultry prices, which include broilers and turkeys, were forecast to drop 2 percent as production rises this year. Analysts said per capita consumption of red meat and poultry may rise about six pounds in 1991 from the record level of about 220 pounds annually in 1990 and 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Europe Unites on Sanctions, Divides Over Military Response
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Europe remains united on economic sanctions against Iraq but divided over the U.S.-led military response to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. There has been a notable lack of enthusiasm in Europe for joining the U.S.-led multinational force to defend Saudi Arabia. Only Britain and The Netherlands have committed troops. Support for the sanctions, meanwhile, is virtually unanimous and is the first major issue on which Eastern Europe and Western Europe have been united. Geographically, Europe is a strategic link in the military operation, but there are worries about how severely that link may be tested in coming days. Spain, Portugal, Italy, Germany and Greece have given the United States access to some bases to use for the Persian Gulf operation. That contrasts with the situation in April 1986, when only Britain allowed U.S. planes to use bases for the bombing of Libya. Denmark is permitting its merchant ships in the gulf to act as supply vessels for the multinational force. But Italy, Belgium and Spain, while preparing or sending warships to the eastern Mediterranean, are waiting at least until Tuesday's Paris meeting of the nine-nation West European Union before making any commitment to the multinational effort. Belgium said it wants the union, the main European pillar of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, to assume a more active role in coordinating a European contribution. Italy, president of the 12-nation European Community, ``cannot remain in the rear guard,'' commentator Antonio Maccanico wrote in a page-one opinion piece in Il Messaggero, the Rome-based national daily. Germany, in a unique position because its constitution bars the military from operating outside NATO territory, remains split over sending ships to the gulf. Chancellor Helmut Kohl was quoted as saying West German minesweepers would join a European naval group sent to the gulf, but Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher remains opposed on constitutional grounds. Some Greeks, including former Premier Andreas Papandreou, have expressed fears of retaliation if they go beyond the letter of the U.N. Security Council resolution barring trade with Iraq. Francis Tusa, European editor of Armed Forces Journal International, said there has been some serious concern in Europe that ``the Americans are going in feet first, gung ho.'' In their drive to put teeth into the sanctions, the United States and Britain have declared their navies are ready to prevent ships from carrying goods to and from Iraq. Australia has said its ships are ready to do the same. ``We are determined not to see sanctions busted,'' Sir Crispin Tickell, Britain's ambassador to the United Nations, said Wednesday. But France and the Soviet Union, formerly Iraq's main arms suppliers, have said the U.N. Security Council must decide when any interdiction takes place. Both have sent sizable naval forces but refuse to participate in any barricade without U.N. authorization. Gennady Yanaev, the Politburo member responsible for international affairs for the Soviet Communist Party, told a Moscow news conference Wednesday that economic sanctions should be given time. ``I emphasize, any solution by force might provoke unpredictable consequences,'' he said. ``We believe that common sense will triumph without any military force.'' The Independent, a leading British daily, said a U.S. barricade not authorized by the U.N. ``would risk breaking ... the broad coalition that made the embargo possible and thus jeopardize the embargo itself.'' But The Daily Telegraph, a conservative newspaper, said unless goods are stopped and sanctions enforced, they are worthless. ``If that can be done under a U.N. mandate, so much the better. If not, then we should accept the necessity for the American, British and Australian navies to do the job on their own,'' the Telegraph said.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Company Puts Iraqi President on Bull's-Eye Poster
LaserPhoto CX13
DOC.TEXT: When Iraqi's Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, he let comedian Roseanne Barr off the hook. A Chicago entrepreneur had planned to produce a poster of Ms. Barr, with a bull's eye superimposed on it, after she shrieked the national anthem at a baseball game, offending Americans all the way up to President Bush. But Saddam has outraged even more people, and Mike McCormack put the Barr poster on a back burner to print up 40,000 Saddam targets. ``The poster allows Americans to relieve a lot of frustration,'' said McCormack, president of ACBA Co., producer of the poster. ``It's designed for people using darts or at rifle ranges.'' ``We're not advocating any form of violence, just emotional release,'' he said. McCormack plans to begin production this week on the first batch of the 17-by-22-inch posters of Saddam, complete with a two-ring bull's eye. The posters will be available at poster shops and rifle stores nationwide on Aug. 20, McCormack said. He said the $4.50 poster also will be sold in Europe. Americans detained in the Middle East will receive Saddam posters when they return home, McCormack said. His company produced and sold about 1.5 million similar posters of the late Iranian leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, during the Iranian hostage crisis, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Support Group Assists Families of Absent Airman
DOC.TEXT: In a small office off Forbes Field, volunteers answer telephone calls around-the-clock for relatives of airmen who have gone on active duty with the Kansas Air National Guard because of the Mideast crisis. Sometimes the callers want to know whether fighting has broken out. Sometimes they want to know things like how to unplug a stopped-up sink. ``Whatever arises, we'll find a cure for it,'' said a volunteer named Vicki, whose husband has gone on active duty. Members of the support group have decided not to give their last names for the time being. ``I've had calls from family members who are very distressed about the situation,'' said Captain D. L. Mitchell, chaplain for the 190th Air Refueling Group, a unit of state guard. ``We have a barrage of calls after each presidential announcement.'' Last week, Gov. Mike Hayden approved a Department of Defense request allowing 500 members of the unit to go on active duty after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The unit has 955 members, including about 300 people who are full time. On Saturday, three of the unit's KC-135 aerial tankers left Forbes Field, reportedly for Saudi Arabia, although National Guard officials declined to comment. The tankers refuel jet fighters and bombers while aloft. Most National Guard airmen serve one weekend a month and two weeks during the summer. The prospect of going on active duty during a national crisis doesn't occur to many people when they sign up, Mitchell said. Many left spouses, children and jobs behind them. Mitchell acknowledges that some wives are a bit dazed by the developments, telling him: ``I was not ready for this.'' Frequently, he invites them to join the family support group as volunteers, so they feel like they are part of the effort. ``We have more help than we can use, but we use all the help we get,'' said Vicki. Capt. John Andrews, family support coordinator for the Kansas National Guard, said he receives many questions about benefits and insurance. In some cases, wives of airmen who have gone on active duty might not have paid the bills and need advice on how to do it, he said. Members of the 190th come to Topeka from all over Kansas and the surrounding states, including one person from Colorado Springs, Colo., Mitchell said.

DOC.HEAD: Party Official Appeals for Halt to Attacks on Lenin Statues
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party's top ideologist appealed to the nation Wednesday to stop a series of attacks on statues of Vladimir Lenin, the founder of the Soviet Union. Politburo member and party ideology chief Alexander S. Dzasokhov told viewers of the nightly television news program ``Vremya'' that the party's secretariat held a ``very serious and worried discussion'' Wednesday on the various assaults on Lenin monuments. In recent weeks, monuments to Lenin have been destroyed in dozens of towns in the republic of Georgia; vandals have disfigured statues from the Baltic Sea to the Pacific; and authorities in the republics of Latvia, Lithuania, Georgia, Moldavia and the Ukraine have acted to dismantle them by legislative means. This week's edition of Moscow News reported that in the town of Petro-Pavlovsk-Kamchatsky, in the Soviet Far East, a statue to Lenin was defiled by someone who scrawled the word ``hangman'' on it in white paint. City Police Chief Ivan Dankulinets said the local prosecutor's office and KGB is investigating, but no one has been arrested. Despite the changes that have taken place under Mikhail S. Gorbachev with previous leaders such as Josef Stalin and Leonid I. Brezhnev being officially denounced, Lenin remains a sacred, almost grandfatherly figure to many Soviet citizens. ``There has been a stream of telegrams and messages from Soviet citizens censuring the defilement of monuments to the founder of our state, and they have called for urgent measures to stop it,'' Dzasokhov said. He compared the attacks on Lenin statues to the destruction of temples and churches ``during the tragic years of the 1930s'' under Stalin. Dzasokhov said the party secretariat would push for legislation to protect the statues as cultural and historic monuments. The secretariat also called on the Foreign Ministry and the Ministry of Culture to hold talks with authorities in Eastern European nations to obtain guarantees that monuments, memorial plaques and museums connected to Soviet history in those countries will be adequately protected, the Tass news agency reported. As Communists have lost power across Eastern Europe the past two years, statues to Soviet figures such as Lenin have been removed _ sometimes with decorum and sometimes with disrespect. Dzasokhov singled out for criticism those local authorities in Soviet republics who have decided to dismantle the monuments through legislation. Tass reported the party secretariat noted that city councils in the Lithuanian city of Kaunas, as well as the Ukrainian cities of Ternopol and Chervonograd had ordered that Lenin statues be taken down, ``thereby demonstrating disrespect not only for the Soviet state founder but also for history itself.'' Last month, the Ternopol City Council voted 64-0, with 21 abstentions, to remove the statues of Lenin and Karl Marx, the father of modern communism, by Sept. 21, in time for the city's 450th anniversary. The city reportedly is seeking to sell the statues. The Moscow City Council, now headed by radical reformers, voted this summer to remove a huge bust of Lenin from its chambers. Dzasokhov said that in the past, ``there were people trying to debunk Lenin in intellectual ways and in fanatical ways.'' He urged public and cultural figures to fight these ``fallacious actions.'' ``Lenin's name is alive and will stay alive,'' Dzasokhov concluded, ``and Lenin's doctrine is dynamic and not a static one.''

DOC.HEAD: Watkins Says Conservation, Higher Output Could Replace Most Oil Losses
With AM-US-Gulf Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins outlined oil production and conservation proposals Wednesday that he said by yearend could replace up to 90 percent of the supplies lost because of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Half the saving would come only if Americans accept conservation efforts that, for example, would require them to keep tires properly inflated and drive at the speed limit or less. The other half, achieved by stepping up domestic oil production, could require some compromises on the environment. ``This is what we should be doing at home to minimize the disruption that is taking place,'' Watkins told reporters. Watkins said there is no indication that President Bush is considering relaxing rules on offshore drilling because of the Mideast crisis. The secretary said the government continues to consider whether the nation's 587 million-barrel Strategic Petroleum Reserve should be tapped because of the disruption of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Watkins said his proposals should not be taken to mean that the United States is expecting oil shortages the rest of the year. The world has ample oil on hand, he said, even though the market is being denied 4.2 million barrels each day because of Iraq's takeover of Kuwait and the resulting international boycott of both countries' oil. The world price of oil has risen significantly since the Aug. 2 invasion and is hovering about $26 a barrel. ``Nobody believes it's going to drop precipitously,'' Watkins said. Before the invasion, the United States was importing between 600,000 and 700,000 42-gallon barrels per day from Iraq and Kuwait, or about 4 percent of total U.S. oil consumption. The list of proposals outlined by Watkins would, by the end of the year, replace up to 550,000 barrels of that, he estimated. But a lot of things would have to happen before those savings were realized. Here are items on Watkins' list: _Boost production from Alaska's North Slope, now 1.8 million barrels daily, by 50,000 barrels. That could be done within 90 days, Watkins said. _The department would attempt to mediate a long-running dispute over whether oil from the offshore Point Arguello fields in California should be transported to refinery via pipeline or ship. Chevron Oil and Santa Barbara County authorities welcome mediation, Watkins said. If successful, it could produce an extra 75,000 barrels a day within six months. _Encourage utilities to switch from oil to other fuels, even those that are more expensive, saving 100,000 barrels a day. This could require relaxed environmental regulations. _Boost production of Naval Petroleum Reserve fields, mainly Elk Hills, Calif., by 5,000 barrels a day by October. _Ask state regulators to be more flexible in setting ``allowables'' _ determining who may extract oil from what fields and in what quantities. This could raise 30,000 barrels a day by yearend. _Operate ethanol-producing facilities, now running at 80 percent of capacity, at full speed, resulting in production of more gasohol and saving 10,000 barrels of oil per day. The secretary's conservation proposals are far more tentative. Nevertheless, he said, ``We must begin to get Americans, without changing their lifestyles, to begin reducing consumption.'' Watkins estimated: _Operating automobiles at proper tire pressure would save 100,000 barrels of oil a day because of improved gas mileage. He said the department plans a campaign to have service stations make the point to customers. _Driving at the posted speed limit or slower would save 50,000 barrels daily. _Another 40,000 barrels daily would be saved if only 20 percent of families with two cars used the more efficient vehicle. Over half of U.S. households have two or more cars. _Increased use of carpools would save 90,000 barrels a day.

DOC.HEAD: Unwed Births Climb to One in Four
DOC.TEXT: One of every four births in the United States in 1988 was to an unwed mother, the government said Wednesday. The 1 million births to unmarried women was an 8 percent increase over the previous year. The report, by the Department of Health and Human Services, said that while the rates for children born out of wedlock were highest among black women, the rates have been rising faster for white mothers. The statistics also saw a rise in births to young teen-agers for the second straight year, after declining through much of the 1970s and 1980s. There were 33.8 births per 1,000 population to teen-agers ages 15 to 17. HHS said the largest annual increase for any age group was to women ages 40 to 44, up 9 percent from 1987 and 20 percent over 1985. Birth rates for women in their 30s have risen more than 40 percent since 1975. Nearly two in three births to unwed mothers was among blacks and it was one in three for Hispanics. For whites the proportion was nearly one out of five. The overall average was one in four. ``The highest levels of births to unmarried mothers continued to be among women ages 18 to 24,'' HHS said. Since unmarried mothers are much less likely than married mothers to begin prenatal care early, the proportion of women beginning such care in the first trimester showed no improvement through the 1980s and remains at 76 percent, HHS said. The percentage was particularly low among black and Hispanic women.

DOC.HEAD: Prisoners' Good Works Earn Warm Welcome
DOC.TEXT: After four months of patching streets, sweeping gutters and mowing lawns, inmates at a National Guard armory have repaired something even bigger: their image. County Sheriff Michael Ashe said Wednesday he's not surprised that Holyoke, which greeted the surplus prisoners from nearby Springfield with trepidation and a lawsuit, has been won over by good behavior. ``I'm just pleased that things are going well,'' said the mild-mannered lawman. He catapulted into national news in February when he solved his overcrowding problems by commandeering an armory in Springfield and refusing to budge until suitable quarters were found for his inmates. Ashe and state officials compromised by moving the prisoners 10 miles to a vacant National Guard armory in this western Massachusettes town. The agreement was met with horror by Holyoke residents, who feared the inmates would upset the neighborhood and could pose a problem for a preschool center across the street. But those fears haven't materialized, said Mary E. Kates, director of Holyoke's library, a few blocks from the armory. ``I was a little apprehensive, especially when I heard it was being located so close to the Early Childhood Learning Center,'' said Kates. Now, she is full of praise for her new neighbors. ``They sweep the curb and get rid of that and then they've been sweeping our walks, picking up any trash that's been disposed of in the park and they've been edging and removing weeds,'' she said. ``I've got loads of projects.'' The saga began Feb. 16 when Ashe dug up a 17th-century statute allowing sheriffs to demand aid and assistance and marched into a National Guard armory in Springfield, the main city in Hampden County. Stunned guard officials watched as the sheriff installed about a dozen prisoners. State officials eventually decided that Ashe was justified in taking extraordinary measures. Ashe's century-old jail was built to hold 279 inmates, is under federal orders to hold no more than 500 and had a waiting list at the time of the seizure. When the compromise was reached, angry Holyoke officials filed a lawsuit trying to block the transfer, but Ashe prevailed, moving in quietly in April. Holyoke Mayor Martin Dunn said Wednesday he's still not thrilled with the location of the temporary jail, scheduled to be used until a new, permanent jail is built in the county. But he said he's dropped the lawsuit and intends to keep using the inmates for such projects as park renovation. ``We've had them cleaning city lots, filling potholes,'' he said. ``Basically it's been going very well. It's been a productive experience.'' Ashe, who has a master's degree in social work, has won accolades for his innovative jail and community programs, including his pre-release program and a jail garden project teaming inmates and senior citizens. Inmates sent to the Holyoke center are those who are close to the end of their sentences and are serving for minor offences. From the beginning, Ashe called the Holyoke armory a ``Community Service Center,'' and assured residents the inmates would bring nothing but good to their neighborhood.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Calls For Tighter Control Of Government-Backed Enterprises
DOC.TEXT: Closer federal supervision is needed to avoid a savings-and-loan style crisis among government-sponsored enterprises providing low-cost loans to home buyers, farmers and students, congressional auditors said Wednesday. ``The government has little ability to identify, prevent or contain the effects of the kinds of problems that have led to taxpayer losses in the past,'' the General Accounting Office said in a report. The GAO, as required by last year's S&L bailout bill, examined the potential for a similar crisis among eight so-called government-sponsored enterprises, with collective obligations of more than $800 billion. It said closer government oversight was needed of three of the biggest: Sallie Mae, which finances four of every 10 college loans, and Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which together finance about one fourth of the nation's home mortgages. The enterprises were created by Congress but earn profits for private stockholders. They are more formally known, respectively, as the Student Loan Marketing Association, the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. While there is no evidence that any of the enterprises are in danger of immediate failure, the GAO said they have many of the same unhealthy incentives that existed in the thrift industry. They are not explicitly guaranteed by the government, but most private investors assume Congress and the administration would not stand idly by were one to near failure. ``It seems clear that ... the federal ties cause investors to behave like insured depositors who believe their investments to be very safe,'' the report said. In fact, Congress in 1987 approved $4 billion in government-guaranteed bonds to prop up the Farm Credit Banks and the Banks for Cooperatives, which finance agriculture. Because of the perception of government backing for the enterprises, it is easy for them to raise money even when they are ailing, the GAO said. ``The enterprises can continue to borrow money in private markets even when performing poorly,'' the GAO said. ``In financially troubled times, after capital is depleted, owners and managers may have incentives to take unusual risks in a last-ditch effort to recover,'' it said. The GAO recommended that private investors in the enterprises be required to put up more of their own money, or capital, to insulate taxpayers from risk and provide an incentive against reckless behavior. And the risk-taking and capital levels of Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and Sallie Mae need closer government supervision, it said. No agency oversees Sallie Mae, while the Department of Housing and Urban Development oversees Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The auditors expressed skepticism that HUD, whose mission is to provide Americans with affordable housing, could properly ensure the safety of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. ``The department has not provided the kind of safety and soundness supervisory controls normally imposed by banking regulators,'' the GAO said. ``The government cannot depend on the department to reconcile its role as a safety and soundness regulator with its role as a promoter of housing,'' it said. Other enterprises included in the report were the Federal Home Loan Banks, which provide money for home mortgages; the College Construction Loan Insurance Association, which supports construction on college campuses, and the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corp., which supports farming. The GAO's findings are similar to the conclusions in a Treasury Department study issued in May. In that report, the Bush Administration backed a controversial proposal to require government-sponsored enterprises to meet the standards applied by independent credit-rating agencies to the healthiest private corporations with triple-A ratings. The GAO said it would present more specific recommendations when it issues a second report, due next May. Wednesday's report was issued three months late.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Dispatches First Workers to Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The American Red Cross is sending 12 workers to the Persian Gulf to help U.S. forces keep contacts with their families, the Red Cross said Wednesday. Spokeswoman Diane Powers said one Red Cross volunteer arrived in the gulf Tuesday and four others will depart with a Marine unit Thursday. The remaining seven will be assigned to U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf soon, she said. Their main function will be helping military personnel reach their families in emergency situations. The workers will staff a 24-hour electronic emergency communications system linking service personnel with more than 2,700 Red Cross chapters in the United States, Ms. Powers said. The Red Cross also will provide emergency financial assistance for troops sent to the gulf to defend Saudi Arabia and other countries in the region following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The Red Cross workers are traveling to the Mideast at the request of the Defense Department.

DOC.HEAD: Restoration of Soviet Citizenship May Include Solzhenitsyn, Brodsky
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 5th `Solzhenitsyn, who' to UPDATE with comment from Solzhenitsyn's wife; pickup graf 6 pvs, `The brief...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY30
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Wednesday restored the citizenship of an undetermined number of exiles, and among those reported on the list were Nobel Prize-winning authors Joseph Brodsky and Alexander Solzhenitsyn. In his second major human rights decree in three days, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ``canceled the decrees on citizenship concerning a number of persons who are now living abroad,'' the official news agency Tass reported. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said the order ``concerns a rather large number of people. Some names were mentioned _ Brodsky, Solzhenitsyn.'' ``I just heard that ostensibly Mr. Solzhenitsyn got back his Soviet citizenship, but I don't know for sure,'' Gremitskikh said. In a statement issued in her husband's name from their home in Cavendish, Vt., Natalia Solzhenitsyn said: ``In Solzhenitsyn's case, the original decree was not only a deprivation of citizenship, but before that a forced eviction from the U.S.S.R. that was accomplished through arrest and the accusation of treason. Since nothing has been said about that in today's resolution, it does not apply to Solzhenitsyn.'' Brodsky, who lives in New York, were not immediately available for comment. The brief Tass report said the order dealt with ``injustices that occurred between 1966 and 1988,'' but did not say if it affected everyone whose citizenship was revoked then. Nor did it name anyone. Gremitskikh said he did not know the number of people affected but that it was not in the thousands. Tass later reported that those people whose citizenship was being restored would be informed by the Foreign Ministry. Solzhenitsyn is the author of ``The Gulag Archipelago,'' which depicted the horrors of dictator Josef Stalin's prison camps. He was charged with treason in 1974, stripped of his citizenship and expelled. Brodsky, a poet and essayist, was forced to emigrate in 1972 under threat of imprisonment for his political comments. Publication of works by both Solzhenitsyn and Brodsky was barred for years in the Soviet Union, but the restrictions were gradually lifted under the reform policies pushed by Gorbachev, who came to power in March 1985. On Monday, Gorbachev issued a decree restoring the rights of all victims of Stalin's repressions, saying thousands of innocent people still bore ``a stain of injustice.'' Gorbachev said he took the action because ``our society ... has chosen the path of moral revival, democracy, and legality.'' A 1989 Soviet high school history textbook says 40 million people were ``repressed,'' a word used to cover death, imprisonment, exile and other punishments. Under Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet government revoked the citizenship of prominent authors and artists who spoke out against domestic repression. However, Gorbachev has restored the citizenship of such notables as cellist and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich and his wife, singer Galina Vishnevskaya. Rostropovich, who has conducted the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, D.C. for 13 years, returned to Moscow in February for a triumphant concert. He promptly held a press conference to call for the government to drop treason charges against Solzhenitsyn and apologize. Wednesday's announcement said nothing about the treason charges against Solzhenitsyn. Other exiled cultural figures have returned for visits in recent years under Gorbachev, although most have stayed in the West. One exception was theater director Yuri Lyubimov, who has resumed his job as director of Moscow's Taganka Theater. Solzhenitsyn won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1970. Government pressure on him increased after that, and in February 1974 he was arrested on the treason charge, which carried a possible death sentence. He was put on a plane to West Germany and stripped of his citizenship. Solzhenitsyn's opus, ``The Gulag Archipelago,'' was published in the Soviet Union last year. Other well-known works include ``One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich'' and ``Cancer Ward.'' Brodsky was forced to emigrate in June 1972 after secret police gave him a choice to leave or ``face the consequences.'' He understood the threat to mean he might face another prison term if he stayed. Brodsky left behind an eloquent appeal to Brezhnev, who was then Soviet leader, that he be permitted to return home one day. ``Although I am losing my Soviet citizenship, I do not cease to be a Russian poet. I belong to Russian culture, I feel part of it. ``I feel bitter as I leave Russia, I was born, raised and have lived here and I owe everything I have in the world to Russia,'' he said. He was sentenced to five years in a labor camp in 1964 after being convicted in 1964 of ``parasitism,'' but released after 18 months. Parasitism was considered the crime of not holding a job. Many dissidents were fired, barred from working and then found guilty of parasitism. Brodsky moved to New York and became an American citizen. Only a few of his works were published in the Soviet Union until the literary monthly Novy Mir printed a selection after he won the 1987 Nobel Prize for Literature. Moscow News reported Wednesday that a book of Brodsky's poetry is being published for the first time in the Soviet Union. The Northwest publishing house in Leningrad plans 100,000 copies of the book, ``The Autumn Cry of the Hawk.'' Solzhenitsyn came under particular criticism in his homeland because he condemned not only Stalin but also Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin, calling him ``evil.'' Lenin is still revered by most Soviets.

DOC.HEAD: Lew DeWitt, Statler Brothers Tenor For 18 Years, Died At Home
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto RM1
DOC.TEXT: Lew DeWitt, who sang tenor for the Statler Brothers and composed ``Flowers on the Wall,'' one of the country group's biggest hits, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 52. DeWitt, who left the group in 1982 because of a severe intestinal disorder, died Wednesday morning at home in his sleep, said Chet Fitzgerald, his road manager and business manager. ``We knew how bad his health was of course, but we were not expecting this so soon,'' said Ann Peters, the group's spokeswoman. ``We're shocked. our prayers go out to his family.'' The 1965 hit ``Flowers on the Wall'' sold more than 1 million copies and has been recorded by about 30 other artists. DeWitt had regional enteritis, or Crohn's disease, an inflammation of the digestive tract. He left the group on doctor's orders, but continued to perform sporadically with the Star City Band. DeWitt retired permanently last November. He was replaced at tenor by Jimmy Fortune of Charlottesville. DeWitt and three boyhood friends _ Harold Reid, Phil Balsley and Joe McDorman _ formed the Four-Star Quartet in 1948. The group, later known as the Kingsmen, sang mostly gospel music. McDorman quit and was replaced by Don Reid, Harold's younger brother. DeWitt once said the group changed its again because several other acts _ all better known _ were billed as the Kingsmen. The new name came from a box of Statler tissue, he said. The quartet switched to country music in 1964, after meeting country singer Johnny Cash and joining his road show. Over the next two decades, the Statlers won three Grammy Awards and were named top vocal groups nine times by the Country Music Association. DeWitt is survived by his wife, Judy; four children, Denver, Brian, Donna Kay DeWitt and Shannon DeWitt, and his mother, Rose Hogan DeWitt. A private family memorial was planned.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Poster Being Used On Buses Sparks Controversy
LaserPhoto CX6
DOC.TEXT: Its creators call it art with a message. But when a poster showing kissing men and women was displayed Wednesday on city buses, two politicians said freedom of speech had gone too far. ``Where will we draw the line in terms of this homosexuality-heterosexuality thing?'' said city Alderman Robert Shaw, who said he would introduce an ordinance banning the AIDS awareness poster. ``Is anything going on in this country now (acceptable) under the guise of free speech?'' About 80 of the posters, which depict three couples _ one heterosexual, one lesbian and one gay _ each locked in a romantic kiss, were displayed Wednesday on buses and at transit stations. ``Kissing Doesn't Kill: Greed and Indifference Do,'' reads the poster, created by a New York art collective. A version has appeared in the mass transit systems of both New York and San Francisco. ``It's our way of saying we're all affected by AIDS,'' said Gran Fury collective member Loring McAlpin. ``Yes, we are affirming sexuality across the board,'' said McAlpin. ``We don't think it's advocating a homosexual lifestyle.'' The posters were approved earlier this year and refusing to display them would violate the First Amendment protection of free speech, said Alfred Savage, executive director of the Chicago Transit Authority. ``Under the law, we have a requirement to post them,'' Savage said. ``We have no jurisdiction over the content.'' The transit authority was sued last year for refusing to post another AIDS awareness poster it deemed ``too black-oriented.'' After the American Civil Liberties Union filed suit, the authority began displaying the ads, said John Hammell, who directs the ACLU's AIDS and Civil Liberties Program in Chicago. Shaw said he planned to call a special City Council meeting to discuss his proposed ordinance, which would bar depictions such as that in Gran Fury's poster. ``This poster has nothing to do with the cure of AIDS,'' he said. ``It has something to do with promoting a lifestyle, which I object to.'' State Rep. Robert Regan, a Republican, said Tuesday he would reintroduce legislation in the Illinois General Assembly that would bar such displays of sexuality. A similar bill failed this spring. McAlpin said the poster, paid for by the New York-based American Foundation for AIDS research, overcame initial objections in San Francisco and New York. ``Nobody said, `This is great, we'll take it' _ there was a certain amount of resistance,'' he said. The poster is intended to address the deadly virus ``as an epidemic of corporate greed, government inaction and public indifference,'' she said. ``We don't believe anyone is going to see that ad and change their sexual preference.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Accuses New Jersey Man of Being Nazi Killer
DOC.TEXT: The government's Nazi-hunting agency Wednesday sought to revoke the citizenship of a Somerset, N.J., man alleged to have killed Jewish prisoners at the Koldyczewo concentration camp in World War II Poland. The Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations said Sergis Hutyrczyk was a member of the Byelorussian ``Shutzmannschaft,'' the local police controlled by Nazi Germany, and participated in killing Jewish and other prisoners at the camp as well as Jews in and around the city of Baranowicze. Baranowicze, then part of Poland, now is in the Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic in the Soviet Union. The OSI said in a complaint filed in U.S. District Court in Newark that Hutyrczyk was a supervising guard known to Koldyczewo inmates as the ``Black Commander.'' ``Because of his wartime activities and postwar lies, Hutyrczyk's citizenship must be revoked,'' OSI Director Neil Sher said. So far, 32 former Nazis have been stripped of U.S. citizenship and 27 have been deported, the Justice Department said. It said more than 600 people remain under investigation by Sher's unit.

DOC.HEAD: Libya Asks Security Council Meeting to Oppose U.S. Mideast Action
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Libya on Wednesday asked for a Security Council meeting in Geneva to oppose U.S. military presence in the Persian Gulf and to request that any forces there fly the U.N. flag, U.N. officials said. A meeting has not yet been scheduled. The Libyan news agency JANA, monitored in Rome, said Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi wants the meeting to criticize the U.S. military presence and quoted him as telling the agency: ``Any troops that are in the gulf that do not carry the banner of the United Nations or that are not formed by the Security Council and under its command are regarded as troops of colonialist invasion and should be resisted. ``We reject individual attempts by some United Nations members in a bid to control and practice hegemony.'' Security Council officials confirmed that Libya sent a letter but said the English-language text was not yet available. Security Council President Aurel Dragos Munteanu of Romania was expected to discuss the request in informal consultations with members. On Monday some Security Council members criticized the United States, saying it acted hastily and should not unilaterally enforce the U.N. embargo against Iraq _ imposed as punishment for Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait _without council approval. Envoys of Cuba, Canada, France and Malaysia said the best course was to wait for the Security Council to evaluate the effectiveness of sanctions on Iraq. The council next would decide whether to call for a U.N. blockade of Iraq to enforce the sanctions, they said. The United States says its action is justified under a U.N. Charter provision that calls for collective self-defense. It cites a letter from the ousted government of Kuwait requesting U.S. aid in enforcing sanctions on Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Rumors Fly in Military Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT to Cavalry sted Calvary.
DOC.TEXT: Folks in this Army town know from experience that something is up at Fort Hood. Soldiers are updating wills and stockpiling desert gear. Rumors are flying. But the Pentagon and the post refuse to say whether any troops have been or will be deployed to the Middle East. ``I can't speculate on that. We have no comment,'' said Fort Hood spokesman Maj. Jesse Seigal on Tuesday. ``We simply haven't announced anything out of Fort Hood,'' a Pentagon spokeswoman said. The post is the largest armored post in the U.S. and home of the 1st Cavalry and 2nd Armored divisions. The Associated Press has quoted an Army source in Washington as saying troops from Fort Hood would be deployed. The people of Killeen are sure that troops and equipment from their neighboring post will be involved somehow in the the Persian Gulf. ``There's something going on. You don't see any GI's downtown. At lunch we usually have five or six, but I haven't seen a GI in 2 or 3 weeks,'' said Margaret Galindo, an employee at The German Restaurant in Killeen. Almost 70,000 people live in Killeen, located at the main entrance of Fort Hood. About 45,000 of them are military, their families or military retirees. Bell County Justice of the Peace Robert Stubblefield said his office has been inundated with calls from soldiers who want to update their wills or designate power of attorney. ``Everybody kind of gets jittery and wants to get their stuff in order,'' Stubblefield said. Others point to the run by soldiers on desert supplies at Army surplus stores. The Fatigues and Things store was sold out of desert bandanas and camouflage, said assistant manager Maryann Carrillo. Canteens and desert goggles also were going fast. Much of that equipment is issued by the Army, but Ms. Carrillo said soldiers are telling her the post is either out of the items, or they're afraid they won't get them in time.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Mother Not to Smoke in Front of Son
DOC.TEXT: A mother has been ordered not to smoke in front of her 5-year-old son by a judge hearing a child custody dispute. Judge David Stirling issued the ruling Tuesday in Superior Court when the boy's father, Manfred Kallweit, complained of health risks associated with inhaling second-hand smoke. The mother, Anna Maria De Beni Souza, called the order crazy. Terry Eagan, regional vice president for the Tobacco Institute and Tobacco Action Network said he's ``never heard of anything like this in any other part of the country.'' Eagan said he would have the industry's lawyers investigate the case. ``The first thing that comes to my mind is the privacy issue,'' Eagan said. Kallweit, who has joint custody of the boy, asked the judge to impose the order after De Beni Souza petitioned the court for sole custody. The petition is pending. The ruling, which bans smoking ``in direct presence of child within the home,'' will stay in effect until the boy turns 18 or a higher judge overrules it. ``If this is a new wave, so be it,'' said Kallweit's lawyer, Charles Asbury. ``I appreciate all the problems that cigarettes pose in the world. ``The courts have regularly forbidden people to drink alcohol and consume drugs in child custody cases, the reason being the risk of harm to the child. Smoking poses the same risk of harm.'' De Beni Souza said she's a light smoker who goes through a pack of cigarettes in two or three days. ``What right does the court have to dictate my behavior in the privacy of my own home?'' she said. ``This is not Russia, right?''

DOC.HEAD: Buyers Flock To Love Canal Homes; State Refuses To Guarantee Them
DOC.TEXT: Home-seekers flocked to the neighborhood surrounding the Love Canal toxic-waste dump Wednesday as a state agency put nine houses up for sale but refused to guarantee their safety in writing. ``The area's been real quiet. It'll be nice to get neighbors back,'' said William Stevenson, one of about 70 people who stayed in the neighborhood rather than accept a government buyout during the late 1970s. But environmentalists and former neighborhood residents denounced plans to resettle the area, which became a powerful symbol of America's toxic waste problem when toxic chemical leaks drove about 2,500 people away. ``I think there is a very real risk,'' said Rebecca Todd of the Natural Resources Defense Council. The Love Canal Area Revitalization Agency originally planned to put 10 homes up for sale Wednesday, but one was snapped by a resident of an area the government considers uninhabitable, agency Executive Director William L. Broderick told a news conference. About 20 people visited the agency's sales office and another 10 called in the first four hours it was open, said Len Rinallo, the agency's salesman. Rinallo said two people had already put down $100 deposits on houses they want to buy when the rehabilitation is finished. The homes are priced at $40,000 to $60,000, about 20 percent less than comparable homes elsewhere. About 250 houses in the area eventually will be sold. The agency also announced that it was renaming the neighborhood Black Creek Village. The agency decided to borrow the name of a tiny local creek to help erase the area's toxic-waste image, said agency Planning Director James E. Carr. Love Canal gained notoriety after 22,000 tons of dioxin, PCBs and other hazardous chemicals dumped there 30 years earlier by Hooker Chemical Co. began leaking into a middle-class neighborhood built on top of the dump. The 2,500 people fled their homes, and 240 houses and an elementary school were demolished. More than 800 other homes have stood vacant since then. The dump has been capped and a monitoring system installed, but most of the chemicals remain buried beneath a 70-acre fenced-off mound. The area chosen for resettlement is north and northwest of the dump. State studies show that it is no more contaminated than comparable neighborhoods elsewhere in Niagara Falls, agency officials said Wednesday. ``It's probably the safest area in the city of Niagara Falls, because we know the most about it,'' said Broderick. However, Broderick said the agency could not give any written guarantees chemical leaks would not recur. ``All we have is the written assurance of the state health department, the state environment department,'' he said. ``If there is a problem in the future, I'm sure the state will come back and do as they did last time.'' Joseph E. Ceretto, a 28-year-old substitute teacher who inspected some of the homes, said the lack of guarantees would not deter him from buying one. He said the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency had deemed the area habitable. ``With the continuous monitoring, I'll know what's in my backyard,'' Ceretto said. Outside the house Ceretto wants to buy stood Luella Kenny, a former resident whose 7-year-old son died of a kidney ailment she blames on dioxin from the dump. She said she didn't trust the government's assurances. ``The government is fooling with people, just like they fooled us 12 years ago, telling us everything was going to be all right,'' said Kenny, who now lives on nearby Grand Island. But other onlookers, such as the Stevenson and his wife, Phyllis, said they never believed the danger was as great as everyone feared. ``We raised a family, and they grew up and had children, and now (the children) have children. They're all healthy,'' Mrs. Stevenson said. Todd of the Natural Resources Defense Council confronted agency officials at their news conference, then held one of her own across the street. She said offering the homes for sale put the agency in contempt of a 1985 court order. Her group and four others have asked a state judge to enforce the order and block any sales. Agency lawer Paul Reid said the court order only barred the sales until a habitability study and an environmental impact statement were completed, and said those requirements had been met.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Asks Congress To Approve Nearly $2 Billion in Arms for Egypt
With AM-US-Gulf Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, bgng: But, she, to UPDATE with congressional comment; SUBS 3rd graf pvs, State Department, to add verb
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Wednesday it has asked Congress to clear the sale of 46 F-16 jet fighters and other weaponry to Egypt. A Congressional source estimated the value of the package at nearly $2 billion. State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler called the deal ``the final phase of a decade-long program to modernize and westernize the Egyptian air force'' and said it was ``totally unrelated to the current crisis'' in the Persian Gulf region. But, she said, ``As part of our response to the current Gulf crisis, we will review requests from our friends for additional arms sales on a case-by-case basis.'' Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., said he had hoped the administration would use the Gulf crisis ``as a time to reevaluate a policy of unrestrained arms sales to the region.'' Levine, a member of the House Middle East subcommittee, said the sales ``had the effect of making a tinderbox more volatile.'' Egypt has played a leading role in the Arab world in supporting the U.S. economic boycott of Iraq. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak also sent troops to Saudi Arabia to assist in the defense of the oil fields should Iraq attack. Congress was notified informally of the sale last Thursday. This started a 20-day period in which Congress has a chance to propose changes in the package. Then, if both the House and Senate do not vote against the sale within 30 days it goes through. There is no indication so far of congressional opposition. Egypt is the only Arab country at peace with Israel. As a result, Israeli governments have not objected to U.S. arms sales to Cairo. The administration also is preparing to ask Congress to clear the sale of at least a dozen F-15 fighters to Saudi Arabia. That could get a far different reception on Capitol Hill. Supporters of Israel and members of Congress concerned about the proliferation of arms in the Middle East or the possibility the weapons could be captured by terrorists are apt to fight a Saudi deal. On the other hand, the Bush administration probably will make the argument that Iraq's annexation of Kuwait and threat to the Saudi oilfields requires building up the Saudi arsenal.

DOC.HEAD: Haiti's Council of State Passes No Confidence Vote on President
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ The Council of State said Wednesday it had passed a vote of no confidence in President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, declaring her administration has become an obstacle to holding free elections. General elections in this poor, violence-wracked Caribbean country are scheduled for Nov. 4. But on Wednesday the Electoral Council set up to oversee the voting pushed back the opening of voter registration from Aug. 19 to Sept. 3. There has been much speculation that the Electoral Council will have to postpone the elections. The 19-member Council of State, which rules alongside Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, passed the no-confidence vote Tuesday. A statement released Wednesday by the council did not indicate how members voted. ``Having respected none of its commitments, the executive is no longer able to win the confidence of the people and has become an obstacle to the holding of genuine elections,'' the council statement said. In passing its no-confidence vote, the council declared it was impossible to collaborate with the government. But the council's president, Dr. Louis Roy, told The Associated Press that council will not resign. It was unclear what effect the no-confidence vote would have, although it does not oblige Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot to resign. The vote was seen as a symbolic gesture to put pressure on Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot to abide by the joint governing agreement under which the council was to have veto power over her Cabinet appointments and major decisions. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot's civilian caretaker government came to power March 13, after a week-long popular uprising toppled military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, 46, a former Supreme Court justice, became the first female president in Haiti's 186-year history. At the time, she agreed to govern alongside the Council of State, whose members were appointed by civilian opposition leaders, until after the country's first free elections could take place later in the year. The council is comprised of representatives of civic organizations and provincial districts. The conflict between the council and Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot came to a head May 21, when the president appointed Marie Violene Legagneur as finance minister without the council's authorization. Council members regarded Legagneur as a sympathizer of the Duvalier family dictatorship of Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier, who fled into exile in 1986, and of his late father, Francois ``Papa Doc.'' Legagneur resigned a month later. Also in June, Council of State member Serge Villard was assassinated by four gunmen, two of whom were dressed in army uniforms. In a statement of Aug. 7, the council accused the government of not pursuing the investigation of Villard's murder. Information Minister Carlo Desinor said last week that the conflict between the council and the president stemmed from ``over-sensitivity _ personality not political differences.'' But in Wednesday's statement, the council accused the president of failing to implement the administrative, judicial, military and economic reforms that were set down as prerequisites for genuine elections when the caretaker government came to power. Haiti's last attempt at holding free elections ended in failure. On Nov. 29, 1987, thugs in collusion with the army killed at least 34 voters at the polls, halting the first free general elections in Haiti since independence from France in 1804.

DOC.HEAD: Philippines To Auction Paintings, Silver
DOC.TEXT: The Philippine government will sell an estimated $10 million worth of Old Master paintings and a 100-piece silver service acquired while Ferdinand Marcos was president. ``We appreciate fine art and we wish we could afford the luxury of keeping these art pieces for ourselves,'' M.A.T. Caparas, chairman of the Philippine Presidential Commission on Good Government, said in a statement released Wednesday by Christie's, the auctioneer. ``Our people, however, suffer from many needs that the proceeds from these art works will help assauge. ... At least part of the money from this sale will probably be directed to the relief of the victims of our recent killer quake,'' said Caparas. The commission was created by President Corazon Aquino in February 1986, primarily to recover wealth accumulated at the expense of the government by Marcos, his relatives, subordinates and close associates. Marcos was ousted in 1986 and died in Hawaii last September. Dana Micucci, a spokeswoman for Christie's, said it was not clear who acquired the silver and 70 paintings to be auctioned, or where they were kept. The sale is planned for January.

DOC.HEAD: New Elvis Song Coming Out
DOC.TEXT: RCA has released a ``new'' song by Elvis Presley, a poignant ballad called ``My Happiness'' that had been believed lost, an RCA executive said in the late singer's birthplace. An 18-year-old Elvis recorded the song for his mother Gladys on July 18, 1953, at the Memphis (Tenn.) Recording Service. The vanity acetate disc, for which the singer paid $3.98, is thought to be first recording by ``the King.'' ``It could be called the underpinnings of rock 'n' roll _ it's still blues and country,'' said Dan Wardell, national director of catalog music for RCA. ``Some have described it as the birth of rock 'n' roll.'' ``My Happiness'' is the lead cut on RCA's just-released ``Elvis: The Great Performances,'' a companion album to a two-volume music video of the same name due out Friday from Buena Vista Video. Thursday is the 13th anniversary of Elvis' death on Aug. 16, 1977. He was 42 years old. The acetate disc had been in the possession of a high-school chum of Presley; RCA obtained the license to the song. The song was snapped up immediately for radio airplay in the United States and Europe, said Wardell. ``There's always extraordinary interest in anything having to do with Elvis,'' he said. ``This is unusual because it was thought to be lost for many years.'' Wardell was a guest at welcoming ceremonies Saturday at the Elvis Presley Birthplace and Park in Tupelo. The sentimental strains of ``My Happiness'' _ ``How I long to be with you'' _ played over a speaker, giving the occasion a warm, ironic note. The disc reappeared in 1988, in the possession of retired airline pilot Ed Leek, who attended high school with Presley. RCA was approached about it 18 months ago, Wardell said, and it took that long to conclude arrangements for its release. Sun Entertainment Corp. bought the rights to ``My Happiness'' from Leek; RCA obtained a license to use the song from Sun Entertainment. Presley recorded another song on the other side of the disc _ ``That's When Your Heartaches Begin'' _ and discussions about that song are under way at Sun, Wardell said. That song needs a lot of restoration work, he said. However, there is some skepticism about ``Heartaches.'' An expert hired by ``NBC Nightly News'' said the ``aural fingerprints'' of a tape of the acetate didn't match a 1956 version of the same song by Elvis. Wardell said, ``We have an affidavit from Marion Keisker, who was a secretary at Memphis Recording Service that day. The Elvis Presley Estate says it's authentic. We have no reason to doubt it's the real thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq to Participate in Emergency OPEC Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will be allowed to participate in an emergency OPEC meeting to make new price and production decisions, Venezuela's acting foreign minister said Wednesday. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has not yet announced a date and location for its meeting. ``Iraq is a member of OPEC, and has the right to participate in any of its meetings,'' acting Foreign Minister Adolfo Raul Taylhardat told reporters. He spoke in the presence of Iraq's ambassador to Venezuela, Majid A. Al Samarra'i. The ambassador visited Taylhardat to clarify a government version of comments he made Tuesday, which indicated that Iraq was threatening OPEC not to raise production in the aftermath of the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraqi forces. The ambassador said he made no such threat. Iraq, with the de facto annexation of Kuwait, controls about 20 percent of the world's oil reserves, second only to Saudi Arabia. Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez said he hoped a pricing decision would be made this week.

DOC.HEAD: Southwest Gets More Wet Weather
DOC.TEXT: The remains of a weakening tropical storm brought thunderstorms and a threat of flash floods to the Southwest on Wednesday, and it also rained across much of the Southeast. The same weather system pelted Southern California with hail and heavy rain Tuesday. There were widely scattered showers and thunderstorms along the western Gulf Coast, west Texas, New Mexico, Colorado, Utah and Arizona. A flash flood watch was posted for parts of Texas, Nevada, southern Utah, New Mexico and most of Arizona. Scattered showers and thunderstorms also developed along a front curving from Missouri and Oklahoma through the central Gulf Coast states to the southern Atlantic Coast. A few showers developed along a cold front in the upper Midwest over central Michigan and east central Wisconsin. An upper-level weather disturbance crossing the northern Plateau over eastern Washington state and northern Idaho produced a few showers. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation. Temperatures were mostly in the 80s and lower 90s from the southern Plains to the southern Atlantic Coast Wednesday afternoon. Afternoon readings were in the 70s in the upper Mississippi Valley, the Great Lakes region, and the Northeast. Clouds and rain kept temperatures relatively cool in the Southwest. Readings in the normally torrid desert areas of southern Arizona and southern California barely topped 90 degree mark at midday. Seasonable temperatures prevailed over the Northwest. The low for the Lower 48 states Wednesday morning was 41 at Warroad, Minn., and West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Panel Calls for Changes in Drug Testing
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's advisory panel on the treatment of cancer and AIDS proposed major changes Wednesday in government testing of experimental drugs to speed them to patients ``for whom time is running out.'' For patients who are not benefited by approved and readily available medicines, ``still unproved therapies may represent their only hope,'' the panel said in its final report. For patients who resist all available therapies, ``new treatments on the cutting edge of science may represent the best standard of care,'' it said. The President's Cancer Panel, chaired by industrialist Armand Hammer, a physician by training, concluded that patients are willing to accept the risks associated with new and untried therapies. But it said they can become more widely available only if the Food and Drug Administration, the agency charged with approving and regulating medical therapies, ``can be allowed and is willing to become more flexible in implementing such innovations'' for patients ``for whom time is running out.'' Activist groups representing AIDS and cancer patients also have called for expediting and expanding use of experimental treatments. The panel made these recommendations and findings: _The secretary of health and human services should establish a permanent policy and oversight committee to monitor the FDA's regulation and approval of drugs and biologic therapies for human use. _Expedited approval of cancer and AIDS drugs could result if the FDA relied more frequently on the opinion of qualified experts serving on agency advisory committees. _The FDA should consider modifying its current criteria for approval of new drug applications. The present standard, proof of improved survival, might well be changed to include complete or partial positive responses in patients whose cancers have resisted all current therapies. The panel said drugs that produce tumor regression in more than 20 percent or 30 percent of patients in approval trials should be approved for marketing. _Congress should give prompt attention to FDA's inadequate resources, staff and facilities. _FDA studies designed to determine if a drug under investigation is superior to that of a prescription drug may no longer be required for that drug to receive market approval. _The FDA's advisory committee system for human prescription drugs should be fundamentally restructured with panels permitted to bypass intermediate staff and report directly to the FDA commissioner. The panels should have an independent staff and control their own agendas and priorities. The panel also recommended that companies sponsoring experimental drugs have the option of paying the FDA for outside review of the applications by qualified and unbiased experts in order to resolve the FDA's problem of increasing responsibilities and decreasing staff. Medicare, Medicaid and private insurers should give identical coverage for experimental drugs and all related medical care for AIDS and cancer patients, the committee said. ``We endorse the development of community-based clinical trials that permit widespread access to investigational drugs without sacrificing statistical analysis of drug effectiveness and thus that can lead to early regulatory approval,'' the panel said. Hammer said he hopes the report will prove useful in improving the federal drug review process ``and in reducing delays in marketing new drugs, thus benefiting cancer and AIDS patients throughout the country.'' The study was initiated in June 1988 at the request of President Bush, then serving as vice president.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Mother, Daughter Die in Saudi Shootout With Drug Dealer
DOC.TEXT: An American mother and daughter were killed when a suspected drug dealer commandeered the car they were riding in, leading to a car chase and a gun battle with police, the U.S. Embassy said Wednesday. Also in the car were the husband and three other children. The mother, Kimberley Hinkson, was 4{ months pregnant withsin Dennis Hansen reported in Provo, Utah. Also killed was her daughter, Courtney, 10, one of the six Hinkson children, he said. In Washington, State Department press officer Adam Shub said both mother and daughter apparently were killed by the gun twins, her couman. An embassy statement said the incident took place Tuesday night in Riyadh, the capital, and identified the man who seized the car as a Saudi citizen. Family members in the United States said Kent Hinkson and his family moved from Orange County, Calif., to Saudi Arabia eight years ago and were scheduled to move back to the United States on Aug. 29 and settle in Provo. Hansen said Mr. and Mrs. Hinkson and four of their children were out for hamburgers when a man being pursued by police jumped in their car and shot the daughter in the throat, killing her. During the chase that followed, Mrs. Hinkson was shot to death and Kent Hinkson was wounded in the scalp, he reported.
