DOC.HEAD: Godzilla Kicked Out of Town
DOC.TEXT: It's a tough place. Officials can tell even Godzilla to get out of town. A 35-foot-high balloon rendition of Japan's cinematic monster that was used to herald the opening of a new computer store will be taken off his rooftop perch after a five-day stay. The city council in this San Francisco suburb decided three years ago that such inflatables are tacky and limited merchants to displaying them for just five days each quarter-year. Godzilla may be the first balloon in Walnut Creek since a chicken was tethered to the top of a fast-food restaurant just befor the ordinance passed, said Bill Englund, chairman of the Design Review Commission. Heanac Chung, spokeswoman at the new ComputerCraft store, said the balloon would be taken down and moved on to a new assignment.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Announces Travel Restrictions For Romanians
DOC.TEXT: The government imposed travel restrictions on Romanian tourists after hundreds of Romanians were turned back into Czechoslovakia by East German authorities, the official CTK news agency said Wednesday. As of Monday, Romanian tourists traveling to Czechoslovakia will have to show an official invitation, a voucher proving they have paid for their stay, or a valid visa for a country of final destination, CTK said. However, it said the measures ``do not mean cancellation of the mutually agreed visa-free travel'' between the two countries. CTK said that starting Thursday, Romanian tourists going to East Germany through Czechoslovakia must produce the required papers at the Czechoslovak-Hungarian border or be turned back. The new regulations came after a growing number of Romanian tourists sought to stay in Czechoslovakia after being denied admission to East Germany. Romania has the weakest economy among the six Eastern European countries which are trying to introduce market-oriented reforms. Many Romanians augment their incomes by buying products abroad that are scarce at home and selling them on the black market, leading Romanian authorities to impose stricter customs regulations. Thousands of others have sought to emigrate in hopes of finding better living conditions and jobs. East German authorities now require Romanians to produce an official invitiation or proof that they possess enough hard currency to pay for their stay. Romanian visitors also must hold round-trip tickets. East German border officials have turned back about 800 Romanians at the Czechoslovak border over the past few days. The Mlada Fronta newspaper said most of those sent back were Romanian Gypsies.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Will Not Stop Iraqi, Kuwaiti Ships in Canal
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Panama said Wednesday it will continue to allow Iraqi and Kuwaiti ships through the Panama Canal, citing the 1977 treaties with the United States guaranteeing neutral operation of the waterway. Foreign Minister Julio Linares said Panama is putting the Panama Canal Treaties above all other international agreements, including those under the U.N. Charter. Last week, the U.N. Security Council imposed a mandatory economic embargo against Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. According to the Panama Canal Commission, 27 Kuwaiti ships passed through the canal last year. Only two ships flying the Iraqi flag have made the passage in the last seven years, the commission said. In an interview, Linares said the United Nations could have no legal objection to Panama's decision to abide by the 1977 treaties. The 1977 agreement ``declares the neutrality of the Canal so that, in times of peace as in times of war, it will remain secure and open to the peaceful transit of the ships of all nations ... so that the canal and the Isthmus of Panama will not be the target of reprisals in any conflict between other nations of the world.'' The Panama Canal Commission issued a brief statement Wednesday saying ``there has been no change in current policy ... in respect to the transit of ships through the Panama Canal.'' President Guillermo Endara said that both the United States and Panama agree that ``ships should be able to pass through the canal, no matter what their nationality.'' The United States and other Western nations have amassed a large naval force in the Middle East to stop shipping into and out of Iraqi and Kuwaiti ports. The Panama Canal Treaties call for control of the waterway to be turned over to Panama at the turn of the century, with that nation guaranteeing the neutral operation of the canal. In 1979, Panama took control from the United States of the Canal Zone, which extends for five miles on either side of the waterway between the Pacific Ocean and Caribbean Sea.

DOC.HEAD: Josie Heath Wins Democratic Senate Primary in Colorado
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Senate candidate Josie Heath wasted no time Wednesday launching her campaign against her GOP opponent, U.S. Rep. Hank Brown, after defeating her opponent in the Colorado primary election. Heath challenged Brown, who ran unopposed in Tuesday's primary, to debates, and criticized his record in Congress on energy, the environment and defense. She said the Nov. 6 general election was ``a referendum on the future of this country.'' Brown spokeswoman Katy Atkinson responded that the congressman in June had challenged the Democratic nominee to a series of seven debates. ``What she said today was in response to his challenge three months ago. We're glad she apparently has accepted,'' said Atkinson. Meanwhile, state Republican Chairman Bruce Benson asked the Federal Election Commission to investigate the Heath campaign's failure to report 18 campaign contributions. The Heath campaign has said the records of those contributions were lost due to a computer glitch. Heath, a former Boulder County commissioner, defeated Alamosa attorney Carlos Lucero in the Democratic primary. She received 115,935 votes, or 59 percent, to 82,044, or 41 percent, for Lucero. Heath and Brown, are vying for the seat held by U.S. Sen. William Armstrong, who decided not to seek re-election after two terms. In other action Wednesday, proponents of a major-league baseball team in Denver pushed forward in their effort to obtain a National League expansion franchise after area voters approved a .1 percent sales tax to pay for a stadium. In other primaries Tuesday, Wayne Allard defeated Jim Brandon for the GOP nomination for the 4th Congressional District seat Brown gave up after 10 years to run for the Senate. Allard, a veterinarian, outpolled Brandon 18,563 to 14,917, or 55 percent to 45 percent. The Democratic candidate in the general election is state Rep. Dick Bond, who was unopposed Tuesday. The stadium-tax question won approval on a vote of 187,539 to 157,539, or 54 percent to 46 percent. The next step for baseball supporters would be to find local business people interested in owning a Denver club. Gov. Roy Romer and his three-member baseball task force met shortly after dawn Wednesday to begin planning their strategy. William W. Fletcher, chairman of the board of the Rocky Mountain News, said his newspaper is interested in a minority stake in a team.

DOC.HEAD: ABC News Chief Doubts Iraq Will Open TV Floodgates ^By JAY SHARBUTT ^AP Television Writer
DOC.TEXT: Although Ted Koppel and CBS anchorman Dan Rather have been allowed in Iraq, ABC News president Roone Arledge said Wednesday he doubts this means a wave of other TV correspondents will be allowed in. ``I don't get that sense and our people there don't get that sense,'' said Arledge. He also said Iraq didn't seek out ABC to be the first network: ``We just worked like hell to get in there.'' He spoke a day after Koppel, anchor of ABC's ``Nightline,'' became the first U.S. network correspondent allowed in Iraq since its Aug. 2 military takeover of Kuwait. Rather, who arrived Wednesday in Baghdad, filed his first reports by phone because no TV satellite uplink was available, CBS said. Koppel also had to do that Tuesday, but on Wednesday was able to send via satellite a videotaped interview with Iraq foreign minister Tariq Aziz. ``We are not going to yield to pressure. We are not going to yield to this kind of intimidation,'' Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said Wednesday in a segment of the interview broadcast on ABC's evening news. ``Iraq is not going to initiate a war.'' The interview was carried on ABC's ``Nightline.'' Arledge, speaking at a press lunch, said he doubted any correspondent, including Koppel, would be granted an interview with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein simply because he rarely gives any. Hussein's only previous U.S. television interview was in July with ABC's Diane Sawyer. However this time, Arledge, ``I don't think anybody's going to get Hussein.'' He said the Iraqis set no conditions in return for allowing Koppel and an ABC team in, but have restricted what his camera crews could shoot there, and once stopped him from taking a still photograph on a street. He noted that similar restrictions apply in Saudi Arabia, which is allied with the U.S. in opposing Iraq's takeover of Kuwait and has allowed a large U.S. military buildup on its soil. Iraqi officials generally haven't limited Koppel's movements, Arledge said, but made him leave a Baghdad hotel where 36 Americans and two British citizens are being held. They were brought there from Kuwait after the Iraqi invasion. Koppel began pressing for entry into Iraq last week when he talked with the country's foreign minister after a news conference in Cairo, and on Sunday got Jordan's King Hussein to intervene for him, Arledge said. Before ABC could transmit from Iraqi TV facilities, it had to get a waiver from the U.S. government and INTELSAT, the international satellite cooperative, Arledge said. This was because payments for use of Iraq satellite facilities are barred by the United Nations' economic sanctions against Iraq. Cable News Network and NBC still are trying to get correspondents into Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Rebels Hold Guineans, Nigerians in Battle Zone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to delete hostage reference, pinpoint Guinea and Nigeria in rebel contention regarding West African force. Picks up 6th graf, `Nigerian and. . .'
DOC.TEXT: Rebels evacuated most foreigners from Monrovia's battlefront in an 18-vehicle convoy on Wednesday, but prevented scores of Guineans and Nigerians from leaving. Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo, commander of a West African peacekeeping force set to sail to Liberia, said a confrontation with Charles Taylor's rebels while they were holding West Africans could make his mission a disaster. President Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso, where some rebels say they were trained, said he opposed the military intervention by fellow West African leaders and warned of a possible ``spillover'' of Liberia's violent civil war. Insurgents of Taylor's National Patriotic Front invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 to oust what they called the corrupt government of President Samuel Doe. Fighting between Taylor, a former Doe aide accused of embezzlement, and a splinter group led by former army officer Prince Johnson has prolonged the conflict. The fighting has killed 5,000 people, mostly civilians. Taylor had said he would allow the Nigerian and Guinean embassies to evacuate personnel. But that was before both countries sent soldiers to join the West African army. Taylor spokesman Tom Woewiyu says Nigeria and Guinea, whose leaders are friends of Doe, are trying to use the West African force as a cover to get troops into Liberia to bolster the besieged president. Nigerian and Guinean troops are mobilizing in Freetown, capital of neighboring Sierra Leone, with soldiers from Gambia, Ghana, Sierra Leone and Togo forming a force to exceed 2,500 men. They have orders to fight to force an end to the war. Taylor threatens to attack any foreign troops sent to Liberia. He excludes 2,100 U.S. Marines on standby on warships off Monrovia and in the capital itself evacuating Americans and some other foreign nationals and protecting a skeleton embassy staff and U.S. installations. Washington says it will not intervene militarily to end the conflict. On Wednesday, Taylor's rebels escorted a convoy of foreigners and Liberians from the West German, Moroccan and Egyptian embassies. West German Ambassador Juergen Gehl told reporters as he left that 11 Germans, two Moroccan diplomats, the Egyptian ambassador, four Lebanese and 24 Liberians were heading for neighboring Ivory Coast. But about 60 Guineans, including the ambassador, were refused permission to join the convoy, Gehl said. Other diplomats said about 1,400 people at the Nigerian Embassy also had to stay behind. Hundreds of Guinean troops have massed with tanks on the border with Liberia since Guinea accused Taylor rebels of making cross-border raids and killing Liberian refugees of the Mandingo tribe. The war has degenerated into a tribal conflict with rebels killing civilians of Doe's Krahn tribe and Mandingos accused of supporting him. Soldiers have slaughtered people of the Gio and Mano tribes, to which most rebels belong. Compaore's warning that the conflict may spill over was contained in a letter to Gambian leader Sir Dawda Jawara, head of a Liberia mediation committee set up by the Economic Community of West African States. Quainoo, commander of the multinational force, told reporters Wednesday a cease-fire was a precondition for the kind of peacekeeping operation he would like to command. He spoke before leaving Freetown for Banjul, the Gambian capital, where Taylor has promised to meet Jawara to discuss the war and his opposition to the intervention force. Doe's troops control a few square miles of Monrovia. Most of the capital is in the hands of Johnson's men. Taylor's fighters hold most of this country of 2.3 million people. In Washington, the State Department said U.S. forces off Liberia evacuated a total of 314 people as of last Monday, most of them Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Carrier Battle Group Heads To Sea

INSERTS 5 grafs after third graf pvs, `The major...' to UPDATE with wedding upswing in Georgia, stealth fighters to deploy; SUBS 8th graf pvs, `At Ft. Campbell...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with troops being cheered. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `At Offutt...' ^LaserPhoto NK2
DOC.TEXT: The aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and seven ships of its battle group left East Coast ports Wednesday on a quickly planned deployment to the Middle East. ``Please don't worry, we can take care of ourselves,'' Capt. Henry C. Giffen III, commander of the guided missile cruiser USS Thomas S. Gates, told well-wishers over the public address system at the Norfolk Naval Base. ``The major challenge for the families has been getting ready for this sudden deployment,'' said Capt. Tom Johnson, Atlantic Fleet chaplain. ``The feelings will have to be dealt with when they see an empty pier and the reality of the separation sets in.'' In Georgia, wedding bells are ringing like crazy for soldiers rushing to say ``I do'' in a marriage frenzy reminiscent of World War II scenes. Jill Sweat, 23, of Hinesville, and 2nd Lt. Michael Vandenbos, 23, were among about 60 military couples who applied for marriage licenses in the past few days. Vandenbos, a mortar platoon leader at Fort Stewart, is on alert and must check in at the post periodically, even on Thursday, his wedding night. ``When we first decided to do this it was such a disappointment because we had planned this big wedding'' in December, said Ms. Sweat, an Armstrong State College student. ``But now I realize that I am not the only one who had to do this. I know of three other couples who are getting married this week.'' Meanwhile, Pentagon sources said 22 radar-evading F-117A stealth fighters would leave for the Middle East on Thursday. One of the ships in the Kennedy battle group is the guided-missile frigate Samuel B. Roberts, which was crippled by a mine in the Persian Gulf in 1988 while escorting a Kuwaiti oil tanker. It headed to sea from Newport, R.I. The Kennedy battle group and its 9,000 men may be used to relieve the Eisenhower battle group in the Red Sea, the Pentagon announced Tuesday. Or, the Pentagon said, the Kennedy could be added to the naval forces arrayed around the Middle East as part of the ``Desert Shield'' operation to defend Saudi Arabia. In one of the many deployment moves Wednesday, soldiers and helicopters from Fort Rucker's only combat unit, the 2nd Battalion of the 229th Aviation Regiment, got a flag-waving send-off in Alabama as they departed for an unspecified destination. And Alabama Gov. Guy Hunt approved the deployment of more than 130 members of the state's Air National Guard to the troubled region. Troops from Fort Bragg's 82nd Airborne Division boarded C-5 transport planes Wednesday at Pope Air Force Base, N.C., while Marines from Camp Lejeune, N.C., prepared for deployment to the Middle East on ships. Hundreds of people gathered along Interstate 75 in Tennessee to cheer members of Ft. Campbell's 101st Airborne Division traveling from the Kentucky base to Florida and then to Saudi Arabia. Some, displaying banners, lined up along highway overpasses, while passing vehicles honked at the military caravan. ``My husband is in the reserves and, you know, do unto others as you would have them do unto you,'' said Charlotte Brumley, who spent her lunch hour in the 96-degree heat watching the Army trucks. At Offutt Air Force Base, Neb., more than 200 friends, relatives and military personnel gathered Wednesday to honor the first American serviceman to die in Saudi Arabia since President Bush deployed U.S. troops there. Staff Sgt. John Campisi, 30, died Sunday when he was hit by a truck. The Kennedy group will conduct previously planned training operations off the Virginia coast for several days, according to Navy officials, while awaiting a decision on where to send the ships. Navy officials declined to say how long the ships might be at sea. The ships are the second carrier battle group put to sea since Iraq invaded Kuwait. Last week, the Saratoga battle group left from Florida for the Mediterranean. The USS Independence and its battle group are stationed in the Mideast and the Eisenhower group has moved from the Mediterranean into the Red Sea. Besides the Kennedy and Gates, the guided missile cruisers USS Mississippi and USS San Jacinto, and the combat stores ship USS Sylvania left Norfolk on Wednesday. The Roberts and the fast combat support ship USS Seattle from Earle, N.J., will join the carrier group at sea, said an Atlantic Fleet spokeswoman, Lt. Cmdr. Carrie Hartshorne. The destroyer USS Moosbrugger was scheduled to leave Charleston, S.C., on Thursday to join the battle group. The Kennedy's departure is the second major force movement from the Norfolk base this week. On Monday, the 13 ships of Amphibious Group Two began their departures. The ships will pick up their Marine air and ground troops at Morehead City, N.C., before heading for the Middle East. Also leaving Norfolk on Tuesday was the 1,000-bed Navy hospital ship USS Comfort heading for the Middle East. On April 14, 1988, the Roberts hit an Iranian mine while escorting a oil tanker in the Persian Gulf during the Iran-Iraq war. The blast tore a 22- to 25-foot hole in its bottom, flooded its engine room and set off a fire that took five hours to control. Ten crewmen were injured, two critically. All have since recovered. The Roberts underwent several months of repairs at Bath Iron Works in Portland, Maine, and returned to Newport in October 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Movie's Re-Release Scheduled for 25th Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: To celebrate the silver anniversary of ``The Sound of Music,'' 20th Century Fox will re-release the Oscar-winning musical on Aug. 24, the studio announced Wednesday. Winner of five Academy Awards, ``The Sound of Music'' made its debut in 1965 and was a commercial hit, grossing $57 million over an unprecedented 4{-year run. The soundtrack album, featuring Julie Andrews, sold 10 million copies worldwide. The film will be re-released in Los Angeles and New York only. In addition to Miss Andrews, ``The Sound of Music'' stars Christopher Plummer and Eleanor Parker. The Rodgers-Hammerstein musical follows a singing family in war-torn Austria. The Aug. 23 gala party will be attended by Miss Andrews, the film's director, Robert Wise, and six of the actors who played children in the film.

DOC.HEAD: Secret Police Say Israeli Aided Murder of Presidential Candidate
DOC.TEXT: A retired Israeli army colonel helped Colombian cocaine traffickers murder a presidential candidate whose death set off a major crackdown on the Medellin drug cartel, the secret police said Wednesday. The suspect, Yair Klein, was a ``mercenary, narco-terrorist instructor and presumed accomplice'' in the murder last Aug. 18 of Luis Carlos Galan, said a report by the Department of Adminstrative Security, Colombia's secret police. At the time Galan was the leading presidential hopeful of the ruling Liberal Party. His campaign manager, Cesar Gaviria, became the Liberal Party candidate and won the presidential elections. He was inaugurated Aug. 7. The killing of Galan led to a war between the government and the Medellin cocaine cartel. Since the asssassination, drug traffickers have killed more than 500 Colombians, police say. Galan's murder, the police report said, ``was part of a plot to produce a situation of political chaos and government instability.'' The plot's objective was to stop prosecution of drug traffickers. Wednesday's report said the government has identified most of the people involved in Galan's assassination. A previous government inquiry found that Galan's murder was ordered by the Medellin cartel. The investigation has so far implicated 19 people, including Klein and cartel leaders Pablo Escobar and Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha. Seven of the 19 have been arrested. Three others, including Rodriguez Gacha, have been killed by the police. Escobar, the cartel's leader, remains at large. Colombia's government has issued an arrest warrant for Klein for allegedly training private armies working for drug traffickers. Klein is now in Israel. He has said he believed he had been hired to train ranchers to defend themselves against leftist guerrillas. He has denied any involvement with drug traffickers. The secret police report summarized the investigation of Galan's murder. It said the weapons used to murder Galan where shipped from Israel via the Caribbean island of Antigua. Klein coordinated the arms shipment, the report said. Galan was the first of three presidential candidates to be assassinated during the 1989-90 electoral campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Commemorates Anniversary of Surrender
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS two grafs after 10th graf `About a' to UPDATE with police finding three bomb-like devices near TV station. Pickup 11th pvs, `The late...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TOK3,TOK8
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito on Wednesday led the nation in honoring the war dead with a minute of silence exactly 45 years after his father broadcast the Japanese surrender that ended World War II. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu urged Japan not to repeat ``the tragedy of the war'' and pointedly did not visit a Shinto shrine where many of Japan's war dead, including 14 convicted high-ranking war criminals, are enshrined. This was to avoid offending nations that suffered from Japanese aggression in World War II. Akihito, flanked by Empress Michiko, bowed deeply before a wooden pillar that stood as a monument to the dead and a huge display of white and yellow chrysanthemums. He prayed for world peace during a memorial ceremony at the Budokan martial arts hall near the Imperial Palace. About 7,600 survivors of Japan's war victims also participated in the nationally televised ceremony. ``It is a very important task for each of us to establish lasting peace in order not to repeat the tragedy of the war,'' Kaifu told the hushed crowd. Earlier in the day, all members of the Cabinet visited the Yasukuni Shrine except Kaifu, the chief Cabinet secretary, and the foreign minister. No prime minister since Yasuhiro Nakasone in 1985 has visited the shrine in an official capacity. Nakasone discontinued the visits because of opposition from China and other neighboring nations. ``I think it is a natural expectation for the head of the state to pay respect to those who are sent to a war ... and lost their lives,'' said a disappointed Tsutomu Hata of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, who was among nearly 200 members of Parliament who visited the shrine. About a dozen riot police vehicles surrounded the shrine to prevent violence between small groups of demonstrating rightists and leftists. Each group blared messages through loudspeakers that were virtually impossible to understand because of the high volume. Police later reported that three undetonated bomb-like devices were found around the television station that broadcast the memorial ceremony. No group claimed responsibility for planting the devices, officials said, but local media speculated that extremists who oppose the monarchy may have been responsible. The late Emperor Hirohito, posthumously known as Showa, announced to a stunned nation Aug. 15, 1945, that Japan would surrender to the Allies. The United States had just leveled the cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki with atomic bombs. Akihito, who is Hirohito's son, led the minute of silence at noon. It even interrupted action at the national high school baseball tournament in Osaka, one of Japan's most popular sporting events. ``I renew my deep sorrow when I think of many people who lost their precious lives in the last war and their survivors. ... I pray for further development of our country and for world peace with all the people in this country, and I would like to present my condolences from the bottom of my heart to those who died on the battlefield and in the war,'' the emperor said. At a separate ceremony, Japan Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi urged the government to admit Japan's responsibility as an aggressor in World War II. Japan has been issuing stronger expressions of remorse for its actions in Asia during the war. When South Korean President Roh Tae-woo visited this spring, for example, Akihito acknowledged that Japan had caused the Korean people a great deal of suffering. While the emperor did not explicitly apologize for Japanese actions, Kaifu did. In the days leading up to the anniversary, newspapers have run accounts from readers recalling the horrors of the atom bombings and the hardships during the war. The English-language Japan Times newspaper ran a series of accounts of atrocities during the war, but most of the Japanese-language media still shy away from such reports.

DOC.HEAD: Report: $5.5 Million Ransom Paid for Release of Swiss Hostage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 8 `Erriquez, 54' to restore dropped words `was held.' Picks up 9th pvs, `Al-Anwar said...'
DOC.TEXT: A Beirut newspaper said Thursday that kidnappers were paid a $5.5 million ransom for freeing two Swiss hostages. Officials in Switzerland, however, have denied making any payoff. The conservative Al-Anwar daily, citing anonymous sources in the southern city of Sidon, did not say who paid the ransom for freeing Emanuel Christen and Elio Erriquez, kidnapped in October. In another development, Iran's deputy foreign minister Thursday called for a goodwill gesture from the West to help gain the release of other hostages in Lebanon, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The Iranian agency, monitored in Nicosia, said Mahmoud Vaezi told visiting Swiss envoy, Klaus Jacobi, the No. 2 official in the Swiss Foreign Ministry, that a goodwill gesture by the West ``would help materialize the freedom of all hostages, whether Iranian or others,'' held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. Switzerland represents American interests in Iran due to the absence of formal Washington-Tehran ties, so Vaezi's call was believed directed at the United States. In its report on the ransom, Al-Anwar said Erriquez's release Monday was delayed for several hours because of the kidnappers' last-minute effort to increase the ransom. ``The kidnappers insisted on collecting the full amount and that the share of the third party which worked as a mediator be added to the previous amount,'' the source said without further elaboration. Erriquez, 24, an orthopedic technician, was held by a group calling itself Palestine Revolutionary Squads. Christen, 33, also an orthopedic expert, was released six days earlier. Both worked for the Red Cross in Lebanon. Al-Anwar said the kidnappers insisted on getting a lump sum and not installments, which prolonged Erriquez' release to give time for the mediators to contact the International Committee of the Red Cross and the Swiss government. It did not elaborate. Both Swiss and Red Cross officials have denied making any deals for the hostages' release. Fourteen Westerners, including six Americans, are believed held hostage in Lebanon, most by pro-Iranian extremists. Longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead In Navy Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: A Navy attack jet crashed Wednesday, killing one crew member and injuring the other, the Navy said. The A-6E Intruder crashed near this town, on a peninsula in the Chesapeake Bay near the Maryland state line. The cause of the crash had yet to be determined, and the names of the dead and injured crew members, said LaDonne McCarthy, a spokeswoman for the Patuxent River Naval Air Test Center in Maryland, where the plane was based.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Move near Canadian Mohawk-Police Standoff Site
DOC.TEXT: An army brigade and a team of world observers took up positions outside Montreal before negotiations began Wednesday to try to settle a land dispute that has led to an armed standoff between police and Mohawks. With the observers in place, the way was cleared for provincial, federal and Mohawk authorities to resume talks that were stalled for a month. They arranged to meet at a hotel in Dorval on the west island of Montreal. Chateauguay, a suburb south of Montreal on the edge of the Kahnawake reserve, has become a flashpoint in the conflict. Mobs of white youths have taken to the streets there the previous three nights, hurling rocks and gasoline bombs at police. The suburb lost its main artery to Montreal with the blockade of the Mercier Bridge, mounted by the Indians five weeks ago in sympathy with fellow Mohawks of Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal. Police and natives have faced each other across barricades at Oka since July 11, when a botched police raid on a Mohawk roadblock claimed the life of a police officer. The roadblock was to halt the planned expansion of a golf course onto territory the Indians say is ancestral land. On Wednesday, jeeps, armored personnel carriers and trucks carrying 2,629 soldiers of the 5th Canadian Mechanized Brigade rolled into communities outside of Montreal. The troops moved from their base at Valcartier, near Quebec City, at the request of Premier Robert Bourassa. The maneuver also involved ambulances, a crane, earth-moving vehicles and a dozen military helicopters. ``We are ready to react if asked to intervene,'' Maj. Serge Quenneville said at a makeshift camp housing a battalion of soldiers in St-Remi, nine miles south of Chateauguay. More troops and supplies were in place at a military base in St-Hubert, south of Montreal, and Longue Pointe in Montreal's east end. Eight observers attached to the Internation Federation of Human Rights stationed themselves at Oka and Kahnawake. ``Since 6 a.m. today the observers have been at both places,'' said Louise Chicoine, an official of the Paris-based group. There are 24 observers in all and they work eight-hour shifts. Under an agreement signed Tuesday by the negotiators, the observers are to man eight positions between police and native barricades at Oka and Kahnawake. In Quebec City, the province's chief negotiator, Alex Paterson, said talks will aim at lifting the barricades. The stage was set for a return to the bargaining table when an agreement was reached Sunday on preconditions, including the role of the international observers and the free passage of provisions and advisers into Mohawk-controlled zones. ``My mandate is pretty vague but it doesn't include native rights or land claims,'' Paterson said. ``It is just to get rid of the barricades.'' On Wednesday, Mohawk leaders said they were anxious to begin talks but they decried the military's stepped-up presence. Provincial and federal authorities say the army's role will be peaceful. Quebec's public security minister, Sam Elkas, said Wednesday said forcibly removing the Mohawk barricades ``would be the last recourse and we want to avoid that.''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Courts Iran; Bush Says U.S. `Way of Life' Threatened
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 29 grafs to UPDATE with Iraqi letter to U.N. Secretary-General criticizing United States, minor editing to conform. Pickup 28th graf pvs, `However, Radio ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NK1
DOC.TEXT: In a bold stroke, Iraq's Saddam Hussein held out a hand of friendship Wednesday to old enemy Iran, proposing a powerful partnership against the Americans who are ``fishing in dirty waters'' in the Persian Gulf. The Iranians sounded receptive to making peace with Iraq _ a potentially troubling note for the U.S. military operation in the Mideast. Iran's spiritual leader condemned the United States as a ``hellish'' power trying to dominate the region. Baghdad radio, meanwhile, said Arab and Palestinian groups were forming in the region to launch suicide attacks on U.S. ships. In Washington, President Bush traveled across the Potomac to the Pentagon, nerve center of the U.S. Mideast mission, and declared that ``no one should doubt our staying power'' in confronting Iraqi expansionism. The American ``way of life'' is threatened by Saddam's growing control of the region's oil, the president told an assembly of military men and women. Bush and Pentagon planners were considering escalating the U.S. mobilization by calling up thousands of reservists to reinforce the regular soldiers, sailors and airmen streaming into Saudi Arabia to face off with the Iraqi army, which two weeks ago invaded and occupied neighboring Kuwait. A fresh U.S. Navy battle group steamed from East Coast ports toward the troubled Mideast, led by the aircraft carrier Kennedy. ``I really don't want him to go,'' one 15-year-old said of his father, a petty officer on the Kennedy. But, the boy said, ``he told me what was happening and explained why he had to go.'' Some in the task force had first-hand knowledge of the gulf's unseen dangers. In 1988, one of the vessels, the guided missile frigate USS Roberts, was heavily damaged by an Iranian mine in the gulf. As Saddam maneuvered and the Pentagon mobilized, immediate hopes for a negotiated solution focused on Jordan's King Hussein, who piloted his own plane to Washington late Tuesday, reportedly bearing a private message for Bush from the Iraqi president. The royal mediator and the U.S. chief executive will meet Thursday at Bush's oceanside retreat in Maine. Concerns heightened daily over the estimated 3,000 American civilians trapped in Kuwait and Iraq. On Wednesday, Turks, Indians, Iranians, Soviets and other foreigners were reported departing Kuwait and Iraq _ or arrangements were announced for their departure _ but the Americans were still barred from leaving and looked increasingly like insurance for the Iraqis against attack. The Iraqis said they seized Kuwait on Aug. 2 to settle economic and territorial grievances. They quickly ``annexed'' the small, wealthy oil state. The U.N. Security Council has ordered a punitive trade embargo against Iraq, and Bush has dispatched thousands of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to defend that oil kingdom against a perceived threat of Iraqi aggression, which he said would also threaten U.S. oil supplies and the U.S. economy. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz accused the United States of pushing through the embargo ``for the purpose of starving and intimidating the people of Iraq, which is a proud people ... and rejects humiliation and subjugation.'' ``The Iraqi people, the Arab nation ... will reject by all legitimate means the attempts of the United States to extend its domination over the world by force, intimidation and deception,'' Aziz said in a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. The text of the letter was released Wednesday. Under growing economic and military pressure, Saddam made a bold move Wednesday, offering Iran favorable terms for final peace in the devastating 1980-88 war between Iran and Iraq. In a letter to Iran's President Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Iraqi president said his country, beginning Friday, would withdraw its troops from Iranian territories occupied in the war and free the tens of thousands of Iranian prisoners of war it has held, in exchange for a peace treaty. Saddam called for ``a new life of cooperation'' between Iran and Iraq, ``so we can deter all those fishing in dirty waters and cooperate to turn the gulf into a lake of peace free of foreign fleets.'' In Tehran, a spokesman for Iran's Supreme National Security Council said the proposal would be reviewed ``with optimism.'' The Iranian foreign minister called the Iraqi concessions Iran's ``greatest victory.'' Iran's Cabinet met late Wednesday to consider the plan. Although Tehran has condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, on Wednesday directed new bitterness toward the United States and the Saudi and other oil autocracies in the region. Speaking to a religious audience, the Moslem cleric said foreign powers were in the region only to fight ``over material interests and resources.'' He said a ``hellish establishment'' was dominating the world. If Saddam wins Iranian agreement, it would at least relieve the military pressure on the Iraq-Iran border and allow him to divert troops to his southern frontier with Saudi Arabia. At the most, a deal might allow isolated Iraq to conduct trade through Iran and give Saddam a potential military partner for harassing or confronting U.S. forces in the region. In the face of international boycott, Iraq's main outlet now is Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba. But Bush is expected to press King Hussein to close that seaport to Iraqi goods. Otherwise, the U.S. Navy will probably set up a maritime cordon off Aqaba to block Iraqi trade. Trucks, many with distictive yellow Iraqi license plates, on Wednesday were seen streaming northward out of Aqaba on the road to Amman, and presumably continuing hundreds of miles on the desert highway to Baghdad. Said one official at an Aqaba port facility, ``They appear to be in a hurry to get as much Iraq-bound cargo to that destination before the sanction loophole at Aqaba is closed.'' American and British warships maintained a close watch on sea traffic Wednesday in the Persian Gulf. Radio monitors said the British frigate HMS Jupiter, for example, called two or three commercial ships in the morning to ask their destination and cargo. The U.S. Navy has massed 27 ships, including three carriers, in the gulf, the nearby Arabian Sea and the Red Sea. ``We are not going to yield to pressure. We are not going to yield to this kind of intimidation,'' Aziz, the Iraqi foreign minister, said Wednesday in an interview with ABC News. ``Iraq is not going to initiate a war.'' However, Radio Baghdad, in a broadcast later Wednesday, said, ``Arab and Palestinian suicidal groups arrived in the gulf area and said that they are ready to launch suicidal attacks against the American ships which are imposing blockade against Iraq.'' The broadcast, monitored in Washington on shortwave radio, gave no details. The Bush administration asserts a right to ``interdict'' vessels under the U.N. Security Council resolution ordering the anti-Iraq economic sanctions. But even some U.S. allies disagree, saying the council itself must approve a blockade. Australia's foreign minister, Gareth Evans, backed down Tuesday from previous government statements that three Australian warships headed for the region would stop vessels violating the sanctions. Instead, he said, the Australians would only interrogate and warn such ships against breaking the embargo. The State Department, seeking to end such misunderstandings, has been conferring with representatives of other major powers about putting the Mideast naval forces under a U.N. flag or U.N. command. The Security Council may take up the issue after hearing a report Friday on international compliance with the embargo.
DOC.HEAD: An effective, graf 1, a0656
Nations Join U.N. Sanctions, but Some May Want Help
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Libya's Gadhafi calling for Security Council meeting to condemn U.S. intervention in Gulf. Pickup 5th pvs, `Jordanian diplomats...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The vast majority of nations say they are complying with a U.N. embargo on Iraq, but envoys of some poor countries said Wednesday they may seek compensation from the world body to offset financial losses. The U.N. ambassadors said no country has formally sought assistance from the U.N. Security Coucil to make up for the loss they incurred by joining the sanctions. However, they said unofficial talks on the issue are under way. A U.N. committee is studying compliance of the 159 U.N. members with the embargo. That body is to meet Friday, and a report is expected later this month. Meanwhile, Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi called on Wednesday for the Security Council to hold a meeting in Geneva to condemn U.S. military intervention in the Persian Gulf in order to prevent a ``needless calamity.'' U.N. officials said that so far no council meeting had been scheduled and consultations on Gadhafi's request were expected. ``Any troops that are in the gulf that do not carry the banner of the United Nations or that are not formed by the Security Council and under its command are regarded as troops of colonialist invasion and should be resisted,'' Gadhafi told the Libyan news agency in a dispatch monitored in Rome. Virtually all envoys who have commented publicly stressed their nations were honoring the sweeping sanctions. Jordanian diplomats declined comment, citing the delicacy of the topic and the arrival of King Hussein to discuss the crisis Thursday with President Bush. Jordan, which has close ties with Iraq, has not put the sanctions into effect and has allowed commercial traffic bound for Iraq to use its Red Sea port of Aqaba. Bush has threatened to close that port. On Aug. 9, Bulgaria informed U.N. officials it was honoring the embargo ``in spite of the serious difficulties that this would create for the Bulgarian economy.'' Ambassador Dimitar Kostova said in a letter that Bulgaria reserves its right to address the Security Council under the U.N. Charter. Under Charter Article 50, any state that faces special economic problems because of Security Council enforcement action may consult the Council about a solution. Relief is not specified but could include exemption and appeals for compensation. The Council adopted mandatory economic sanctions against Iraq on Aug. 6, banning all imports, exports and even indirect financial dealings with Iraq and Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2. The sanctions includes most food deliveries but exempt medical supplies and, under special humanitarian circumstances, food. Ivan Sotirov, another Bulgarian U.N. envoy, emphasized Wednesday that Bulgaria was ``living up to its commitment'' to observe the quarantine. ``But we must admit, we feel the pinch,'' he said in an interview. Bulgaria is a major transporter and transit point for commerce between Europe and the gulf region. Iraq owes Bulgaria about $1.2 billion, Sotirov said. Iraq was paying Bulgaria mostly in oil deliveries, he said, and this year Bulgaria stands to lose an estimated $140 million because all commerce has stopped with Iraq and Kuwait. Bulgaria also has doubled the price of gasoline because of the oil shortage, he said. Sri Lankan Ambassador Daya Perera said his government was also supporting the embargo. But he added that Sri Lanka faces ``a tremendous hardship'' as a result and may eventually seek U.N. relief. He said Iraq buys about 25 percent of Sri Lanka's tea and provides oil to his nation.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Predict Containment Of Several Major Wildfires
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with partial reopening of Yosemite park planned for Friday. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `For the third...
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters contained several major forest fires Wednesday and experts said they were confident the blazes will soon be fully controlled. Three big fires in Yosemite National Park were all expected to be contained within lines of bare earth by Friday night, officials said. The park was closed to visitors Aug. 9 because of the fire danger. The park will be partly reopened Friday, officials announced. A highway through the park across the Sierra Nevada range will be opened, but Yosemite Valley, the main tourist destination, will remain closed until at least Monday. For the third day in a row, fire bosses gave highest priority to the Finley Lake fire in Tehama County in northern California, which had burned 21,880 acres as of Wednesday and was 70 percent contained. There was no estimate of when the fire burning 230 miles northeast of San Francisco would be contained, said Dwayne Collier of the California Department of Forestry. The Finley Lake fire, which threatened about 1,600 homes earlier this week, was within four miles of the town of Manton but it didn't appear to pose a threat, Collier said. Forest and range fires also burned in parts of Alaska, Arizona, Idaho, Wyoming, Montana, Oregon and Washington state, said the National Fire Information Center in Boise, Idaho. So far this year, the Boise Interagency Fire Center has shipped 1.9 million tons of firefighting supplies at a cost of $11.3 million, officials said. In Yosemite, the A-Rock fire, which burned across 17,000 acres, was 70 percent contained Wednesday and was expected to be fully contained by Friday evening, said Collier. The Steamboat fire, which burned 4,400 acres and was 60 percent contained, was expected to be fully contained by Thursday evening, he said. The T-Grove 4 fire, covering 4,700 acres, was 90 percent contained with full containment expected by Thursday night, Collier said. Other small fires also burned in the 757,000-acre park, but none on the valley floor where tourists congregate. A total of 22,100 acres in the park had been burned as of Wednesday, Collier said. The T-Grove 4 fire was less than two miles from Merced Grove, a stand of ancient sequoia trees, but didn't pose an immediate threat to the grove, Collier said. However, smaller trees burning along the park's roads might keep the park closed, officials said. Burning trees were still toppling onto roads, said Janet Buzzini of the U.S. Parks Service. ``We cannot open the park until we get those closest to the roads down,'' she said, adding that falling rocks, crews and equipment posed additional hazards. ``It's really not safe yet.'' The first of 1,200 Army troops from the 4th Infantry Division in Fort Carson, Colo., began arriving Tuesday to help with the Finley fire. Tehama County, the Campbell complex fire _ the largest of the siege of fires that spread across the northern part of the state this month _ had burned across 115,000 acres and was 85 percent contained Wednesday, Collier said. In the community of Foresta near Yosemite, 66 homes were burned earlier this week. A total of 250,956 acres of California has been burned by an estimated 1,300 wildfires since Aug. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Gives Commanders OK to Interdict Shipments With `Minimum Force'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs files, makes minor editing changes and trims from end to tighten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush authorized naval commanders to use ``the minimum force necessary'' to interdict shipments to and from Iraq, a senior administration source said Wednesday. The president's message was expected to be sent Thursday to the U.S. Navy fleet in Middle East waters, the source said. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the instruction described a step-by-step approach under which commanders should first request ships to halt and to seek their cooperation before taking any more aggressive steps. Those steps could include attempting to block the ship's passage or firing warning shot across the bow. A minimum use of force might include steps taken to disable the ship so that it couldn't continue on its way, the source said. ``It will tell them to use the minimum force necessary,'' said the source. Ever since Bush has spoken of his barricade against Iraqi commerce, administration officials have said they hoped the mere threat of a possible confrontation would deter unarmed merchant vessels from carrying Iraqi cargo. In a pep talk address at the Pentagon earlier Wednesday, Bush vowed to use the massive infusion of U.S. military might in the region to put a stranglehold around Iraq and force it to abandon Kuwait. ``Together we must ensure that no goods get in and that not one drop of oil gets out,'' he said. The source said the president had actually approved the minimum use of force ``a couple of days ago'' but that the directive had gone through a rigorous intra-agency approval process. Departments such as State and Commerce were brought into the process because of the delicate nature involved in dealing with a situation where shipments might be carried by ships flagged by third countries. A preliminary message was sent out to commanders late Wednesday but was pulled back for revision and the formal final directive was scheduled to be sent to the fleet early Thursday, the source said. The official did not define what the problem was, describing it only as a minor glitch. Bush spent 90 minutes at the Pentagon getting an update on Operation Desert Shield from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin Powell. The issue of a possible callup of the nation's reservists was discussed but no decision has been made, the source said. Another matter still under study is the development of a joint command for the tens of thousands of U.S. soldiers and their international counterparts sent to Saudi Arabia to defend the oil-rich kingdom from the threat of an attack by Iraq. ``There has been progress made, but we're not there yet on that one,'' the source said. Underlining the president's words, the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy and its eight-ship battle group left Norfolk, Va., for the Middle East and Pentagon officials said aircraft leaving soon would include F-117A stealth fighters. Defense Department sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 22 of the radar-evading fighters, which saw their first combat in Panama last December, would leave for the Persian Gulf on Thursday. Meanwhile, the State Department said more than 2 million foreigners, including about 3,000 Americans, were being kept from leaving Iraq and the small nation it invaded two weeks ago. A spokeswoman said Iraq had promised ``new guidelines'' on foreigners' travel rights, but officials said privately they doubted any changes would mean the Americans could leave. Noting that an Iraqi official had been quoted as referring to the foreigners as ``restrictees,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said, ``Finally, they are admitting behavior that is contrary to all international norms.'' However, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said merely, ``That's not an official description and not what the government has told us.'' Bush's remarks came one day before he was to meet with Jordan's King Hussein, who has continued to allow supplies to flow into Saddam Hussein's Iraq despite a United Nations trade embargo. The king, who has put himself forward as a mediator in the crisis, was said to be carrying a message from Saddam to the president's Maine vacation home on Thursday. Fitzwater said the White House had no indication there was such a message but was ``willing to listen'' to Hussein. The spokesman said Saddam's public peace overture toward longtime adversary Iran ``doesn't appear to have any impact'' on the Mideast crisis except as ``another effort to separate the countries and create a diversion.'' Bush also will meet with Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, and Ambassador Prince Bandar bin Sultan on Thursday following his talks with King Hussein, Fitzwater said Wednesday night. ``The meeting will allow further consultations between the two countries as agreed to by the president and King Fahd,'' the spokesman said. Bush returned to Kennebunkport, Maine, shortly after his Pentagon remarks, less than 24 hours after arriving in Washington for meetings, a news conference and Wednesday's speech. The president also was expected to get cost estimates for the huge operation and to discuss whether to call up the nation's armed forces reserves and National Guard to bolster units depleted by the Gulf crisis. Fitzwater said later that Cheney had not reached a decision on the reserves. In his speech, Bush offered no new information on the questions of how many U.S. troops will go to the Mideast and how long they will stay. In the event full-scale conflict, the Pentagon has made plans to ship up to 250,000 soldiers to the region. Defending his decision to dispatch tens of thousands of U.S. combat troops and dozens of warships halfway around the globe, Bush said nothing less than world order is at stake. Bush denounced what he called Saddam's ``raw territorial ambition'' and attempts to portray the conflict as ``a holy war of Arab against Infidel,'' a struggle between ``the haves and the have-nots.'' The president said the U.S. action was important to maintain access to energy resources that are key to America's way of life and to the world's economy. But he also said, ``We are striking a blow for the principle that might does not make right. Kuwait is small. but one conquered nation is one too many.'' Calling once again for Iraq's immediate and complete withdrawal from Kuwait, the restoration of Kuwait's government, and the protection of all Americans caught up in the conflict, Bush warned Saddam not to ``doubt our staying power or our determination.'' As long as Iraq ignores the need for international order, Bush said, ``peace and freedom are impossible. The rule of law gives way to the law of the jungle.'' ``It is Saddam who invaded an Arab state. It is Saddam who now threatens the Arab nation,'' he said. ``We, by contrast, seek to assist our Arab friends in their hour of need.'' At the State Department, officials said Americans stuck in Kuwait are running out of cash, and the U.S. Embassy has been advancing some of them money. In Iraq, Ms. Tutwiler said, the 500 or so Americans are able to move about _ but not to leave the country _ except for the 39 held in a hotel in Baghdad. Again, she cautioned against their trying to leave either country, saying that would entail ``serious risk.'' But she also kept to the administration's stance that the Americans should not be described as hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets To Evacuate Civilians from Kuwait, Americans Remain
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS two grafs after 8th graf `The Americans' to UPDATE with news report about group of Americans restricted to Baghdad hotel. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `Ms. Tutwiler...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union prepared to evacuate its citizens from Iraq and Kuwait and at least 3,600 foreigners reached Jordan overland from Baghdad on Wednesday. Western governments demanded that Iraq grant Westerners freedom to leave. About 3,000 Americans, 3,000 Britons, 500 Italians and more than 450 Japanese were stranded in Iraq and Kuwait. Overall, more than 2 million foreigners are in both countries. A Jordanian border official said at least 3,600 foreigners from 19 countries, including Poles, Pakistanis, Sri Lankans and Somalis, had crossed Wednesday evening at the Ruweishid border post, about 200 miles northeast of Amman. No North Americans, West Europeans or Japanese were among them, said the official, who cannot be identified under standing regulations. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in Washington that an Iraqi Foreign Ministry official informed a U.S. diplomat in Baghdad on Tuesday that ``new guidelines'' were being prepared governing travel rights for the stranded Americans, but no new guidelines had been disclosed as of Wednesday. Privately, U.S. officials said they doubted the rule changes would let Americans leave. Iraq's ambassador to Greece, Abdel Fetah al-Khazreji, said Tuesday in Athens that Americans and others could leave ``as soon as the threats from the United States and its allies are eliminated.'' ABC quoted a Foreign Ministry official in Baghdad as saying Americans in Iraq were ``restrictees'' who would stay until the crisis was over. Ms. Tutwiler said, ``We have been telling you for days these people are restricted from leaving. . . . Finally, . . . (the Iraqis) are admitting behavior that is contrary to all international norms.'' The Americans were caught in the war of nerves. Although the Americans were not being called hostages, U.S. officials suspected that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein might try to use them as blackmail if his confrontation with the United States worsened. While most Westerners are free to travel around within Iraq and Kuwait, one group of 36 Americans and two Britons has been restricted to a luxury hotel in Baghdad, according to ABC News. An ABC correspondent said the detainees in the hotel are ``being treated rather well,'' spending much of their day at the hotel pool, but ``seem to be under enormous tension'' and are afraid they will be stuck in Iraq until the crisis ends. Ms. Tutwiler said banks in Kuwait were still closed and the U.S. Embassy was giving cash to stranded, strapped-for-money Americans. An estimated 500 Americans slipped out of Kuwait after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. The State Department has been discouraging Americans from trying to leave since British businessman Douglas Thomas Croskery, 49, was shot to death while trying to flee into Saudi Arabia on Saturday. In northern England, Croskery's widow, Thelma, 45, appealed to Iraqi authorities to send her husband's body home for burial. ``Can they not realize that I am torturing myself that my husband's body is lying in the sand for days and I want him home?'' she said. Iraq has agreed to allow all 880 Soviets in Kuwait to leave, but only by a 1,200-mile road through Iraq to the Iraqi-Jordanian border. All Soviet women, children and invalids will be permitted to leave Iraq, but not Soviet men. Officials have not said how many of the 9,000 Soviets in Iraq are men. There are 193 Soviet military advisers in Iraq. In Moscow, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said the first group of 230 evacuees were assembling in Baghdad on Wednesday. He said intense desert heat and lack of transportation hampered evacuation plans. Italy's Foreign Ministry on Wednesday accused Iraq of showing an ``absolute lack of respect for fundamental human rights'' by refusing to say when it would let Westerners leave. It said European Community ambassadors to Iraq, including Italy's envoy, met Wednesday with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Baghdad and asked that foreigners be allowed to depart but met with a ``very disappointing'' response. In Tokyo, the Foreign Ministry said Iraq was asked to let Japanese nationals leave after six Japanese were denied permission to go to Jordan. About 230 Japanese business people remained in Iraq, after all Japanese on tourist visas were permitted to leave. The ministry said the Japanese Embassy in Kuwait was sheltering 246 Japanese citizens.

DOC.HEAD: N.J. Governor Asks New Jersey Residents for Patience on Tax Plan
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Jim Florio on Wednesday night asked state residents angered by higher taxes for patience, vowing in a rare televised address that his plans would benefit many and keep New Jersey's economy strong. Calling the $2.8 billion in tax increases a ``good investment that will take time,'' Florio said it would ease skyrocketing property taxes and improve schools. In his 25-minute speech, the governor acknowledged that his popularity has waned because of the proposal, which prompted several anti-tax campaigns by citizens groups. ``Would I like to be the most popular governor in the history of New Jersey?'' Florio asked. ``Sure. Who wouldn't? ``But not if it means sacrificing the future for my grandchildren. Not if it means losing the quality of life we cherish in New Jersey,'' he said. The Democratic governor blasted his Republican predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, for leaving a $600 million budget deficit that Florio said made tax increases necessary. The governor, who requested the prime-time slot, spoke from the studios of WWOR-TV in Secaucus across the Hudson River from New York City. His speech was carried by television and radio stations across New Jersey. In a Republican response to the governor's speech, Assembly Minority Leader Chuck Haytaian appealed to the anti-tax groups, saying the tax hikes will harm the state's economy. Haytaian said the increases ``insult the intelligence of New Jerseyans,'' and have spawned ``New Jersey's summer of discontent.'' Florio's popularity plummeted in a recent newspaper poll in what experts said was a tax backlash. The governor's plan included raising the sales tax from 6 percent to 7 percent, and expanded to cover previously untaxed products, including toilet paper. The sales tax and other levies went into effect last month, and a higher income tax for about 17 percent of the state's residents takes effect next year. The new taxes will be used to close the deficit, pump more than $1 billion in new money to schools and reduce property taxes. The plan also includes a shifting of state dollars from richer school districts to poorer ones. The new taxes, passed by a wary state Legislature in June, have been sharply criticized. ``You've heard about the people going around, getting petitions signed, demanding we undo what's just been done, before it even gets a chance to work,'' Florio said. ``Well, I can't help feeling most people are more patient. They have questions, not demands. They're not yelling. They're more interested in answers than confrontation.'' Florio denied that he lied during last year's campaign when he said he saw no need for new taxes. ``I believed we would have the surplus money Governor Kean said we would,'' Florio said. ``I was wrong.'' Florio said a $274 million surplus quickly became a $600 million spending gap in the budget he inherited from Kean, forcing him to make cuts in state departments and raise the sales taxes and levies on liquor, cigarettes and oil. Haytaian blasted the tax plan as one that will hurt many residents, particularly middle-class homeowners in rich areas that stand to lose education dollars. ``The grassroots tax revolt that is sweeping our state was born out of the anger and frustration of yet another political promise broken and yet another political promise for property tax relief,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students Hurl Firebombs at U.S. Army Facility
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with U.S. Army facility attacked near Seoul, details. Picks up graf 4th pvs, `The leftist...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SEL4,SEL9
DOC.TEXT: Radical students hurling firebombs and shouting anti-American slogans attacked a U.S. Army facility Thursday near downtown Seoul, police and officials said. ``We oppose the U.S. and demand unification of the fatherland!'' yelled about 60 radicals who tossed firebombs at the U.S. Army's Corps of Engineers building, witnesses said. On Wednesday, thousands of leftist students clashed with riot police who blocked them from marching to the border for a unification rally. Police said 350 people were arrested and more than 100 others hurt. But about 2,000 people were allowed to rally peacefully near the heavily fortified border with Communist North Korea. They were protesting what they said was the North's unwillingness to allow them to visit relatives in North Korea. The protests overshadowed what would have been a festive mood for the 45th anniversary Wednesday of Korea's liberation from Japanese colonial rule. The holiday is observed in both Koreas. In Thursday's incident, students pelted riot police with firebombs as they fled, police said. One student was arrested, they said. It was not known how many people were inside the building at the time of Thursday's attack, but a spokesman for the U.S. 8th Army said there were no injuries and no significant damage. The leftist rally at Seoul's Yonsei University turned violent as some 10,000 student radicals and dissidents, throwing rocks and firebombs, tried to march off campus to go to the border. About 2,000 riot police, backed by a dozen armored vans equipped with tear gas launchers, blocked all entrances to the school. Police said about 350 people were arrested and more than 100 injured in the two-hour clash at Yonsei and in protests in other parts of the capital. The protests were limited to a section of the capital and along the main highway to Panmunjom, a border village 35 miles north of Seoul where the pro-unification rally was to be held. The border village is off-limits to civilians and no one can enter the area without the approval of the two Korean governments. Authorities deployed 16,000 police in Seoul and along the main highway leading to Panmunjom, the destination of the march. ``Let's drive out U.S. imperialists!'' radical students chanted as riot police blocked their march. Protesters demand the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty be withdrawn immediately. They claim the U.S. military presence hinders dialogue with North Korea. ``Kill me!'' one student shouted, ramming against shields held by riot police in front of her. Police kicked and punched some arrested students. Under a South Korean proposal, the 155-mile border was to have opened for five days beginning Monday. The opening has not taken place because both sides failed to agree on conditions. The two Koreas have been bitter rivals since the division of the peninsula in 1945. They fought a three-year war in the early 1950s. The border is heavily fortified and there is no mail or other forms of regular communication between the two sides. In Seoul, President Roh Tae-woo indicated that the government may offer another temporary border opening around Chusok, the Korean thanksgiving day, which falls on Oct. 3. ``Free travel between the South and the North is an indispensable step toward unification,'' Roh said. He also called for talks with North Korea on pending issues such as arms control and the establishment of permanent representative missions in the Korean capitals.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq, Busy on Other Fronts, Makes Peace Proposal to Iran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 23 grafs to UPDATE with Iraqi foreign minister requesting U.N. assistance on troop withdrawal, Iran's U.N. ambassador saying Tehran will continue to abide by sanctions. Pickup 20th graf pvs, `Even if...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's Saddam Hussein, in a move that could free military manpower and ease the stranglehold of economic sanctions, offered Wednesday to make peace with his longtime enemy, Iran. Iran greeted the proposal ``with optimism'' but said a thorough study was needed. That country's Islamic Republic News Agency said President Hashemi Rafsanjani and his Cabinet were meeting to discuss the proposal. Iran and Iraq never formally settled their eight-year war, although it ended with a cease-fire in August 1988. In his proposal, the Iraqi leader said he would pull troops out of territories seized from Iran and free Iranian prisoners of war. He also suggested he was relinquishing the Iraqi claim to full control of the strategic Shatt-al-Arab waterway to the Persian Gulf. Those were major points of disagreement that stalled peace talks almost from the time they began, five days after the 1988 cease-fire. In addition, Iraq allowed Iranians trapped by the invasion of Kuwait to leave. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said the first of the estimated 100,000 Iranians in Kuwait arrived in Iran on Wednesday. The Iraqi president outlined his peace proposal in a letter to Rafsanjani. A broadcaster read it over Baghdad radio, which was monitored in Nicosia. Saddam indirectly called for an alliance with Tehran against the United States, saying the Persian Gulf should be ``a lake of peace free of foreign fleets and forces that harbor ill intentions against us.'' The Iraqi president said he was ``looking forward to a new life of cooperation on the principles of Islam and respect of each other's rights.'' Iran has denounced Iraq's Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait, but it has also criticized the buildup of thousands of Western troops in Saudi Arabia to deter any Iraqi attack. Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, reiterated criticism Wednesday of ``any sort of aggression in the region'' and said Iran considers ``the presence of American forces in Saudi Arabia ... to the detriment of Islam and Moslems and against the Islamic revolution.'' His remarks were carried by the Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, before the Baghdad announcement. Iran's press trumpeted Saddam's proposals with large headlines, but one newspaper cautioned that Iran should not become more embroiled in the gulf conflict. ``Peace between two regional powers is certainly conducive to peace, stability and security for the whole region,'' said the English-language Tehran Times in an editorial made available in advance of publication Thursday. But the paper, which often reflects Rafsanjani's thinking, said Iran's leaders ``should not allow the country to get involved in a crisis that might prove detrimental to our own national interest and security.'' Saddam said the troop withdrawal and the prisoner release would start Friday. He did not specify the size of the territory from which his troops would withdraw, and the number of Iraqi troops involved was not known. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz sent a message to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar asking him to instruct the head of the U.N. Iran-Iraq Military Observer Group to cooperate with Iraqi authorities in the troop withdrawal, Iraqi national radio said Wednesday. Iran claims Iraq holds 772 square miles of territory occupied in the final weeks of the war. The United Nations says the area is half that size. In any event, a peace treaty with Tehran would ease pressure on Saddam to defend the 730-mile frontier with Iran, Iraq's longest border. Saddam could also be hoping Tehran would break with the rest of Iraq's neighbors and allow food and other goods to pass through Iranian territory to Iraq. But Kamal Kharrazi, Iran's ambassador to the United Nations, said Tehran remained opposed to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and would continue to abide by U.N. economic sanctions. ``We cannot accept aggression against another Islamic country and annexation of that country to another country,'' Kharrazi told the BBC. ``The settlement of the dispute between Iran and Iraq does not necessarily mean any sort of support or so-called help toward that country. ... Certainly we have our principles and we are committed to the resolutions adopted by the Security Council,'' he said. Even if Iran formally maintained an embargo, a relaxation of military strength on the border would be a bonanza for smugglers. The Iraqi president said he wanted to settle the dispute over a 1975 treaty that divided the Shatt-al-Arab waterway, which forms the gulf border between the nations. Saddam abrogated the treaty before invading Iran in September 1980 and had claimed full control of the Shatt al-Arab as one of the main fruits of the war. It remains closed to shipping. Iran immediately interpreted Saddam's announcement Wednesday as dropping the claim to the full waterway. Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, speaking on Tehran Radio, called it ``the greatest victory of the Islamic Republic of Iran in its history.'' As for prisoners of war, the Red Cross has registered 50,000 prisoners held by Iran and 19,000 Iranians in Iraqi hands. But United Nations and other officials have estimated the total number at 100,000, some of them held since the early days of the war. The International Committee of the Red Cross headquarters in Geneva said Iraq had asked it to handle the repatriation, beginning with 2,000 Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Closing Arguments Begin In Flying While Intoxicated Case
DOC.TEXT: Three former Northwest Airlines pilots used an ``Alice In Wonderland'' defense at their trial on charges they flew while drunk, a federal prosecutor said Wednesday in closing arguments. Assistant U.S. Attorney Elizabeth de la Vega said the defense attempted to make a routine flight look difficult and at one point contended it was easier to fly during an emergency. She said the pilots also told of being sober when common sense and blood-alcohol tests showed obvious impairment. ``It tells you a lot about the defense in this case. It sounds like Alice in Wonderland,'' de la Vega told the U.S. District Court jury. ``They say it's hard to fly if it's easy, but it's easy to fly if it's an emergency.'' William Mauzy, attorney for First Officer Robert Kirchner, said in his closing argument that de la Vega had no evidence of alcohol impairment and that her case was an appeal to public fears about flying with drunken pilots. ``What we have in this case is Stealth impairment,'' Mauzy said, ``impairment that hasn't been detected.'' Kirchner, 36, of Highland Ranch, Colo.; Captain Norman Lyle Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga.; and Flight Engineer Joseph Balzer, 35, of Antioch, Tenn., have been on trial since July 25 on charges of operating an aircraft while under the influence of alcohol. If convicted, each man faces up to 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The three were arrested after their March 8 flight from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis. In tests about two hours after the flight, Kirchner's blood-alcohol was 0.06 percent; Balzer's 0.08 percent; and Prouse 0.13 percent. In many states the legal limit for driving a car is 0.10 percent. The case marks the U.S. Justice Department's first prosecution under a 1988 federal law prohibiting operation of a common carrier while under the influence. The law doesn't specify an illegal blood-alcohol content. To find the aviators guilty, jurors must conclude they were impaired by alcohol even though there were no problems with the flight. Judge James Rosenbaum said he would instruct the jury Thursday after Balzer's attorney, Bruce Hanley, gives his closing argument. De la Vega said she would present a rebuttal closing argument. Prouse's attorney, Peter Wold, maintained that his client, an alcoholic, has a stiff tolerance to alcohol from 35 years of drinking. ``It's not hocus-pocus to suggest there are different tolerances for alcohol,'' Wold said. Proving impairment doesn't require proof that the pilots were staggering or that the flight was flawed, de la Vega said. The law only requires that she prove the pilots did not have the ``clearness of intellect and control that they otherwise would have,'' she said. Mauzy said, ``What's going on here is an appeal to fear. It's a scary thought to think that a pilot with a little alcohol in his blood would go flying.'' But while the public may think its unsafe for pilots to drink the night before a flight, Mauzy said, it's not against the law. There is an FAA prohibition against flying within eight hours of drinking, but the pilots are not on trial for that. Kirchner and Balzer said they did not break the rule, but all three were fired for violating Northwest's 12-hour prohibition against drinking before flying.
