DOC.BYLINE: Cable Networks Mostly Avoid Networks' September ^By JAY SHARBUTT
DOC.TEXT: Come September, the networks' annual banzai charge of new and returning shows will begin in earnest, with 35 new series on tap. But don't expect a counterbarrage then of new shows from cable TV. Although cable now is plugged into 58.6 percent of the nation's households and at least five new cable series will arrive next month, cable networks still generally avoid the September rush. The idea, say cable executives, is to avoid getting stomped by the megabuck ``watch-us'' campaigns of ABC, CBS and NBC. ``That is the primary reason for us,'' says Kay Koplovitz, president of USA Network, a cable heavyweight with nearly 53 million subscribers. ``We feel that we're more competitive introducing series at different times of the year.'' Although the fall campaigns of the Big Three have become more frenzied in recent years as audiences defect to cable and independent stations, cable's annual ``watch-us'' campaign still is held in April. Unlike the networks' big month, April is more a display of what cable has to offer than the premiere month for a flood of new series. ``Cable launches new programs all year around,'' says Turner Entertainment Networks President Gerry Hogan, sounding the traditional slogan of his industry. And instead of cable eventually joining the September Stomp, ``I think it'll change the other way,'' says Hogan, who runs Ted Turner's TNT network and TBS SuperStation network. ``I think the networks are going to recognize that what we do is more correct in the current television environment,'' Hogan says. Even though viewing levels are lowest in the summertime, cable programmers at times premiere new shows then, the idea being to offer an alternative to network reruns, busted pilots and a few awful summer series. Last month, for example, the extra-fee Home Box Office service offered a sitcom, ``Dream On,'' and the USA Network began ``Counterstrike,'' an action-adventure epic co-starring Christopher Plummer in his first series. But some of the larger cable networks now appear to be gradually edging into the fall fray with a mix of new series and former network series that in pre-cable days would have been syndicated to local TV stations. Example: On Sept. 7, the USA Network starts a new half-hour fantasy series, ``Swamp Thing,'' adding that to new episodes of three other existing made-for-USA series, including ``Counterstrike.'' Another newcomer, ``Uncle Pooch,'' about a talking dog, is due in October. But USA also has some potent Old Reliables from the networks, too, arriving in September. On Monday, Sept. 17, the unofficial start date of the new TV season, it will start Monday-through-Friday repeats of ``MacGyver.'' Later in the month, it will add repeats of ``Just The Ten of Us'' to its current rerun roster of ``Crime Story,'' ``Miami Vice,'' ``The Equalizer'' and ``Murder, She Wrote.'' On Sept. 3, the Lifetime cable network, targeted at women and in 49.7 million homes, will premiere an ambitious double-barrelled project that will be seen Monday through Friday evenings. Its weeknights will start with the one-hour, Canadian-built ``E.N.G.,'' which, like CBS' ``Murphy Brown'' and new ``WIOU'' series, has a TV newsroom setting. ``E.N.G.,'' which takes the drama of news seriously, will be followed by repeats of NBC's ``L.A. Law.'' Those who denounced CBS for axing ``Beauty and the Beast'' probably will cheer the Family Channel next month. It will run its first repeat of the series Sept. 7 and start the show's weekly run Sept. 21. But the Family Channel, serving nearly 53 million homes, also has three new series arriving in September, the most of any cable network. Two are sitcoms, ``Maniac Mansion,'' and ``Big Brother Jake.'' The latter features Jake Steinfeld, body-builder to the stars, in his acting debut. He plays a Hollywood stuntman who returns to the old neighborhood in Brooklyn to care for a group of foster children. Old pro Mickey Rooney, who was nominated for an Oscar in 1979 as the trainer in ``The Black Stallion,'' will reprise that role in the third new series, ``The Adventures of the Black Stallion.'' The Family Channel also next month is bringing back three other series it premiered in past seasons _ ``Rin Tin Tin K-9 Cop,'' ``Bordertown'' and the new version of ``Zorro.'' On the news front, the Arts & Entertainment Network will premiere on Sept. 20 a new, British-made current events series, ``World in Action,'' hosted for American viewers by Bill Kurtis, former anchor of the ``CBS Morning News.''

Elsewhere in television ... DEPT. OF WHEN WILL IT STOP?: Effective Aug. 27, the number of TV households in the U.S. will be 93.1 million, according to A.C. Nielsen estimates. That's up one million from 1989-90, and 19.5 million more than in the halcyon season of 1979-80.

For Release PMs Thursday, Aug. 16
DOC.HEAD: A ``Boring'' Economic Slowdown
DOC.TEXT: An indicator of smaller business optimism has fallen to its lowest level since 1982, suggesting the economy isn't likely to regain strength before the end of the year. The indicator, an index based on analysis of more than 2,000 responses from members of the National Federation of Independent Business, was completed before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``Developments in the Mideast will undoubtedly increase uncertainty,'' said William Dunkelberg, who interprets the results. Dunkelberg, an economist, is dean of Temple University's school of business and management. He said the deterioration in confidence reflects an economy that ``is going down, at least for the count of 2 or 3,'' but that no particular aspect of the economic situation could be blamed more than another. Rather, said Dunkelberg, ``each index component continued to reflect the slow deterioration apparent in the data for some time,'' an erosion he describes as slow motion. The index, begun by Dunkelberg in 1974, is based on detailed responses regarding expected business conditions, climate for expansion, sales volume, credit conditions, job openings, capital outlays, inventories, hiring and more. These responses are formulated into the index, which ranks 1978 conditions as 100. It fell to a seasonally adjusted all-time low of 81.1 in the second quarter of 1980 and reached its high of 108.7 in 1984's first quarter. The latest reading of 98.2 for the third quarter 1990, down from 100.8 in the second quarter, was the lowest since 95.3 was recorded in the third quarter of 1982. Shortly thereafter the index ascended into 100-plus levels. While the index is valued as a measurement of private-sector strength or weakness, it is watched also because of its fairly accurate record in forecasting future economic conditions. Based on responses to the latest survey, Dunkelberg believes the inflation outlook may continue to improve, that pressure from labor costs may ease and that the jobless rate likely will edge up as the year ends. Still, he believes inflation fears will prevent the Federal Reserve from any major easing of credit conditions. At best, he suggests, the Fed will make ``ease noises'' rather than take strong action. The companies on which Dunkelberg's analyses are based, all members of the National Federation, range from very small companies _ proprietorships and the like _ to companies with annual sales of more than $100 million. None of these companies would qualify by size for lists of the 1,000 largest companies, which generally are said to constitute ``big business.'' Broadly categorized, therefore, they are ``small.'' The community they represent, the federation says, involves a vast and varied number of companies employing about one-half the nation's private, non-farm work forces and producing about 50 percent of gross national product. As such, says Dunkelberg, they provide a grass-roots view of attitudes and experiences that add up to an accurate picture of present conditions and an indication of what lies ahead economically. While reminding people that the survey was conducted shortly before the latest oil problems, he doesn't foresee dramatic changes ahead. ``The expansion was not characterized by any extremes, and it is consequently likely that the slowdown that follows will be equally boring,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thursday, Aug. 16.

DOC.HEAD: Travel Agents Say Book Air Fares Now Because of Fuel Uncertainty
DOC.TEXT: Deciphering airline fares never has been easy for passengers, and the latest gyrations caused by the rising cost of oil are making the picture more frustrating than a rush-hour runway backup. That's why many travel agents have started urging clients to book flights several months ahead of time, fearing that airlines inevitably will push fares higher to compensate for an enormous jump in jet fuel prices. ``I'm writing tickets for February, March and April,'' said Ben Chanowitz, an agent at Travel Magic, a Manhattan travel agency. ``We're recommending that people lock in now.'' Even for veteran air passengers, the past week has been one of the more confused periods in the economics of air fares, a convoluted science crammed with fine-print limitations. First, most airlines announced fare increases of more than 5 percent to defray unexpected increases in jet fuel prices caused by the crisis in the oil-rich Persian Gulf. But on Monday, Eastern Airlines and Trans World Airlines, two of the most financially weak carriers, cut certain fares by up to 40 percent to stimulate sales. Competitors matched them. Then on Tuesday, all major airlines delayed fuel surcharges by a week, evidently out of partial fear that they could discourage would-be travelers from flying. The net result is an atmosphere of uncertainty that is convincing a growing number of travelers to postpone plans or buy tickets now for Thanksgiving, Christmas and beyond, travel agents said. ``We are encouraging people to buy whatever is available at the moment,'' said Juergen Krenzien, president of Paul Klein Travel Service in Chicago. ``Our feeling is fares aren't going down. They're going to go up.'' Others said it was a good idea to buy tickets now even if prices decline over the next few months, because generally airlines will reissue the same tickets at the lower fare and refund the difference to the buyers. But that generalization is loaded with some important exceptions, especially in the case of discounted advance-purchase tickets that in many cases are non-refundable. The widely accepted rule is that airlines will only exchange the more expensive ticket for the cheaper one if the class of ticket is identical and the itinerary remains unchanged. ``Say you're holding a non-refundable ticket for $200 and a lower fare is introduced at $150. All you do is contact a travel agent and you may switch to the lower fare,'' said Jackie Pate, a spokeswoman for Delta Air Lines. ``But there are conditions,'' she said. ``You can't change the flight or date. If you were holding the 7-day advance purchase non-refundable and the new fare is a 14-day non-refundable, then you may not be able to switch.'' Even with all the airfare uncertainty, many travel agents say some good bargains are likely to endure, especially going into the fall travel season that historically is one of the year's slowest periods. For example, one of the most popular discounts, a 14-day advance-purchase non-refundable ticket, still offers a 40 percent discount off the peak price. However, it's generally only good for Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday travel. Moreover, if you're a senior citizen, you can get some of the best discounts, because airlines and hotels have targeted people in their 60s as one of their most lucrative untapped markets. Some airlines offer packages to seniors that save hundreds of dollars on tickets, with few limitations. Some travel experts are even predicting airlines will be forced to lower fares. They speculate carriers might face a passenger boycott if they hike prices substantially to defray jet fuel costs, which have jumped 25 percent and more since Iraq seized Kuwait Aug. 2 and provoked world fear of an oil shortage. ``The airlines have panicked over the fuel situation,'' said Eric Munro, chief executive officer of the San Diego office of Uniglobe Worldwide Travel. ``But people are going to refuse to fly, let's face it.'' Others said it was more likely that the airlines eventually will seek to minimize any fuel-related increases and that many travelers probably wouldn't notice the rise in cost. ``Ten or 15 bucks just isn't going to make any difference for a bunch of people,'' said Herbert Teison, editor of the newsletter Travel Smart for Business.
End adv for PMs Thursday Aug. 16

DOC.TEXT: An art expert says stolen German treasures stored at Dallas Museum of Art rank among the world's rarest and most important religious artifacts. One of the treasures may contain material linked to the Virgin Mary, said Dietrich Koetzche of the Kunstgewerbe Museum in Berlin. He visited Dallas to study the relics for a German church that claims to own them. They were believed to have been taken from a mine shaft at Quedlinburg, East Germany, near the end of World War II by a soldier from Texas. The objects ``rank among the three most significant medieval church treasures in Germany,'' he told the Dallas Times Herald. Joe Meador, the soldier, died in 1980, leaving the art to his brother and sister. It later was turned over to the museum. Officials say most of the treasures were reliquaries or containers used to hold relics. Koetzche said he believes some small reliquaries hold items belonging to the Virgin Mary, possibly including a lock of her hair.

William Bentley Ball, a noted religious-rights attorney, urges Roman Catholics and evangelical Protestants to become partners in opposing trends toward secularism. Ball, a Catholic, writes in the evangelical fortnightly, Christianity Today, that evangelicals and Catholics share positions in opposing the breakdown of sexual morality, affirming the sanctity of life, rejecting abortion and euthanasia, favoring parental choice in schooling and supporting religious efforts to influence political decisions.

A Jewish scholar says Orthodox Judaism, one of three major branches of the faith, is on the rise despite ``Orthodox-bashing by its detractors.'' Rabbi Norman Lamm, president of Yeshiva University, told a recent convention of the Rabbinical Council of America, representing Orthodox rabbis, that ``Orthodox-bashing appears to have abated, but it is still powerful.''

Membership in the United Methodist Church declined during 1989 to 8,873,638, down about 68,000. But that loss was 7,000 less than the year before, the denomination reports. The denomination, second largest in U.S. Protestantism, had a peak membership of more than 11 million in 1968. But like most mainline Protestant bodies, it has declined in size for the last 22 years.

Appealing to alienated Roman Catholics to ``Come Home'' to church, Franciscan friars in New York and New Jersey run periodic newspaper ad campaigns. A report says the program in five years has drawn 2,000 back into church life. ``Too many alienated Catholics have heard only the voice of authority,'' the Rev. Flavian Walsh says in an article about the program in St. Anthony Messenger, a Cincinnati-based monthly. The ads, inviting telephone calls and participation in group sessions, stress the gentler, compassionate side of the church. Similar programs have also been used in Boston and Cincinnati. Of 15 million non-practicing Catholics in the country, 40 percent of them would like to mend fences and return to church activity, according to a Gallup Poll, the article says.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, Aug. 17

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Celibacy Rule Widely Violated And Unexamined
DOC.TEXT: An extensive study of celibacy among Roman Catholic priests finds that only half of them adhere to the discipline and that the subject itself is largely unexamined and confined to ``a realm of the secret.'' Psychotherapist A. W. Richard Sipe, a resigned Roman Catholic priest who made the 25-year study involving 1,000 priests and 500 of their intimates, said the church shuns exploring realities of the celibacy requirement. To church officials, ``it can't be talked about in any way of actually discussing it,'' he said. ``It can't be questioned or logical arguments put forth about it. ``All that is considered acceptable is to reiterate the party line.'' Sipe, 57, a lecturer in the psychiatry department of the John Hopkins University medical school in Baltimore and also in private family-therapy practice there, added in an interview: ``An astounding thing, not one seminary in the country has a course on celibacy. Not one even has a course on the history of celibacy. So my church demands a state of celibacy without educating about it or supporting it.'' Sipe, whose findings are to be detailed in a book, ``A Secret World: Sexuality and the Search for Celibacy,'' to be published next month by Brunner@Mazel, said the church avoids the issues. ``It relegates that activity to the area of the secret, to a secret world,'' he said. ``You cannot have Christian responsibility and put an important part of it in a secret world.'' Roman Catholicism's rule of priestly celibacy is not a doctrine of faith but a clerical discipline. It was not required until the 12th century. Even afterward, some priests, bishops, cardinals and even an occasional pope were married and ``concubinage flourished for centuries among clergy vowed to celibacy,'' Sipe said. His findings came as surveys indicate a rising majority of U.S. priests and laity favor ``optional celibacy,'' allowing marriage for priests who chose it. On the basis of his large-scale data, Sipes estimates 50 percent of priests uphold celibacy to a great extent, while the other 50 percent violate it. Twenty percent have regular relationships with women, he said. ``Many of these relationships are remarkably durable and personally compatible with the practice of ministry,'' he added. ``Some behaviors, of course are exploitative and pathologically determined.'' In a preliminary summary of his findings last Saturday to a convention of the American Psychological Association in Boston, Sipes said another 6 to 8 experiment with non-celibacy in a ``dating-like behavior.'' Additionaly, 10 to 13 percent of priests are active homosexuals, he said, while 6 percent involve themselves sexually with children or minors, in most cases homosexually. One percent practice cross-dressing transvestism and 5 percent involve themselves in ``problematic sexual activity'' such as pornography and ``compulsive masturbation'' Sipes said masturbation, which the church condemns, is a ``great conundrum for the student of celibacy because it is a common occurrence'' _ about 80 percent of priests do it occasionally. Of the half of priests upholding celibacy, Sipes said only 2 percent have firmly ``achieved celibacy'' in a mature sense, while another 6 to 8 percent, despite missteps, have solidly established the discipline. Additionally, he said 40 percent of priests are ``practicing celibacy sufficiently well enough to be called celibate,'' although ``unresolved personal and spiritual issues'' sometimes bring non-celibate behavior. Sipe, who left the priesthood in 1970 to marry, said his study identified four essential elements that make for a mature adjustment to celibacy, namely: ``Productive work, a well-defined prayer life, a deep sense of community, and a dedication to service.'' The study, conducted from 1960 through 1985, involved in-depth interviews and reports from 1,500 people, a third of them priests in psychotherapy, a third priests in other settings, and a third lovers or others closely associated with priests. He said that despite the obscurity in which celibacy has been shrouded and the lack of objective study of it, ``celibacy has been a powerful factor in spiritual and cultural achievement in both the West and East.'' However, he said the present church approach is crippled by inadequate training of priests in human sexuality generally and by lack of education in celibacy itself. Considering the wraps kept on the subject, preventing genuine, pro-and-con analysis of it, Sipes said: ``I say that bishops don't know any more about celibacy than priests and that you would find among bishops the whole spectrum of sexual adjustment and problems just as you do among priests. ``It is logical to assume that bishops suffer the same sexual pressures as priests. And if priests get involved sexually, bishops must also. There is no question about this. The further I go in this study, the more surprises there are about what goes on.''

DOC.HEAD: Smugglers Going Legit; Plan Shopping Mall
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Tepito, the infamous smugglers' market, is suffering an identity crisis. Mexico has thrown its doors open to imports, making Sonys and Mars Bars legal. Yesterday's contraband is available at stores with names like Super Gringo. What's a smuggler to do? Cut prices. Build a shopping center. Offer cheap parking. ``Tepitenos have always had a keen sense of timing, an eye for opportunity,'' said Miguel Galan, president of the Confederation of Tepito Merchant Associations. In the 1970s, when Mexico was flush with oil money, Tepito became known as the place to buy contraband, known as fayuca. Tough import restrictions meant only smugglers could supply the booming consumer demand for Japanese televisions and stereos, for shampoo and sweets made in the U.S.A. Residents of Tepito, a scrappy inner-city slum, were glad to oblige. It became a place where guts and a pickup could make a prince of a pauper. Tepitenos streamed back and forth across the U.S. border like ants, buying off police and customs officers. ``Fayuca flourished because it was good business for everybody: customs, the police, the Tepitenos, the consumers,'' Galan said. Things began to change after Mexico joined the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, in 1986. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has further eased import restrictions since taking office in 1988. Most of merchandise in Tepito, which specializes in electronics, now is imported legally because ``people realized it was easier to pay taxes than to make payoffs,'' Galan said in an interview. The prospect of legitimacy has spawned ambitious visions of direct imports from Japan, Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea. It evokes dreams of conventional grandeur. Galan proudly unfurled an architect's rendering of a five-story, 172,000-square-foot commercial center that would replace the maze of stalls, booths and shops run by thousands of people whose families have done business here for generations. ``We need 4,000 parking spaces, minimum,'' Galan said. Is it possible that infamous Tepito, home to 14,000 merchants, could become just another shopping mall? On the surface, the district seems to have changed little. It hums with the raffish energy that made it legend. Housewives haggle with hustlers; carts jam the streets, laden with products as diverse as fresh donuts and eggs of endangered turtles. Pickpockets prey on the unwary in a bruising din of radios, stereos, televisions, video players and Nintendos. Merchandise still changes hands on a cash-only, don't-even-think-of-asking-for-a-receipt-or-warranty basis. Tomorrow's Tepito already seems to be evolving, however. Since Mexico opened its borders, small-time smugglers have been largely replaced by bulk importers, legitimate and otherwise. ``There used to be thousands of people bringing stuff across the border,'' said Alejandra Escareno, a third-generation Tepitena. ``Now there are only a handful of big guys. They bring in stuff by the trailer load, put it in their warehouses and sell it to small vendors.'' Escareno, 42, said small-timers can't offer competitive prices, so she quit dealing in electronics when it became legal. ``How could we compete when we had 10 televisions and they had 100?'' she asked. Escareno went back to the family's old line: used clothes, another time-honored business in Tepito. Tepito is a scavenger on the edges of Mexican history. For decades, it was like a quirky mirror that reflected the silver lining instead of the cloud. ``There has always been a special kind of person here who could figure out how to keep ahead of the game,'' Tepito historian Alfonso Hernandez y Hernandez said in a recent interview with the newspaper La Jornada. Its open-air markets emerged after the desperate years of the 1910-1920 Revolution. Craftsmen displaced by war settled in Tepito and survived by patching old clothes and shoes. World War II shortages rekindled the demand for refurbished items, and then came the postwar years of growth. As people moved into Mexico City's new suburbs, Tepitenos snapped up their discarded possessions. ``They cast off their old things in the rush to be `modern','' Galan said, running a hand over the huge, claw-footed desk his father had found. ``Tepito became known as the place to get bargains on antiques.'' Businessmen like Galan, who quit living in Tepito after he made a fortune in pirated cassettes, sometimes are described as insensitive to its special nature. Most Tepitenos are fiercely loyal to the neighborhood, which already was a teeming slum when Spanish conquerors arrived in 1519. The spirit that bred its smugglers also has spawned writers, painters and poets. Some fear legitimacy may be the one thing this barrio of about 400,000 people cannot survive. Escareno considered Galan's vision of megashopping, parking lots and computerized marketing, and said: ``Tepito is a special place. The community is very united. But it just wouldn't be the same.''

DOC.HEAD: New Policy of Disengagement Frustrates Soldiers and Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: The army plans to lower the Israeli flag and remove a tent encampment near Gaza City as part of a new policy intended to reduce friction with Palestinians. Soldiers have orders not to open fire and to avoid confrontations with stone-throwing youths. Patrols rarely enter the villages and crowded refugee camps. The disengagement reflects a radical shift in the army's military doctrine, and its effectiveness is reducing bloodshed in the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories that began in December 1987. No one has been killed since May in the Gaza Strip, where the uprising began. In July, three Palestinians were killed in the West Bank, the lowest monthly toll of the revolt, in which Israelis have killed well over 700 Palestinians. ``This can't be called turning a blind eye . . . but whoever thought of it was brilliant,'' a military commander said, on condition of anonymity. He said the policy had been implemented gradually after the massacre of seven Gaza workers by an Israeli gunman May 20 started 10 days of riots in which 18 Palestinians died. Israel is changing its tactics at a time of of increasing conflict among Palestinians. Since June 1, twice as many Palestinians have been killed by other Palestinians as by soldiers, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Assad Saftawi, an elementary school principal and leading PLO supporter in the Gaza Strip, described the new policy as a ploy by Defense Minister Moshe Arens to improve Israel's image abroad. Some prominent Palestinians say the uprising is in trouble and seek a new, longer-term strategy to revive morale. Hamdi Faraj, a journalist in Bethlehem, said PLO chairman Yasser Arafat should acknowledge the revolt, or intefadah, has flagged and is unlikely to bring Palestinian statehood in the new future. ``There is a gap between what the PLO says and what the people see,'' he said. ``The state is not a stone's throw away like they claim in slogans.'' At the Dheishe refugee camp in the West Bank, several activists blamed Palestine Liberation Organization policy for the revolt's loss of impetus and accused Arafat of making concessions without getting anything in return. Khaled, 25, who says he has been wounded three times and served 10 months in jail without trial, said Arens timed his change of strategy well. ``The intefadeh has cooled down and Arens played his cards at the right time because people are tired and not chasing after the army,'' he said. Ibrahim, 33, said: ``The intefadeh has almost stopped, and the people have to start realizing that they have to take the solution in their own hands and do it themselves.'' He said younger men should be brought into the PLO leadership. Neither gave his last name. For the army, the Arens policy signifies reversal of a longstanding military doctrine of taking the offensive and confronting each small demonstration to keep riots from developing. ``It was very strange for the soldiers, who have been drilled to charge, to attack and to fire, to be told, `halt . . . restrain yourselves','' the military commander said. Because of the relative quiet, he said, an army encampment set up in the middle of the village of Beit Hanun would be dismantled and the troops evacuated. Villagers were told soldiers would return in force at the first signs of violence. Restraint also was evident elsewhere. From an army lookout post near the Jabalia refugee camp, black smoke could be seen rising as Palestinian youths ignited a tire in the streets. In the past, such an act would have brought swift action by an army patrol, and possibly casualties. This time, Itzik, a 21-year-old first sergeant, looked at the smoke and shrugged his shoulders. ``We'll probably let it burn itself out,'' he said. ``Besides, it creates a lot of heavy black smoke and the (Palestinians) have to breathe it. If it were four or five tires, then we'd probably go in with a company'' of about 100 men, he said. Politicians have praised the army for restraint, but military sources said some soldiers of lower rank felt it could be interpreted as a sign of weakness. Young Palestinians say they will carry the fight to the army. ``Arens might pull back the soldiers, but in that case we will start chasing the army,'' said Fuad, 17, who showed a reporter wounds behind the ear and on his arm from rubber-coated steel bullets.

DOC.HEAD: Bonnie Bedelia Is Widow of Slain Policeman in HBO Thriller
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Bonnie Bedelia, following roles in two of this summer's biggest box office hits, also stars in a race-against-time TV thriller about evidence that might free a man about to go to the electric chair. Bedelia plays the widow of a slain policeman in the Home Box Office movie ``Somebody Has To Shoot the Picture,'' which debuts Wednesday, Sept. 12. She also plays Bruce Willis' wife in ``Die Hard 2'' and Harrison Ford's wife in ``Presumed Innocent.'' ``If I'd been in `Ghost,' I'd be in the three biggest pictures of the summer,'' she said. In the HBO movie, Arliss Howard, about to be executed for killing Bedelia's husband seven years earlier, requests that a burned-out photographer played by Roy Scheider photograph the execution. Scheider reluctantly accepts the job. When the execution is stayed for 48 hours, an alcoholic ex-cop who was at the murder scene kills himself. Scheider finds an old photograph among his effects that refutes crucial evidence at the trial and indicates a cover-up might have taken place. ``Although Hannah has an affair with the photographer, this is not a love story,'' Bedelia said of her character. ``This washed-up photographer comes to town and she's bowled over. She's been a widow for a long time, and sometimes it takes someone from the outside. ``She's a working-class woman, and he's famous. She even goes to the library to look up his work. They're not in love. It was just an impulsive thing.'' Their fling is the backdrop for a complicated story that even Bedelia admits she had difficulty following. Director Frank Pierson used the opportunity to also examine the issue of capital punishment, which he said in an HBO press release that he opposes. Robert Carradine plays the murdered policeman's partner, and Andre Braugher is a reporter. The screenplay was written by Doug Magee, a photojournalist who published a book on death row prisoners in 1980. Pierson co-wrote the screenplay for ``Presumed Innocent,'' but Bedelia did not meet him until he directed ``Somebody Has To Shoot the Picture.'' She said she didn't find her character to be as complicated as the story. ``She was a woman whose husband had been killed, and she had stayed in the town,'' she said. ``I don't know why, but it wasn't important to the story. ... I don't imagine she was very well-educated. It wasn't a part that required a lot of delving. She was a simple person.'' Bedelia said her three recent roles, two wives and a widow, have little in common. ``In `Die Hard 2,' she's an executive of a multinational corporation. Her husband's a cop. She probably makes five times what he does. She's left him. She's totally secure and confident. In `Presumed Innocent,' she's a mathematician who's totally caught up in her work at the university. She's insecure and has deep-rooted problems stemming from her childhood. In the HBO movie, she's a manicurist married to a cop who was killed in his rookie year. ```Die Hard' was a lark. It's not something you have to give a lot of thought to. It's not meant to be deep. It's bang-bang-bang. In `Presumed Innocent,' she's an interesting person. She's very bright, but not very confident. She's insecure, and her husband gives her a lot of reason to be.'' Bedelia grew up in New York, and made her acting debut at the age of 7. She had been in six Broadway shows by the time she was 17. She appeared in more than a hundred shows during the heyday of live television drama and also worked in several series filmed in New York, such as ``Naked City,'' ``East Side, West Side'' and ``The Defenders.'' Her career reached a low point in 1980 when she returned to work after her second son entered kindergarten. But in 1983, she played race driver Shirley Muldowney in ``Heart Like a Wheel,'' a turning point for her. In November, she will co-star with Billy Crystal in ``City Slickers,'' a comedy about a group of city dwellers who sign up for a vacation cattle drive.

DOC.HEAD: Critics: Patients Pawns in Transplant Politics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hellen in 14th graf cq
DOC.TEXT: Recent high-profile campaigns to locate bone-marrow donors have overshadowed a worrisome plight: The nation's two major bone-marrow registries are at odds. Wide-ranging campaigns to enlist potential donors have created a backlog of blood samples for testing. And when the tests finally are done, not all patients get access to the results, partly because the two registries have acted in competition, not in concert. Their failure to share information is more than a bureaucratic tangle. It wastes time, and time is the one thing these dying patients don't have. ``Patients are caught in the middle,'' acknowledges Liz Quam, spokeswoman for the National Marrow Donor Program, which has been criticized by its smaller rival, the American Association of Bone Marrow Registries. ``The country and the patients are not going to be helped to the fullest with these two groups fighting like dogs and cats,'' said Claude Lenfant, director of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. A marrow transplant is the last hope for thousands of patients with leukemia, aplastic anemia and other diseases. But time is precious in the search for a donor. ``You don't have an extra day or month,'' said Bonnie Lundquist of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who searched for months for a transplant for her husband, Peter. He died in February _ a week after potential donors were found. The odds of finding a perfect match are, at best, 20,000-to-1, so the bigger the pool of donors, the better the chance. The National Marrow Donor Program, a quasi-governmental agency, is the nation's largest donor bank, with more than 150,000 names. American has 35,320 potential donors, and also offers low-cost access to foreign registries. About 10,000 Americans a year search for a marrow match. Public awareness about transplants has burgeoned in the past eight months _ largely because of people like leukemia patient Allison Atlas, 20, of Bethesda, Md. Her determined supporters, Friends of Allison, ran a highly publicized search for a perfect marrow match that raised $3 million and enrolled 50,000 potential donors. Atlas's quest was unsuccessful; she got an imperfectly matched transplant from her mother before time ran out. National, based in St. Paul, Minn., hopes to one day have the nation's sole registry. It is supported in part by federal funds and draws on 70 major blood banks for its donor base. American's registry, based in Mandeville, La., is a network of community-based donor pools and gets no federal funds. Each local pool began to help a particular patient, then expanded to aid other patients before joining in a network. The rift between the two registries came to light in February in a congressional staff paper co-written by health policy analyst Hellen Gelband, who noted a lack of coordination from the patients' perspective. ``People didn't always find out that there were different registries they could go to,'' Gelband said in an interview. Have deaths occurred because patients weren't aware of all their options? ``You'd have a hard time documenting it. But it could have happened, certainly,'' she said. ``We get kids who've been searching with National eight to nine months and found nothing, and don't have eight weeks left when we get them,'' said Joanne Raymond, executive director of American. ``When I'm talking to the mother of a 6-year-old who died yesterday because we had a donor but they didn't get to us in time, I can't see the big picture any longer,'' she said. Critics say there are two basic obstacles: Patients don't know where to turn, and the donor banks don't share their resources. National started sharing donor lists with American on April 16, but its data is too incomplete for a successful search, Raymond said. And American thus far has refused offers to merge with the larger National. The reason, says the congressional paper: ``Major philosophical differences having to do with transplant center access, costs, search information and approval of transplant centers.'' National requires patients to be admitted to costly hospital transplant centers before they can search its donor registry. At American, patients can search with permission from their doctors, without entering a center. National says transplant centers ensure that donors get the best possible care and don't waste their time giving marrow to a patient who isn't eligible for transplant or properly prepared for surgery. Quam said the centers also relieve unqualified patients of false hope. American believes in trying, even when the odds seem impossible. And while National focuses on donor protection, with an eye toward research, Raymond says she's more oriented toward patients. The congressional paper said the price of searching for a match and harvesting bone marrow varies substantially by transplant center even though the center itself ``is minimally involved in those activities and is paying the registry for those services.'' Gelband found that patients who never find a successful match spend an average of $4,000, and sometimes up to $15,000. Patients who go through transplants can spend $100,000 to $200,000, depending on whether there are complications, said Quam. American and National are considering proposals that would help them work together, though neither side will discuss them yet. Congress also is looking at the rivalry. For now, the turmoil continues in court battles and press releases. Until recently, the Life-Savers Foundation of America, based in Covina, Calif., was National's recruitment and fund-raising nerve center. Friends of Allison was a major tributary of Life-Savers. Then Life-Savers and National split. In a pending court case in Minneapolis, Life-Savers says it now is a registry in itself. It enlisted 100,000 donors for National in the past and wants to share them; National wants sole rights to them. Dr. Rudolf Brutoco, founder and chairman of Life-Savers, said he was disgusted by delays at National that wasted patients' precious time. But it was Life-Savers' success that helped overload the system, backing up lab tests and paperwork at the donor centers. When the Atlases began their search, National had gathered 57,000 donors in three years. The money the program had allocated for blood typing paid for 1,300 new donors a year; the Atlases brought in that many in two days.

DOC.TEXT: Matching marrow is a three-step process. First, the blood is tested to classify its first four antigens, or cell identifiers; that costs $75 per donor. The second step is to identify the last two antigens; that costs about $300. If all six match, a final test mixes the patient's and donor's blood to see if one rejects the other. Because of the cost, the second step _ called DR typing _ usually is not done until a match is achieved on the first four antigens. Only about 30 percent of National's donors, for example, have had DR typing. On June 1, Life-Savers' staff followed up on potential marrow donors whose names had been submitted to National as far back as March. In two days, the staff members claimed, they located 62 potential donors who had not yet been contacted by National for follow-up tests. National responds that it sometimes has trouble locating donors after a potential match is found. And the registry says some patients with common blood types can be matched preliminarily to scores of donors; National says it can't test each of those matches immediately, due to the logistics and high cost. For its part, National said it wants to do away with Life-Savers' publicity techniques, featuring poignant pleas for donors by patients and their families. Instead, it will seek donors to contribute marrow and money through corporations and service organizations. Quam said Life-Savers, in essence, told families how much money had to be raised. ``We don't want these determined moms and dads to feel so much pressure they have to second mortgage their homes, plead with relatives or cash in IRAs,'' she said. Leaders of each registry include people who got involved because of the illness of a family member or friend, and those emotional ties color the debate over what approach to use. Those same emotions are at work among those who want to reorganize a system that is not working. ``I'm concerned because it isn't a cohesive system, because it's too much of a burden'' on families, said Mrs. Lundquist, the widow whose husband's match came too late. ``I'm concerned that lives are being lost because of an inadequate system.''

DOC.HEAD: How One Man's Search for Marrow Transplant Inspired Reform Effort
With BC-Transplants-Politics
DOC.TEXT: The search for a bone-marrow transplant for Peter Lundquist dragged on for months. It was more time than he had. Lundquist, 37, a Miami television news anchor and father of three, died of lymphoma in February, a week after potential donors were found. His wife, Bonnie, says administrative delays in a bogged-down system robbed her husband of precious time. Lundquist wanted others to have the chance that eluded him. Before he died, he extracted some ``pretty stringent'' promises from his wife: to help other patients and better the system. ``Peter was a really giving person, who cared about other people,'' Mrs. Lundquist said in a telephone interview. ``He left those good qualities: I tried to step in where he had to leave off.'' Mrs. Lundquist promotes marrow donation, because ``patients have no other options: It's the only system we have right now.'' But she wants lawmakers and the public to know that: _The bureaucracy needs to be speeded up. Lundquist was orking through a transplant center; in August, his doctor asked the center to authorize a search with the nation's biggest donor bank. The search wasn't begun until November. Later, there were delays in processing potential matches. ``You don't have an extra day or month with cancer or leukemia patients,'' said Mrs. Lundquist. _The medical establishment doesn't tell patients about all their options. A month after starting a search at the National Marrow Donor Program, she heard from another patient's family about the American Association of Bone Marrow Registries. She immediately started a search in the second registry. _Patients' families need to keep constant tabs on the progress of their donor search. Mrs. Lundquist said she called the transplant center weekly for updates; the National Marrow Donor Center doesn't take calls from patients. _Families, already under stress because of a loved one's life-threatening illness, often must resort to public appeals for a donor. They might not have to if more potential donors could be found. ``I'm concerned because it isn't a cohesive system, because it's too much of a burden'' on patients' families, she said. ``I'm concerned that lives are being lost because of an inadequate system.'' Eventually, she said, ``each and every one of us will be faced with a cancer or leukemia situation _ a brother, sister, friend, father, co-worker, somebody you know will be affected.'' Mrs. Lundquist, a former broadcast journalist, now lives in suburban Fort Lauderdale and works as an aide to a state lawmaker. She hopes to start a foundation to help people who need transplants. In the meantime, she gives advice and emotional support to patients and their families. ``Remembering my situation doesn't paralyze me: it makes me empathize and sympathize with them,'' she said. ``But it's hard, because I realize the frustrations they feel. I wish I could wave a magic wand and make it go away and have all the answers for them. ``For me to become bitter now would not help other people. I've become a lot more positive and motivated to make some good out of it _ not to become bitter and vengeful,'' she said. ``Each day is a precious day.''

DOC.HEAD: Witness Says Neil Bush Became `Ethically Myopic'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 11th graf pvs `In another ...' to ADD Silverado chairman refusing to testify. Picks up 12th graf pvs `In addition ...'; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A government witness in the conflict of interest case against Neil Bush says the president's son lost his ethical moorings _ but did not try to deceive anyone _ while a director of a Denver savings and loan. In testimony released Tuesday by the federal Office of Thrift Supervision, University of Colorado professor Edward J. Conry wrote that the 35-year-old Bush did not lie, try to conceal or mislead. Still, Neil Bush's conduct was unethical because he ``placed himself in situations where his self-interest or loyalty to others was in competition with the interests of depositors, shareholders, insurers and taxpayers,'' wrote Conry, a professor of business law and ethics. ``He became ethically myopic, unaware that his perspective or conduct were biased,'' he said. Neil Bush was a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver, which collapsed in December 1988 at a cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. Conry was one of several expert witnesses on both sides whose testimony was released by OTS and Bush's attorney, James Nesland. The testimony was submitted to Administrative Law Judge Daniel J. Davidson as part of the proceeding in the Bush case. Bush has been ordered to appear at a public hearing on Sept. 25 in Denver before Davidson, who will then make a recommendation to OTS Director Timothy Ryan. In documents submitted by Bush, two experts disputed the regulators' contention that Bush failed to adequately disclose to Silverado his business relationships with Kenneth M. Good and Bill L. Walters, two big borrowers from the thrift institution. Bush has denied any wrongdoing. ``I have never observed charges of unsafe or unsound practices as insubstantial as the charges filed against Bush,'' wrote Charles M. Pickett, a former attorney for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. ``In my opinion, Bush's actions underlying the charges against him are not unsafe or unsound practices.'' The OTS also submitted statements by several former Silverado directors that they were not informed of Bush's precise relationships with Good and Walters. In another document made public Tuesday, the OTS asked Davidson to authorize subpoenas for former Silverado chairman Michael Wise and Russell M. Murray, a former loan officer of the thrift. The thrift office noted that Wise has announced his intention to refuse to testify by asserting his 5th Amendment right against self-incrimination. However, the office said it believes Wise's assertion of that right is invalid. In addition to the thrift agency's case, the FDIC is considering filing a negligence lawsuit against Bush and other Silverado directors. Pickett and Geoffrey C. Hazard Jr., a professor at Yale Law School, supported Bush's contention that it was not a breach of his duty to vote as a director on Silverado loans to Good and Walters, since he didn't have a financial interest in the developers' projects. Good and Walters invested millions of dollars in Bush's oil partnership, JNB Exploration Co., which drilled a number of dry holes in Wyoming over two years and never became profitable. Bush has asserted that before he joined the Silverado board, he disclosed his relationships with Good and Walters to Wise, other Silverado managers, the board of directors and the thrift's attorneys. Good and Walters, two of Silverado's biggest borrowers, got a combined total of $117 million in loans that they never repaid.

DOC.HEAD: United, Northwest, American Delay Proposed Fuel-Related Fare Increases
DOC.TEXT: Several airlines are delaying for about a week a scheduled 5.3 percent fare increase that the carriers proposed to defray the rising costs of jet fuel. At the same time, major airlines moved to match fare cuts that Trans World Airlines and Eastern Airlines proposed earlier this week for flights after Labor Day. The 5.3 percent fare hikes were to have gone into effect today, but United Airlines and Northwest Airlines said Tuesday they were delaying the hike until Aug. 22 while American Airlines postponed it until Aug. 23. They said they were taking the action for competitive reasons and that the delay meant they would absorb higher fuel costs for the time being. The fare hikes were announced in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait that drove oil prices higher. American, for instance, said that each penny-a-gallon rise in fuel prices costs the airline $25 million a year on an annual basis. United estimated its costs go up $22.5 million a year under similar conditions. Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons said his airlines' jet fuel costs climbed 8 cents a gallon to 74 cents in 48 hours following the invasion. In another development Tuesday, United, Northwest and American offered lower fares in response to the post-Labor Day fare cuts announced Monday by Trans World Airlines and Eastern Airlines. United said it would match the TWA and Eastern fare cuts, American said it would match the TWA fares and Northwest announced a reduction plan that it said ``parallels price reductions'' at TWA. Eastern had said it will introduce discount one-way fares ranging from $69 to $139 and cover all of its 62 U.S. destinations from Sept. 5 through Dec. 16. The tickets must be bought by Aug. 29. TWA said it will cut non-refundable domestic fares in most markets at least 20 percent under similar conditions. Meanwhile, U.S. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said Tuesday he'll talk with airline executives this week to see what the Department of Transportation can do to help them cope with high fuel prices. He said he won't know what form the help might take until he meets with the executives, ``but I think we can do a lot.'' Skinner spoke with reporters after a tour of The Boeing Co.'s commercial jetliner factory in Renton, Wash.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 412.42 up 2.09 from the previous day's close.

Stock prices moved broadly higher today amid signs that the Mideast crisis may be easing. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks rose 9.66 to 2,757.43 in the first hour and a half of trading. In the broader market, advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by more than 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 823 up, 388 down and 529 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Mixed As Inflation Fears Ease
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices turned mixed after a higher opening today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting an easing of the inflation fears that recently have helped support the crop markets. The markets opened higher across the board in an extension of Tuesday's rally, in which soybeans climbed as much as 9 cents a bushel. But soybeans and corn turned mixed in reaction to a drop in oil and gold futures prices in New York. Some analysts interpreted the early declines in the New York markets as a sign that inflation fears are easing amid speculation the Persian Gulf conflict may be resolved peacefully. Crude oil and gold rose dramatically after Iraq invaded Kuwait, touching off worries that a reduction in crude-oil shipments from the Middle East would push the U.S. economy into a recession. In early trading, wheat futures were 1\ cents to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.81\ a bushel; corn was unchanged to } cent higher with September at $2.46 a bushel; oats were unchanged to } cent higher with September at $1.16\ a bushel; soybeans were \ cent lower to 5 cents higher with August at $6.10 a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed while pork futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were unchanged to .35 cent lower with August at 78.45 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .37 cent higher with August at 89.95 cents a pound; live hogs .15 cent to .20 cent higher with August at 56.97 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .50 cent to 1.27 cents higher with August at 52.10 cents a pound. Cattle futures retreated on Tuesday; pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Western Union Rescinds Lockout, Signs Contract
DOC.TEXT: Western Union Corp. signed a tentative two-year contract today with the union representing 2,500 union employees, four days after it locked out 2,000 workers, union officials said. The accord, which guarantees the same level of health benefits and a 3.5 percent annual wage hike to the workers, must be ratified by union members, said Steven Rosenthal, spokesman for the Communications Workers of America. Workers who were locked out were asked to return to work, Rosenthal said. Union lawyers filed an unfair labor practices complaint with the National Labor Relations Board Monday over the company's lockout. Union employees authorized a walkout two weeks ago, but set no date for a strike. On Monday, both sides expressed a desire to continue the contract negotiations that began July 23, two weeks before a two-year contract was due to expire. Talks continued after the agreement expired Aug. 6, but ran aground on the desire to pare down medical benefits and to contract work to outside firms. Western Union served notice Saturday that it would replace most of its union employees unless labor officials reconsidered a company offer to extend the expired contract by 90 days.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Hikes Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: Egypt is increasing its oil export prices by $1.15 a barrel for all blends, a senior Oil Ministry official said Wednesday. Hammad Ayoub, director of foreign trade, said the new increases will be effective on Thursday. The new prices will range from $21.95 a barrel to $24.55 a barrel, depending on the blend. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait, Egypt reviewed its oil export prices every week. Wednesday's announcement represents the third price increase this month. Egypt is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and is not bound to OPEC pricing standards. Egypt sets its oil prices based on the world market.

Dealers said the lack of significant developments in the Persian Gulf brought the dollar down as the market focused on the fundamental weaknesses in the U.S. economy. Mike Lovell, a dealer with Bank of America in London, said the dollar was hurt by growing belief that the Federal Reserve may be poised to ease interest rates, a move that would diminish the value of dollar-denominated securities. Jordan's King Hussein traveled to Washington for talks with President Bush, reportedly carrying a letter from Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Higher
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished slightly higher during a choppy session at the London Stock Exchange Wednesday, aided by news that Imperial Chemical Industries PLC (ICI) sold its 25 percent stake in Enterprise Oil PLC. The early-morning deal was confirmed by brokerages Warburg Securities Ltd. and Cazenove and Co., which said they bought ICI's block of 113.3 million Enterprise shares for 600 pence per share, or about $11.40, for a total 679.6 million pounds ($1.29 billion). Investors then snapped up the stock as it was sold on the open market. Outside the Enterprise news, which had been widely rumored in the market, there was little overall activity, dealers said. Although the Dow Jones Industrial Average on Wall Street shot up as much as 20 points at the start of New York trading, London investors paid scant attention. DOC.HEAD: Volkswagen to Open Design Center in California
DOC.TEXT: Volkswagen of America will open an auto design center in California, its first in the United States. The center will be located 35 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles, the Los Angeles Daily News reported Wednesday. Details were being withheld until a formal announcement Monday. Pat Fitzgerald, a Volkswagen spokesman in Troy, Mich., said the car manufacturer has four other design centers, all in West Germany. Volkswagen is joining a number of other automakers in setting up facilities in California. General Motors, Volvo, Honda, Toyota, Mazda, Isuzu, Mitsubishi and Nissan are among the others with design centers in the state. ``It's a hotbed for design,'' said Ron Hill, a transportation design specialist at the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena.``The minivan started here in southern California and the sports cars and off-road vehicle movements are also strong out here.''

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures End Mostly Higher; Soybeans Surge Late
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a session that was relatively quiet except for a late surge in the soybean market. Soybeans sold off early in the afternoon amid reports that Brazil's government would make available the equivalent of $4.2 billion in farm loans for the planting season beginning in September. Uncertainty about the level of government assistance Brazilian farmers would receive had been a supportive factor in the soybean market. Soybeans rebounded strongly near the close, though, on buying that analysts attributed to technical factors. Wheat futures were strong all day, partly reflecting farmers' reluctance to sell wheat at current prices. ``Prices are so darn low, they're just sitting on the stuff,'' said Katharina Zimmer, a grains analyst with Merrill Lynch Captial Markets Inc. in New York. At the close, wheat futures were 4{ cents to 5\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.84{ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 1} cents higher with September at $2.47\ a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 3 cents higher with September at $1.16} a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents lower to 3 cents higher with August at $6.13 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Extends Incentive Package
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. has extended rebates and lowered some interest rates on many of its cars and trucks, the company said Wednesday. Chrysler, which says it spent more than $1,000 per vehicle sold during the second quarter of this year, said it was extending rebates until Sept. 30. The rebates had expired Aug. 14. The cash-back offers range from $500 to $2,500, depending on model. In lieu of the rebates, a consumer may choose new low-interest financing rates on some vehicles. Interest rates range from zero percent to 10.9 percent, depending on model and length of loan. Incentives cover all Chrysler cars and trucks except convertibles and minivans.

DOC.HEAD: After Splashy Debut, Steve Jobs' New Company Has Hardly Made a Dent
LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Some experts are starting to wonder whether there is much of a ``next'' for Steve Jobs' new computer. Launched with splashy publicity in October 1988, the Next machine was supposed to revolutionize personal computers, like the Apple that Jobs and former partner Steve Wozniak hatched in a garage in 1976, and the Macintosh that Jobs gave the world in 1984. One of the industry's most innovative creators, Jobs called the Next the ``best computer in the world.'' Nearly two years later, Next Computer Inc. has hardly made a dent. Only a few thousand of the sleek black boxes have been sold, and the Next has failed to generate great interest among corporate computer users, analysts say. ``The fundamental problem with Next is they were just born at the wrong time,'' said Esther Dyson, who publishes the computer industry newsletter Release 1.0. ``It's one more desktop computer,'' she said. ``The next new revolutionary advance is not going to happen on the desktop,'' but on the new hand-held computers that recognize handwriting, she predicts. Others say the Next machine may be too advanced for its own good. For example, it stores data on a state-of-the-art optical disk, which offers vastly more capacity than conventional magnetic ``floppy'' disks. But optical disks are much slower at retrieving data. Jobs has since offered a faster magnetic hard disk as an option, but still no floppy disk drive. ``Although the machine is exciting intellectually and important from a computer architecture point of view, most customers have work to do. They don't get off on computer technology,'' said Richard Shaffer, the editor of Technologic Computer Letter, another trade letter. An additional problem for Next is the machine's unique operating system, the base layer of software that controls internal computer functions. It makes the Next incompatible with other computers at a time when the industry is moving toward interchangeable systems. Software must be specially tailored for the Next _ it can't use popular off-the-shelf software such as Lotus 1-2-3. That creates one of its most serious dilemmas: Because relatively little software exists to run on the Next, it has a hard time attracting customers. Because there are few customers, software developers are reluctant to write programs for it. ``At the moment there still is no major application for which the Next machine is the best solution, or even more important, the only solution,'' Shaffer said. Next's critics also say the machine is too expensive _ $9,995 to the general public and $6,495 to universities. It didn't help that the operating system was delayed until almost a year after the computer was unveiled, they add. Jobs, who founded Next in 1985 after leaving Apple Computer Inc. in a management dispute, said in January his detractors would be impressed by the fledgling company's performance in six months. Since then, Next announced what apparently is its largest contract, the sale of about 300 machines to William Morris Agency Inc., the Beverly Hills, Calif., talent firm. The company said it chose Next because of its ability to store videos of entertainers as well as text-based information. But the industry is still waiting for delivery on Jobs' promise. ``I would say there's a certain degree of disappointment,'' said Beverly Bird, a spokeswoman for Businessland, a computer store chain that signed an exclusive deal with Next in March 1989 to retail its machines domestically. At the time, Businessland predicted sales would hit $100 million in the first year. But sales have fallen short. International Data Corp., a high-tech research firm, estimates that fewer than 7,000 Nexts were sold as of June. Next is privately owned and therefore is not obligated to disclose sales or finances. Jobs declined to be interviewed for this article. Bird said the $100 million estimate was based on availability of Next's operating system and applications software. Potential customers are still awaiting groundbreaking software that will entice them to buy the machine, she said. ``We know those products are coming,'' she said. She said Businessland has placed Next machines with a number of potential customers who are evaluating them or are working on software for internal applications that would run on Next computers. Despite the slow start, no one is predicting Next's demise. The company is heavily capitalized. One of its principal owners, the Japanese high-tech company Canon Inc., paid $100 million for a one-sixth share last year. The Canon purchase valued Next at $600 million, which Shaffer called ``a mouth-opening, jaw-dropping valuation for a company so young.'' Next's other principal owner, aside from Jobs, is billionare computer magnate H. Ross Perot, while International Business Machines Corp. has paid Next to license its user interface _ its easy-to-use on-screen graphics that control the machine _ for an option on IBM computers. Next aides say they're working on the shortcomings. A faster processing chip is promised later this year, along with a color monitor. More software is on the way, including a spreadsheet product from Lotus Development Corp., said Todd Rulon-Miller, Next's vice president of sales. ``We're trying to develop and deliver some compelling or breakthrough applications this year,'' he said in an interview at Next headquarters in this Silicon Valley community. ``We're starting to begin to see the efforts of a thousand software developers who went through training at a Next developer camp last year.'' While Next has critics, it also has received praise from many computer aficionados. They say it is extremely easy to use vs. rival machines, has razor-sharp graphics and is a computer programmer's dream thanks to a built-in feature that allows easy assembly of new programs. The Next also has a built-in sound device that allows users to add spoken comments to computer documents through a microphone. The comments, in digital sound, can be played back the next time the document file is opened. Jobs has said he believes the merger of text, voice and video _ so-called multimedia _ will represent the ``third wave'' of desktop computing; the first two were spreadsheets and desktop publishing. He also has predicted the Next will establish the third major computing standard after those of IBM and Apple. Experts emphasize that other entirely new computers, such as the Macintosh, lacked adequate software at first. When the Macintosh found its original niche _ desktop publishing _ a flood of software followed. It took about two years for the Macintosh to catch on. In the interim, critics also questioned whether the Mac was a mistake. ``It takes a long, long time to bring a new machine to the market,'' said Shaffer, the trade letter publisher. ``Even if it were the next Macintosh we're still early in the course. I wouldn't write it off yet.''

DOC.HEAD: Next's Factory: A Black and White Wonderland
With BC-Next Computer
DOC.TEXT: From the outside, Next Computer's nondescript white factory building could be mistaken for an insurance company claims office. Inside, it looks more like a showroom for Italian furniture. Next Chairman Steve Jobs' fascination with detail and design is evident everywhere, from the slick black-and-white decor to the two varieties of gourmet coffee in the employee lunchroom. A glass wall behind the reception area reveals the building's true purpose: Through it, the company's highly automated assembly line can be glimpsed below. The assembly floor is surprisingly small _ about the size of a couple of football fields. On a recent visit, it also was surprisingly quiet. The assembly line was not running, and little activity was evident among the handful of workers _ hardly a good sign for Jobs' startup company. The idle assembly line and operating-room cleanliness gave the plant, situated in a well-manicured office park, the air of a science fair project. But Randy Heffner, Next's vice president of manufacturing, said it is unusual for a startup computer company to have its own plant in the first place. Most would farm out production until sales increased to a level to justify the expenditure on machinery. By building its own plant, Heffner said, Next can control the quality of its products, reduce inventory, cut retooling costs and be more responsive to customer needs. He said the plant currently is operating at one-third capacity, but he would not say what that figure is. Jobs has said the plant can support sales of $1 billion a year. Of the 50 employees at the factory, only nine are needed to run the custom-designed, robotic assembly line, which Next says is one of the most advanced in the world. The rest work in packaging, shipping and other areas. Because the company has its own assembly line, it can put together its own prototype computer circuit boards to make sure there will be no unforeseen problems in production that may not be evident in the design phase, said Heffner, who worked at computer giant Hewlett-Packard Co. before joining Next. In addition, it can produce a prototype board for Next's engineers in a few days, instead of the few weeks if production were contracted out, he said. About 20 revisions were made in the circuit board used in the Next machine, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Kroy Reorganization Plan Approved
DOC.TEXT: A reorganization plan for the lettering-machine maker Kroy Inc. and a European subsidiary has been confirmed by a U.S. Bankruptcy Court judge. Under the plan approved by Judge Robert Mooreman, more than $1.9 billion in liabilities will be eliminated and Minneapolis-based Red Oak Investment Corp. will provide operating funds. Confirmation of the plan ``provides sufficient working capital to enable Kroy to continue to expand its operation and products, and it preserves the jobs of our nearly 300 employees,'' said Kroy President Howard Klemmer. Kroy and Kroy Europe Ltd. were sold in 1986 to a management group and an employee stock ownership plan (ESOP) in a leveraged buyout. Kroy was unable to repay the $60 million debt incurred in the buyout and the company filed for reorganization May 15 under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code. Assets of $50 million and liabilities of $53 million were listed on the bankruptcy petition. During the confirmation hearing, it was announced that the company had reached a settlement with the U.S. Department of Labor and Valley National Bank of Arizona, trustee of the ESOP, in a $35.5 million lawsuit. The Labor Department had sued Kroy for hurting the ESOP with the buyout. As part of the settlement, the Labor Department has agreed to dismiss Kroy from the lawsuit. The company said the reorganization plan was supported by virtually all of Kroy's significant creditors. The company, which has 120 employees at its Scottsdale, Ariz., headquarters, has manufacturing facilities in Osceola and St. Croix, Wisc., and 400 dealers and distributors worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Nevada Casinos Make Record Revenues
DOC.TEXT: Nevada casinos raked in a record $4.91 billion in fiscal 1990, helped by increased tourist traffic and major new resorts in Las Vegas. The taxable gross revenue was up 10.6 percent over the previous fiscal year. State Gaming Control Board spokesman Harlan Elges said the total revenues, before operating expenses and taxes, are double what the clubs amassed only nine years earlier. The Las Vegas area accounted for $3.57 billion of the total, for a 12.2 percent year-to-year increase. Elges said the southern Nevada figures showed strong gains partly because of the opening of the Mirage and Excalibur hotel-casinos, which together have added about 6,000 more hotel rooms in Las Vegas. Reno-area clubs accounted for $784.2 million in fiscal 1990, up 6.7 percent.
