DOC.HEAD: In Europe and U.S., French Show Flair For Corporate Takeovers
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Evoking images of boardroom Napoleons, French executives have struck out beyond their borders to wage the most aggressive corporate takeover campaign in Europe. The conquests extend far beyond the continent. Goodrich tires, Mack trucks and Maalox antacid are among the American products French companies are commandeering in a trans-Atlantic offensive even Napoleon would envy. Some experts say France, after decades of passive and insular business practices, is simply catching up, girding itself for a single European market by doing now what corporations from other economic powers have done for years. But there is no disagreement that the French have undertaken the process with skill, enthusiasm, vast reserves of cash, and the strong encouragement of their government. That encouragement has prompted some complaints, arising from the fact that many of the acquisitive French companies are state-owned. European Deal Review, published by the U.S. consultancy group Translink, said there were 40 French state acquisitions of European targets in 1989, valued at $3.34 billion. ``France is in effect nationalizing Europe,'' said Mark Dixon, the review's editor. Many governments consider such takeovers unfair because of the protection given to the French companies by their own government. European Community officials recently ordered Renault and other French companies to pay back hundreds of millions of dollars of state aid which was ruled to give them an unfair advantage over companies from other EC members. Britain, the most popular target for French companies last year, said it may adopt special measures to prevent state-backed takeovers. The Sunday Times of London, in a recent full-page article titled ``France Inc. Storms the Barricades,'' said many experts ``see the hidden hand of the French government behind the sudden aggression of French deal-makers, who, for the first time, have overtaken the British as Europe's most acquisitive businessmen.'' In July alone, French companies announced a series of ambitious, far-flung acquisitions, including financier Bernard Tapie's headline-making purchase of an 80 percent interest in Adidas, the West German-based sporting goods giant. In other transactions last month: _ Accor became the world's largest operator of hotel rooms, with 160,000 worldwide, by purchasing Motel 6 of the United States. Accor's owners described their firm as ``the McDonalds of the hotel world'' after adding 554 budget motels to a network that already included 850 hotels and 3,000 restaurants in 60 countries. _ Lafarge Coppee became Europe's largest cement producer by acquiring VEB Karsdorf, a major East German company. _ State-owned Usinor Sacilor announced plans to acquire Edgcomb Corp., a major U.S. steel trading company. Usinor Sacilor became the world's second-biggest steel producer in 1989 through an aggressive foreign expansion. ``Usinor reflects the imperialistic style that appears to be in vogue in France,'' said Peter Dupont, a steel industry analyst with UBS-Phillips & Drew Ltd. in London. ``The neo-Napoleonic trend is slightly anachronistic in terms of today's conventional wisdom,'' he said, ``but it's in line with the tendency of French governments to allow industrial policy to be influenced by ideas of national prestige.'' Olivier Collette, a Frenchman who directs the marketing information section at the U.S. Embassy in Paris, said most French companies are viewed favorably in the United States as productive industrial investors rather than speculators. ``I've not detected any reaction similar to those concerning the Japanese,'' he said, noting the French firms were rarely seeking real estate investments. ``France was probably the last starter in this race,'' Collette said. ``Three years ago, of the hundred largest French groups, you had a very significant portion with very limited operations in the United States, or none. Now, most of them have a significant foothold in the U.S. market.'' He said French investment in the United States is now roughly equal to U.S. investment in France. Earlier this month, U.S. regulators approved the $1.8 billion merger of Norton Co., a Massachusetts-based abrasives company, with Saint Gobain of Paris, one of the world's leading glass manufacturers. When Saint Gobain proposed the merger in March, to help Norton avert a hostile takeover by a British firm, it won praise from the U.S. management. ``With Saint Gobain as a partner, we will continue to be who we are,'' said Norton's chairman, John Nelson. Another aggressive investor in the U.S. market has been state-owned chemical company Rhone-Poulenc. It acquired a majority interest this year in the Pennsylvania-based Rorer Group, best-known as the maker of Maalox antacid, thereby forming one of the world's top 10 pharmaceutical companies. Earlier, the Michelin tire company acquired Uniroyal-Goodrich and Pechiney, a major packaging manufacturer, bought American National Can. Renault is in the process of buying Mack Trucks. On the other hand, the French can show a different side when foreign acquirers come calling. For example, Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti tried to buy France's Pathe-Cinema film company this year, but the government blocked the transaction on grounds it was not in France's national interest. ``It's not as easy for foreign companies to make acquisitions in France,'' said Ian Fisher of the MMG Patricof, a British buyout firm. ``The French are much more protective of their shareholdings.'' Why the sudden surge of French acquisitions? Experts say it results partly from French corporate fear of vulnerability in 1992, when Western Europe is to be melded into a single market. ``French industries are realizing that if they are going to compete in the new Europe, they're going to have to get out there and do it,'' said Eammon Bates, head of the Brussels office of Bernard Krief Consultants. In the past, he said, French companies got along satisfactorily by serving their large domestic market, often with generous government support. ``Now they may find their own markets at home are threatened (by the single market). French industry has to defend its own interests,'' Bates said. The best defense, France decided, was to take the offensive. Companies fortified by France's prosperous economy set out on concerted acquisition campaigns to gain large chunks of business elsewhere. ``France, at the highest levels, has looked at the strategic aspects of 1992 from a fairly partisan angle _ `If we exploit this to the full, we can ensure further French preeminence in the EC,' '' Bates said. End adv for Sunday Aug. 19

Stock prices rose today in light trading, boosted by moderating oil prices amid signs that the Mideast crisis may be easing. Analysts said the market was reacting favorably to the visit by Jordan's King Hussein to the United States. Hussein was carrying a letter from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to President Bush. Stocks received an additional boost as oil prices declined. Government bond prices rose, also helping the stock market. ``It's been playing tag all day with bond prices and oil prices,'' said Walter Murphy, a senior market specialist at Merrill Lynch & Co. He said the market's initial price spurt, in which the Dow Jones industrial average rose as much as 21 points in the first half hour, was based on expectations that some breakthrough was imminent in the Mideast. When that did not materialize, prices moved lower. Speculation that the Mideast situation might be easing prompted a stock rally in Japan. The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei, closed 5.4 percent higher, while stock prices also gained in London.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Return to Posts at Western Union Following Contract Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Two thousand Western Union Corp. employees got their jobs back Wednesday as the company signed a tentative labor contract that rescinded a four-day lockout of union workers, company and union officials said. The two-year settlement, reached at 3:30 a.m. Wednesday, guarantees the same level of health benefits and a 3.5 percent annual wage increase to the employees, who are represented by the Communications Workers of America. About half the workers covered by the contract are recording operators. The others include technicians, clerical workers and a smaller number scattered in other departments. The contract also applies to 500 CWA employees not affected by the Saturday morning lockout. Settlement of the labor dispute will free the company to concentrate on its proposed recapitalization plan, which is essential to Western Union's future, said Robert J. Amman, Western Union president. The company's old contract with union workers expired Aug. 6. Workers had authorized a strike two weeks ago, but the union never threatened to strike, even after the lockout was declared, said Dan J. Beckstead, the union's chief negotiator. ``(The company) probably started moving when they realized the union and the membership was not going to crack under their pressure of a lockout,'' Beckstead said. Employees who were locked out will be reinstated with full back pay, Rosenthal said. Temporary replacements who had been staffing the company's principal facilities since Saturday were withdrawn Wednesday as union employees returned to work, Western Union spokesman Warren Bechtel said. Beckstead said an unfair labor practice charge filed on Monday with the National Labor Relations Board would be dropped. The complaint alleged that the company violated federal labor law by selectively locking out the 2,000 workers. The contract must be ratified by union members, said CWA spokesman Steven Rosenthal. He said ballots will be mailed by next week, with the tally expected to be completed by early September. The contract maintains pensions at current levels and retains a profit-sharing program that was created in 1985 to compensate workers for wage and benefits concessions, Rosenthal said. Union negotiators made some concessions on the company's ability to contract work to outside firms and on the use of part-time employees, Bechtel said. Much of the debate at the three-week-long talks centered on the company's attempts to curtail medical benefits. Bechtel said the company dropped its efforts to reduce medical benefits as part of the ``normal bargaining process.'' The agreement came hours before Western Union's adjourned annual meeting was scheduled to reconvene. The meeting, to continue at 2 p.m. Thursday, will focus on the debt-ridden company's proposed recapitalization plan. Under the plan, Western Union wants shareholders to approve the reclassification of preferred shares into common shares. A two-thirds vote of the preferred shareholders is needed to approve the plan, Bechtel said. The proposal also asks bondholders to allow the company to swap $530 million in high-yield notes for new notes paying lower interest rates and common shares. Noteholders originally had until midnight Wednesday to turn in their bonds, but that deadline will be extended, Bechtel said.

DOC.HEAD: ICI Sells Enterprise Oil Stake
DOC.TEXT: Imperial Chemical Industries PLC sold its 25 percent stake in Britain's Enterprise Oil PLC on the open market Wednesday, brokers said. Brokers Warburg Securities Ltd. and Cazenove and Co. said they bought a block of 113.3 million Enterprise shares from ICI for 679.6 million pounds ($1.29 billion), or 600 pence a share. The shares were then sold into the open market on the London Stock Exchange. A total of 232 million Enterprise shares changed hands on the London Stock Exchange Wednesday for prices of about 607 pence per share ($11.53) traders said. Enterprise stock closed at 628 pence per share ($11.93) Wednesday, while ICI shares finished at 950 pence ($18.05). Enterprise Oil is one of Britain's largest independent oil exploration and production companies. Another 25 percent of its shares are owned by France's Societe Nationale Elf-Aquitaine. Elf has focused on the North Sea recently in its search for additional sources of production and has said it wants to increase its oil and gas reserves by 700 million barrels. Jim Henderson, an oil analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd, said Enterprise would be a logical target for Elf. But he said such a bid is unlikely now, given the Middle East crisis that has sent crude oil prices soaring.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: in London.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose a slight 0.50 point to 2,748.27. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by nearly 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 885 up, 628 down and 476 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 135.21 million shares, against 130.32 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index rose 0.44 to 186.54. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 0.70 to 340.64.

DOC.HEAD: AC Rochester West Workers Back to Work, Strike Effects May Linger
DOC.TEXT: United Auto Workers union members at a General Motors Corp. parts plant returned to their jobs Wednesday after a six-day strike that idled several other GM plants. GM spokesman John Maciarz said the company was happy to have the work force back and was gearing up production at its AC Rochester West plant. Parts shortages caused by the strike have halted production at eight car and truck assembly plants in Michigan, Ohio, Louisiana and Indiana, GM said. Manufacturing also was curtailed at a variety of component factories. Workers at assembly plants in Flint and Oakland County, Mich., were recalled late Tuesday, leaving six plants shut down Wednesday, Maciarz said. By Wednesday afternoon, Maciarz said, about 16,800 people were still on layoff because of the strike. ``I'm sure there are going to be more callbacks tomorrow and more Friday,'' he said Wednesday. ``We also might see another plant or two go out for a short period of time.'' Production at the assembly plants will gear up through next week toward their pre-strike capacities. Maciarz said he didn't know when each affected plant would return to normal production. The contract ratified Tuesday calls on GM to maintain the current work force level at the Flint factory for the next six years. Workers were concerned GM would turn to outside, non-union companies to supply some of the grilles or fuel tanks made at the factory. Job security is also the top issue in national contract negotiations going on in Detroit between the UAW and GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. The three national contracts, to replace those expiring Sept. 14, will cover more than 450,000 workers total. After the Flint agreement was ratified, local union leaders hailed its job security language just as national leaders did three years ago when the current GM-UAW agreement was signed. That contract permitted the automaker to close a plant only when sales of its products slumped badly. Since then, GM has closed four assembly plants, prompting UAW charges of betrayal. The union unsuccessfully challenged one of the closings before an arbitrator. This time, things will be different, said Mike Grimes, shop chairman for UAW Local 659 in Flint. ``We're going to keep their feet to the fire,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Shutting Down 3 Assembly Plants; Dealer Orders and Lack of Material
DOC.TEXT: Three Ford Motor Co. assembly plants will be idle next week because of a lack of dealer orders and interior material, the company said Wednesday. Assembly plants in Atlanta and Kansas City will be closed because of low dealer orders. The Atlanta plant produces Ford Taurus and Mercur Sable cars and the Kansas City plant makes Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz cars. Ford also said this week's shutdown of its Lorain, Ohio, plant would be extended through next week because of a shortage of interior trim materials. Spokesman Joel Pitcoff said the company received more orders for a particular interior trim package than anticipated, resulting in the shortage. The Lorain plant makes Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar cars. The shutdowns affect about 2,500 hourly employees in Atlanta, 2,300 workers in Kansas City and about 2,700 in Lorain.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Volatile As Mideast News Breaks
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures were mixed Wednesday, as news of the tense Middle East standoff continued to affect trading. ``It's a nervous market,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``It's very volatile on headlines. Any kind of news that comes up, there's wild swings or trends.'' The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the U.S. benchmark grade of crude, closed at $26.46 per 42-gallon barrel, 4 cents above Tuesday's close of $26.42. Crude futures for later months were mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In early trading, the price of crude fell as traders speculated that Jordanian King Hussein's visit Thursday with President Bush could lead to a peaceful settlement in the Persian Gulf. Oil prices have increased since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. September crude dropped as low as $25.60 per 42-gallon barrel before swinging up on news that OPEC member nations might not hold an emergency meeting to discuss higher production. Prices later tumbled on a report that Saudi Arabia may be willing to raise OPEC production to 22.5 million barrels per day. That would make up about 3.5 million of the 4 million barrels kept off the market each day by the international boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries plans an emergency meeting this week to discuss the possibility of boosting production. OPEC has not yet announced a date and location for its meeting. But Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez said Tuesday that the cartel hoped to make oil decisions by the end of the week. Venezuela's acting foreign minister, Adolfo Raul Taylhardat, told reporters in that country Wednesday that Iraq will be allowed to participate in the meeting. ``Iraq is a member of OPEC, and has the right to participate in any of its meetings,'' he said. Other petroleum futures on the Merc were mixed. Home heating oil for September closed at 72.85 cents per gallon, or .12 cent lower than Tuesday. Later months were also down. The September contract for unleaded gasoline rose 1.32 cents per gallon to 84.05 cents. Future contracts were mixed. Natural gas for September fell from $1.448 to $1.428 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rose modestly Wednesday in light trading, boosted by moderating oil prices and signs that the Mideast crisis may be easing. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks rose a slight 0.50 point to 2,748.27. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 887 up, 619 down and 494 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 135.21 million shares, up from 130.32 million in Tuesday's session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 161.14 million shares. Analysts said the market reacted favorably to the visit by Jordan's King Hussein to the United States. Hussein was carrying a letter from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to President Bush. The king was scheduled to meet with Bush on Thursday. Stock prices initially spurted on expectations that some breakthrough was imminent in the Mideast, traders said, sending the Dow 22 points higher in the first half hour of trading. When no breakthrough materialized, prices moved lower and ``the market settled down to something that was more reflective of what's going on in the market itself,'' said Walter Murphy, a senior market specialist at Merrill Lynch & Co. The market received boosts when oil prices declined and government bond prices rose, though trading in both markets was choppy. ``It's been playing tag all day with bond prices and oil prices,'' Murphy said. Speculation that the Mideast tension might be easing prompted a stock rally in Japan before the domestic market opened. Wal-Mart was the most-active NYSE issue, falling \ to 30\ as 2.03 million shares changed hands. The retailer said it knew of no reason for the activity, which it said was not that much greater than normal trading in the stock. Among other active issues, AmBase plunged 4} to 2}. The financial holding company, which announced Tuesday it would sell its insurance unit, said it was unlikely that it would pay a special dividend that had been promised to shareholders from the proceeds. DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Repayment, Fines, in Business Week Insider Trading Case
DOC.TEXT: A print shop worker and stockbroker who teamed up to buy stocks based on tips in Business Week before the magazine hit the street were ordered Wednesday to repay $28,655 and were fined $37,444. The rulings against stockbroker Brian J. Callahan and print quality control analyst William N. Jackson were issued by U.S. District Judge Stephen V. Wilson in a civil insider trading case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Wilson also entered a permanent injunction barring Callahan, 30, of Anaheim, from further securities law violations. Callahan and Jackson, 34, of Long Beach, were convicted by a jury in May of insider trading in more than 53 stocks in 1987 and 1988. Jackson made $19,507 in personal profit, while Callahan made $1,148 in personal profit and $8,000 in commissions. Wilson ordered them to repay those amounts and fined Jackson $10,000 and Callahan $27,444.57 _ three time his personal profit and commissions. Neither the printing company, R.R. Donnelly and Sons, nor Business Week was a defendant. SEC attorney Jeffrey Zuckerman said Jackson reviewed a new copy of the magazine every Wednesday night at a printing plant in suburban Torrance. He then phoned Callahan, a Prudential Bache broker, the next morning to buy stocks recommended in the ``Inside Wall Street'' column. The stock prices would tend to rise later as buyers entered the market after reading the information. Jackson testified he didn't realize he was breaking the law or confidentiality requirements of his company. Callahan testified that he thought Jackson got his stock tips from a computer. Both men have lost their jobs. Their lawyer, Joseph Connolly, had accused the SEC of stretching the securities laws ``almost beyond recognition'' to cover a marginal violation.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Falls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS decimal place to 1.5540 in 5th graf
DOC.TEXT: The dollar bounced higher Wednesday against the German mark in U.S. dealings after sinking to an all-time low against the mark in Europe. Against other major currencies, the dollar finished mixed in domestic trading after falling broadly overseas. Gold prices turned lower after rising in recent sessions due to worries about war and inflation resulting from actions in the Persian Gulf. The dollar sank to a record closing low of 1.5605 marks in Europe, down from 1.5685 marks late Tuesday and below its previous trading low of 1.5615 marks on Jan. 4, 1988. Dealers said the dollar drifted even lower as trading got underway in New York with the currency dropping to about 1.5540 marks early in the session. But the dollar retraced some lost ground in the afternoon session in New York as some traders sold other currencies to cash in on their recent rise, said John McCarthy, chief currency dealer at Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank. ``We have seen some classic profit-taking this afternoon,'' he said from his New York office. ``People got tired of selling dollars.'' By late afternoon in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.5660 marks, up from 1.5645 marks late Tuesday. Despite the recovery against the mark, McCarthy said he does not think the sentiment toward the dollar has changed. ``It was just oversold against almost all currencies and many participants were short dollars,'' he said. The fundamental conditions that have caused the dollar to decline over the past few weeks should continue to depress the currency, he said. Many analysts say weakness in the U.S. economy will eventually force the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates to avoid a recession just as Germany, Japan and other nations boost their rates to curb inflation. The net effect will be to make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors, currency analysts say. The dollar has also been hurt by indications the Middle East crisis might be winding down. Jordan's King Hussein traveled to Washington for talks with President Bush, reportedly carrying a letter from Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and remains there despite protests from other nations around the world. Besides rising against the mark, the dollar gained ground against the Swiss franc, French franc and Italian lire in New York while falling against the Japanese yen, British pound and Canadian dollar. In New York, the dollar fell to 147.65 Japanese yen from 148.85 yen late Tuesday. Earlier, it fell to 147.15 yen in Tokyo from 149.90 yen at Tuesday's close. In London, the dollar was quoted at 147.15 yen. The dollar also fell worldwide against the British pound. The pound rose to $1.9000 in New York from $1.8970 late Tuesday. In London, the pound rose to $1.9045 from $1.8930 late Tuesday. Other dollar rates as of 4 p.m. EDT in New York, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.30735 Swiss francs, up from 1.3042; 5.2570 French francs, up from 5.2555; 1,149.75 Italian lire, up from 1,149.25; and 1.14345 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14425. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Tuesday's late rates, included: 1.3005 Swiss francs, down from 1.3055; 5.2365 French francs, down from 5.2695; 1.7579 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7675; 1,145.75 Italian lire, down from 1,152.50, and 1.1435 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1452. Gold prices dropped worldwide in response to an apparent decline in tensions in the Persian Gulf. Gold for current delivery fell $2.20 to $402.60 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank quoted a bid for an ounce of gold at $402.40 as of 4 p.m. EDT, down $1.60 from Tuesday's late bid. Earlier, gold fell to $401.25 a troy ounce in London from $410.25 late Tuesday and to $398.75 an ounce in Zurich from from $412 late Tuesday. In Hong Kong, gold fell $9.50 to $401.50 an ounce. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery fell 12.3 cents an ounce to $5.068. Silver bullion fell to $5.12 an ounce in London from $5.28 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Suspends Publication of French Version of Fortune
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. has suspended publication of Fortune France, the French language version of Fortune magazine that it has published since early 1988 in partnership with Hachette Filipacchi Group. A spokeswoman for Fortune said the move resulted from differences between the partners over the magazine's editorial direction. ``Hachette was looking for more of a lifestyle magazine, while Marshall Loeb said it should be more consistent with the business direction of Fortune,'' said Emma Dockendorff, the spokeswoman for Fortune. Loeb is the managing editor of the U.S. edition of Fortune and had veto power over stories that appeared in the French edition. She said Fortune is pursuing talks with others about new foreign-language editions, however. She said Fortune is in negotiations about the possibility of publishing a Spanish-language edition of Fortune and a Fortune Benelux edition that would be in Dutch or Flemish for distribution in Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. She declined to say who Fortune was talking with. ``We are disappointed about the need to close (Fortune France) but we feel confident about our editorial direction,'' Ms. Dockendorff said. She said Fortune International, an English-language version of Fortune distributed overseas, recently increased its circulation guarantee to 115,000 from 105,000. Time Warner has published an Italian-language version of Fortune, Fortune Italia, as a joint venture with Arnaldo Mondadori Editore since April 1989 and that magazine is doing well, Ms. Dockendorff said. On the domestic front, Time Warner's magazine division confirmed Wednesday that it will publish two test issues of a woman's magazine developed with author and home entertainment stylist Martha Stewart. The first issue of the magazine, which is being called Martha Stewart Living, will be put on newsstands in mid-November and focus on holiday entertaining and family holiday activities, according to Time Inc. Magazines spokesman Peter Costiglio. The second issue will appear on newsstands in mid-March and focus on spring activities and Easter holiday entertaining. Costiglio said 500,000 copies of each issue would be distributed and a judgment would be made afterwards on whether to continue publishing. Meantime, Sports Illustrated said it is planning to pubish three special issues in 1991 of a sports nostalgia magazine, tentatively called Sports Illustrated Classic. It would be distributed to Sports Illustrated subscribers and sold on newsstands.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Rebound, End Higher as Brazilian News Becomes Clear
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices posted modest gains Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a trading session enlivened by conflicting reports about the size of a Brazilian agricultural loan program. On other commodity markets, grain futures also advanced; oil futures were mixed; precious metals retreated; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Soybean futures settled 2\ cents lower to 3 cents higher with the contract for August delivery at $6.13 a bushel. The contract tumbled from near its opening level of $6.10{ to $6.02{ at midday after a report that the Brazilian government would make available to farmers the equivalent of $6.3 billion in loans for the planting season beginning in September. The amount was much higher than last year's $4 billion program. The report immediately prompted speculation that next year's soybean crop from Brazil, the world's second-largest producer, would be larger than many analysts had been anticipating. But soybean prices rebounded a little later on another report that Brazilian President Ferdinand Collor de Mello had announced the amount would be the equivalent of $4.2 billion, which was in line with market expectations. Wheat futures were strong all day, partly reflecting farmers' reluctance to sell wheat at current prices. ``Prices are so darn low, they're just sitting on the stuff,'' said Katharina Zimmer, a grains analyst with Merrill Lynch Captial Markets Inc. in New York. Wheat futures settled 4{ cents to 5\ cents higher with September at $2.84{ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 2 cents higher with September at $2.47{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1{ cents higher with September at $1.16} a bushel. Crude oil futures finished little changed on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a day of up-and-down trading tied to developments in the Persian Gulf. Prices slumped early in the day amid hopes that Jordan's Kind Hussein was bringing an Iraqi peace proposal to President Bush. But crude prices recovered on reports that most OPEC members were not inclined to discuss the possibility of increasing their crude output to make up for the loss of Iraqi oil exports. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 6 cents lower to 28 cents higher with September at $26.46 a barrel; heating oil was .02 cent to .23 cent lower with September at 72.85 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .15 cent lower to 1.32 cents higher with September at 84.05 cents a gallon. Gold and silver futures fell on New York's Commodity Exchange in the absence of significant new developments in the Middle East. Gold futures ended $2.90 to $3 lower with August at $402.60 a troy ounce; silver was 12.3 cents to 15.1 cents lower with August at $5.068 a troy ounce. Livestock and meat futures ended narrowly mixed in lackluster trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .23 cent lower to .23 cent higher with August at 78.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .25 cent higher with August at 90 cents a pound; live hogs were .08 cent lower to .75 cent higher with August at 56.87 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.3 cents lower to .13 cent higher with August at 50.95 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dow Boss An Old East European Hand
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Born in Bulgaria and raised in the Midwest, Frank Popoff is just as comfortable steering Dow Chemical Co. into Eastern Europe as he is steering chums into a Bloomington, Ind., bar to reminisce about college. Popoff is a veteran of the chemical business in Dow's European operations and travels there at least once a year. The president and chief executive is at home in a changing Eastern Europe and its fledgling free-market economy. ``But because we're old hands in that part of the world and have been for many, many years, we're trying to be part of a process, rather than part of the pyrotechnics of Eastern Europe newly discovered by people who, a year ago, could have cared less,'' he said. High-profile U.S. companies have plunged into Eastern Europe over the past year, forming businesses ranging from auto assembly plants to tourist hotels. But Dow's been there since the 1960s, originally as a trader with all the East bloc countries and more recently as a partner in a Hungarian styrofoam factory. Global operations are part of a broader strategy Popoff helped devise to tame boom-and-bust cycles in the chemical industry. He's also pushed Dow into new technologies, pharmaceuticals and consumer products ranging from oven cleaner to Saran Wrap, which sell regardless of the economy's health. He said the biggest challenge is trying to persuade consumers that Dow's products can be used without harming the environment. ``There are no chlorofluorocarbons in these cups any more,'' Popoff said in an interview, picking up a white styrofoam coffee cup from a dark wood conference table. ``We have to be a player in the Earth Day scenario,'' he said. ``We'll either have to meet this challenge or revise our growth rates for the industry.'' A 50 percent slump in second-quarter earnings proved the country's second-largest chemical company behind Dupont isn't yet immune to industry cycles. Prices for plastics and chemical products weakened, raw material costs stayed high, and production outages at several plants contributed to the decline. Popoff and other Dow officials predict a gradually improving economy still will give Dow with its best year in sales and third-best year in profits. ``Dow is like a baseball player who hits .300 year in and year out,'' said David Sowerby, vice president and economist at Manufacturers National Bank in Detroit. Of the second quarter earnings, he said: ``Even .300 hitters go into temporary slumps. The economy is weak and they can't escape that. They still look good fundamentally.'' Although developments in Europe are of particular interest to Popoff, he said the area remains mired in bureaucracy and central planning that make the area relatively unattractive to foreign investors. ``The Pacific Rim is, I think, the growth area for the next decade,'' Popoff said. Dow has growing operations in Japan, Thailand, Korea and China. Popoff, 54, succeeded Vienna-born Paul F. Oreffice as president and CEO in 1987 after success with European operations. Oreffice remains chairman. ``He did a good job of achieving a low-cost production position in Europe, and that's why they brought him over here,'' said industry analyst Fred H. Siemer of Chemical Research for Wall Street. ``He understands the global nature of the business.'' The global outlook came to Popoff naturally. His family left Bulgaria when he was a child, amid turmoil of Hitler's Nazi expansion. His father ran an import-export business. The Popoffs emigrated to Terre Haute, Ind., in 1940. Popoff's father operated a dry-cleaning business, Popoff attended high school, and the family became U.S. citizens. Popoff graduated Indiana University in Bloomington with a bachelor's degree in chemistry and a master's degree in business administration, both in 1959. He returns for alumni activities and advisory committee meetings and is an active alumnus of Sigma Chi, his college social fraternity. ``Frank is a very valued counselor for me,'' said Jack Wentworth, dean of the university's School of Business. Dow hires many university graduates and funds scholarships at the school. Wentworth said Popoff also relishes meeting old friends like John Peterson, now chairman of City Securities Corp. in Indianapolis. ``When they get together they act like classmates and they go back to their old local pub.'' ``We'll go back to Nick's Old English Pub for old memories,'' Peterson said. ``They don't check us for IDs anymore, they just look at us funny because we have a tie. The students are looking very young.'' Popoff strikes many as urbane and humble at the same time, perhaps a reflection of his success. ``He's not phony,'' Wentworth said. ``He doesn't come on like he knows it all. He's the kind of person you'd like if he was the janitor.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday Aug. 19

DOC.HEAD: Study Predicts Petroleum Companies to Spend Billions to Reformulate Gasoline
DOC.TEXT: Tighter controls against air pollution will push petroleum companies to devise new formulas for nearly all the gasoline sold in America by the end of the century, according to a study released Wednesday. The study by the Arthur D. Little management consulting firm predicts domestic refiners will spend up to $22 billion to alter their gasoline. One result would be higher gasoline prices. The changes would mark the most significant shift in gasoline production since companies started making unleaded fuel in the 1970s, said Carlton Jones, who helped write the study. A driving force behind the change will be legislation to amend the federal Clean Air Act, Jones said. Both the U.S. House and Senate have approved bills that would require companies to reformulate their gasoline. The goal is to reduce emissions of pollutants such as carbon monoxide. The legislation would require reformulated gasoline to be sold in nine metropolitan areas that represent about 21 percent of the nation's population, Jones said. Those areas, which have high ozone concentrations, are New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Hartford, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Milwaukee, Houston and San Diego. The requirement would take effect in 1993, but other forces could lead the movement to spread around the country, Jones said. For example, distributors might face logistical problems if they try to continue providing gasoline made under current formulas, while at the same time providing the reformulated product. Also, petroleum companies might broaden the sale of reformulated gasoline as a competitive wedge. ``If one company advertises that its reformulated gas burns more cleanly, consumers might want to buy that,'' Jones said. Some companies already have begun to change their formulas. Shell Oil Co. introduced a new gasoline formula this year in the nine areas targeted by the federal legislation, said Norman Altstedter, a company spokesman. Altstedter acknowledged there was a ``competitive aspect'' to the company's decision, but he said ``our first thing is to help improve air quality.'' But the petroleum industry objects to the legislation proposed in Congress. ``Our position is the government should not be writing formulas for gasoline,'' said R.G. Ensz, spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade association. ``The government should set certain air quality goals and let the auto and petroleum industries figure out how to meet those goals,'' he said. Along those lines, automobile and oil companies have joined to conduct a comprehensive study of cleaner burning fuels, Ensz said. He predicted some small refiners could be put out of business if the government adopts ``unworkable formulas.'' The study itself says the ``investments required to meet tighter environmental standards may be unprofitable for refiners.'' To make the new formulas, companies would not simply be able to adjust current operations but would have to install new processing equipment ``that refiners don't usually have,'' Jones said. The study predicts reformulated gasoline will cost consumers an additional 7 to 12 cents per gallon. The study also looked at the European market, but predicted the push for new gasoline formulas will proceed more slowly there. This is partly because the United State has been more active in imposing strict emissions requirements and also because Europe has less severe smog problems. Another variable in the equation, however, is the political crisis in the Middle East. Jones said he did not expect the crisis would have much effect, although an extended drop in oil supplies could delay implementation of federal regulations.

DOC.HEAD: Arco Extends Freeze on Wholesale Prices
DOC.TEXT: Atlantic Richfield Co. said Wednesday it was extending a freeze on wholesale gasoline, diesel and jet fuel prices enacted in response to a call by President Bush for restraint during the Persian Gulf crisis. Arco, which sells gasoline at 1,500 stations in five Western states, was the first oil company to announce a freeze after pump prices increased sharply after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The company, based in Los Angeles, said there was no time on the extension but it would review prices daily. Crude oil prices have risen only slightly since the one-week freeze was announced, and pump prices have stabilized as well. Arco spokesman Doug Elmets said the company's demand volume has increased 10 percent at the pump since the price freeze was announced. The freeze applies only to the price of fuel sold to wholesalers and not retailers. The company has asked its retail distributors to keep a hold on pump prices. Arco sells gasoline in Arizona, California, Nevada, Oregon and Washington state. Bush called for price restraint by oil companies after widespread allegations of price gouging at the pumps to take advantage of the instability in the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Continental to Match Other Airlines and Cut Fall Fares
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines said Wednesday it will cut fares for flights after Labor Day, matching reductions already announced by several other major carriers. The carrier said it will lower its discount fares for fall vacation travel in the continental United States by an average of 30 percent. Continental said the lowered fares will be exempt from a pending 5.3 percent increase that the carrier and several others plan to implement in about a week to defray the rising costs of jet fuel. The Houston-based airline's reduced fares apply to round-trip tickets purchased by Aug. 29 for travel between Sept. 5 and Dec. 16, excluding the five days around Thanksgiving. On Tuesday, United, Northwest and American offered lower fares in response to the post-Labor Day fare cuts announced Monday by Trans World Airlines and Eastern Airlines. The 5.3 percent fare increases were to have gone into effect Wednesday, but Continental, United Airlines and Northwest Airlines said they were delaying the hike until Aug. 22. American postponed it until Aug. 23. The carriers said they were taking the action for competitive reasons and that the delay meant they would absorb higher fuel costs for the time being.

DOC.HEAD: City Casinos Post First-Ever Second-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: The casino industry here posted a loss in the busy April through June period for the first time in its 12-year history, according to figures released Wednesday. The loss came despite a 10.7 percent increase in gross revenue generated by the April opening of Donald Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort. Overall, the industry lost $1.2 million on gross revenue of $884.2 million in the second quarter, according to figures released by the Casino Association of New Jersey. During the same period last year, the city's 12 casinos earned $21.9 million on gross revenue of $798.8 million. Half the casinos posted losses in the second quarter, with the Taj Mahal posting the steepest loss _ $14.4 million on gross revenue of $126 million. ``Although the Taj Mahal has produced an expansion of the market, it has not been enough to offset its impact on the rest of the industry,'' said association president Thomas Carver. However, only two gaming halls _ Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino and Caesars Atlantic City Hotel and Casino _ had earnings that amounted to more than 5 percent of their revenues. The 5 percent mark is considered a barometer of success in the industry. One bright spot for the industry was found in Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel, which recorded a net profit of $2.7 million on gross revenue of $59.2 million. Resorts, which is trying to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, is adjacent to the Taj Mahal. Company officials hoped that interest in the Taj would lure patrons to Resorts. Showboat Hotel Casino, situated on the other side of the Taj Mahal, posted a loss of $1.7 million on gross revenue of $71.4 million. Trump's other properties had mixed results in the three months since the April 2 opening of the Taj Mahal. Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino had a profit of $876,000 on gross revenue of $83.4 million while Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay lost $8.1 million on gross revenue of $63.4 million. The other four casinos that posted profits were: Caesars, $4.1 million profit on $77.7 million revenue; Bally's Park Place Casino Hotel, $3.4 million profit on $82.3 million in revenue; Harrah's Marina, $15 million profit on revenue of $80.5 million; and Bally's Grand Hotel and Casino, $1.7 million profit on revenue of $56.2 million. The three othere casinos to post losses were: Sands Hotel & Casino, which lost $1.7 million on $66 million in revenue; Claridge Hotel and Casino, which lost $842,000 on revenue of $39.6 million; and TropWorld Casino and Entertainment Resort, which lost $2.2 million on revenue of $78.6 million.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Financial Package Revealed in Accountant's Report
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lead to CORRECT to subcontractors; SUBS 14th graf to ADD for whom report was prepared.
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump owes $3.2 billion to banks, $69.5 milion to subcontractors who helped build the Taj Mahal casino and is involved in 111 court cases, according to documents released Wednesday. The documents also reveal that several of Trump's marquee properties, including the Taj Mahal and the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan, may be worth hundreds of millions of dollars less than he claims. The asset analysis by the firm Kenneth Leventhal & Co. was among documents released by the state Casino Control Commission in advance of hearings Thursday and Friday over a $65 million rescue plan Trump reached with creditors in June. The papers _ which Trump unsuccessfully fought to keep private _ give some of the most detailed information yet about the troubled developer's holdings and the rescue plan. They also cover such matters as lawsuits and other court action by aggrieved parties ranging from his estranged wife Ivana to the New Jersey State Funeral Directors. Under the rescue plan, Trump gave up substantial control of his real estate and hotel empire in exchange for a debt restructuring that kept his holdings out of bankruptcy. Leventhal's report, based on figures as of April 30, said Trump controlled $4.6 billion in assets with a market value of $3.7 billion to $3.9 billion and a short-term liquidation value of $2.9 billion to $3.5 billion. The severity of Trump's financial problems began surfacing in June, after he missed a $43 million payment on bonds used to finance Trump Castle Casino Resort By the Bay and payments on a $30 million bank loan. The documents state that Trump has outstanding debts of $3.2 billion to lending institutions, including $933 million to Citibank. Trump already has pledged his three Atlantic City casinos _ Trump Castle, the Taj Mahal Casino Resort and Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino _ as collateral for new loans granted under the rescue plan. Trump put up his equity in the Taj Mahal as a guarantee of an existing $75 million loan by First Fidelity Bancorp.; his equity in Trump Castle to secure an existing $13 million loan by Midlantic Bank; and his equity in Trump Plaza to secure a $19.6 million letter of credit from National Westminster Bancorp. The restructuring also defers payments on some of the outstanding bonds for the three casinos and his Manhattan properties for three and five years. Trump spokesman Norma Foerderer said Trump would have no comment on the documents. A cover letter on the on the report prepared for Trump's lenders by Leventhal asked the commission to keep details of the restructuring plan confidential. ``This report contains highly confidential and sensitive information which is vital to Donald J. Trump,'' the letter said. ``Dissemination or disclosure of any or all the contents of this report could adversely affect those interests.'' The rescue plan also requires Trump to sell some assets to raise cash, although there has been speculation that such transactions could amount to a ``fire sale'' because some values were depressed. The major assets listed by Trump, with the value he assigns to them, the going market rate estimated by Leventhal and the short-term liquidation value estimated by Leventhal were: _ Taj Mahal and adjacent land: $1.06 billion, $767.5 million, and $740.7 million. _ Trump Plaza, the land under it and the adjacent land: $647.8 million, $555.2 million to $655.2 million, and between $412.4 million and $642.4 million. _ Trump Castle: $571.5 million, $400 million to $460 million, and $300 million to $350 million. _ The Plaza Hotel in Manhattan: $830 million, $450 million to $550 million, and $413.2 million to $500 million. _ The Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan: $150 million, $90 million to $110 million, and $80 million to $100 million. _ The Trump Shuttle airline: $340 million, $340 million, and $150 million to $300 million. Also included was a 29-page list of 111 legal matters involving Trump. They included lawsuits filed by Ivana Trump and by former securities analyst Marvin Roffman, who claimed he was fired due to complaints by Trump. Another complaint was filed by the New Jersey State Funeral Directors charging an alleged breach of a booking agreement at a Trump casino. Trump also owes $69.5 million to 253 subcontractors who worked on the Taj Mahal on projects from installing minarets and chandeliers to bathroom fixtures. The subcontractors who have not sued Trump for payment are negotiating with him for payment. Trump's attorneys lost an appeal Wednesday to keep the documents sealed. State Supreme Court Justice Alan Handler upheld a two-judge appellate panel's decision, rejecting Trump's argument that release of the documents would cause him undue harm.

DOC.HEAD: FundAmerica Inc. Will File Bankruptcy, Attorneys Say
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday extended an order freezing the assets of FundAmerica Inc., but refused to appoint a receiver to protect the marketing company's assets until bankruptcy papers are filed Thursday. The preliminary injunction issued by U.S. District Judge Marilyn Hall Patel was similar to a temporary restraining order that froze the assets last month. Attorneys for the plaintiffs in a $150 million class-action lawsuit asked Patel to appoint a receiver for the company, but were denied. Patel said that since FundAmerica's attorneys said they plan to seek protection from creditors while reorganizing under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws Thursday, a receiver is unnecessary. ``I don't intend to appoint a receiver for a day, a dubious position and just one more person who will have to be paid from the funds of FundAmerica,'' she said. Receivers are appointed by judges to manage troubled companies until a court rules on claims brought against the firm. She said the preliminary injunction freezing assets would remain in effect until a trustee is appointed by bankruptcy court to run the company's affairs. Company founder and former president Robert Edwards is charged in Florida with fraud for allegedly bilking club members out of $8.2 million in an illegal pyramid scheme. FundAmerica sold memberships in a discount buying club that offered rebates on services such as MCI long-distance calls and a range of consumer products. Various levels of memberships were sold through network marketing and multi-level sales. Attorneys in four states _ Florida, Washington, Texas and California _ have alleged FundAmerica may have run a pyramid scheme by selling multiple memberships to club members that they in turn could sell. The company maintains it is a legitimate consumer buying club. The class action suit seeks compensation for an undetermined number of members who did not recoup their total investment in the club. Patel certified the class in the suit on Wednesday.
